text: 1.2.2 Natural ventilation of occupied spaces must be achieved by providing a net openable area of windows or other openings to the outside of no less than 5% of the floor area.
paraphrase: If a space has natural ventilation and is occupied, then the net area of openings to the outside must be greater than 5 percent of the floor area.

text: 1.1.1 A fence erected to ensure security against unauthorised access to storage and treatment facilities shall comply with F5/AS1 Construction and Demolition Hazards.
paraphrase: If a storage or treatment facilities has a security fence, then the security fence shall comply with F5/AS1.

text: 1.2.1 Discharge to the sewer without pre-treatment – Where the network utility operator accepts the discharge of industrial liquid waste to a sewer without pre-treatment, the disposal system shall comply with Acceptable Solution G13/AS2.
paraphrase: If a disposal system discharges industrial liquid waste and the network utility operator accepts discharge of industrial liquid waste to a sewer with no pre-treatment, then the disposal system shall comply with G13/AS2.

text: 1.2.2 Discharge to the sewer after pre-treatment – Where the network utility operator accepts the discharge of industrial liquid waste to a sewer with pre-treatment, that part of the discharge system used to convey the waste after treatment shall comply with Acceptable Solution G13/AS2.
paraphrase: If a disposal system discharges industrial liquid waste and the network utility operator accepts discharge of industrial liquid waste to a sewer with pre-treatment and a disposal system part is after the treatement, then this disposal system part shall comply with G13/AS2.

text: 1.4.2 Occupant loads shall be calculated from the occupant densities given in Table 1.2 based on the floor area of the part of the building housing the activity. Table 1.2 Occupant densities; Activity; Occupancy density (m2/ person).
paraphrase: If a building part has an activity, then the building part's occupant load shall be calculated by the parts floor area times the part's occupant density as given in C/AS2 Table 1.2.

text: 1.4 Calculating occupant loads 1.4.3 Duplication shall be avoided by: a) Ensuring that, where people may be involved in more than one activity, they are counted only once.
paraphrase: If people are involved in more than one activity, then the people are counted only once.

text: 1.4.4 Occupant load assessment shall take account of the actual arrangement and number of seats for fixed seating (see Paragraph 3.7.4). Where additional floor area abuts the fixed seating, additional occupants are permitted in that floor area based on standing space density (see Table 1.2), provided the escape route is not obstructed.
paraphrase: If a space has fixed seating, then the occupant load shall take account of the actual arrangement and number of seats for fixed seating. Floor area adjacent to the fixed seating, the spaces occupant load may include the floor areas occupant load based on standing space density given in C/AS2 Table 1.2, provided the escape route is not obstructed.

text: 1.4.5 The requirements of this Acceptable Solution account for the fact that other people may be present in the building or firecell and additional calculations are not required when an occupant load is derived by bed spaces (i.e. for risk groups SM and SI).
paraphrase: If an occupant load is calculated by the number of bed spaces and the risk group is SM or SI, then additional calculations of the occupant load are not required.

text: 1.4.6 For the purposes of risk group SI the term 'bed' means the number of people that are under care or detention. It can include people on: a) Beds, or b) Recliner or lounge chairs, or c) Dentist chairs, or d) Treatment tables, or e) Any other furniture where an occupant may be for a period of treatment, in care or detention.
paraphrase: If the risk group is SI, then a bed is a person under care or detention. A beds include recliner or lounge chairs, or dentist chairs, or treatment tables, or treatment furniture.

text: 1.4.7 If, in a particular situation, the occupant load derived from Table 1.2 is clearly more than that which will occur, the basis of any proposal for a lesser occupant load shall be substantiated to the building consent authority.
paraphrase: If the expected occupant load of a space is less than the occupant load of the space as from C/AS2 Table 1.2, then the space's expected occupant load may be used for the fire safety design if the building consent authority shall approve the expected occupant load.

text: 1.4.8 If the maximum occupant load is greater than that calculated from Table 1.2, the higher number shall be used as the basis for the fire safety design and will need to be justified to the building consent authority.
paraphrase: If the maximum occupant load of a space is greater than the occupant load of the space as from C/AS2 Table 1.2, then the space's maximum occupant load shall be used for the fire safety design and the building consent authority shall approve the maximum occupant load.

text: 2.1.1 The floor area of firecells shall be limited in accordance with Table 2.1.
paraphrase: If a firecell exists, then the floor area of firecells shall be limited in accordance with C/AS2 Table 2.1.

text: This Acceptable Solution is one of three Acceptable Solutions that provide a means of establishing compliance with NZBC Clauses C1 to C6 Protection from Fire. It can be used for the building activities covered by risk groups specified in Paragraph 1.1.1 and described in Table 1.1.
paraphrase: If a building complies to CAS2 and the building risk groups are in C/AS2 Paragraph 1.1.1 and Table 1.1, then the building complies with NZBC Clauses C1, C2, C3, C4, C5, and C6.

text: C1-C6 Protection from Fire; For risk group SH, please refer to Acceptable Solution C/AS1.
paraphrase: If the building's risk group is SH, then the building may comply with C/AS1.

text: C1-C6 Protection from Fire; For backcountry huts, please refer to Acceptable Solution BCH/AS1.
paraphrase: If the building's activity is backcountry hut, then the building may comply with BCH/AS1.

text: 1.1.1 The scope of this Acceptable Solution is restricted to all risk groups listed in Table 1.1 except for risk group SH (refer to C/AS1).
paraphrase: If the building risk group is listed in Table 1.1 and the building's risk group is not SH, then C/AS1 applies to the building.

text: C1-C6 Protection from Fire; It covers buildings or parts of buildings where people: Sleep (SM).
paraphrase: If a buildings or parts of buildings has activity Sleeping or risk group SM, then CAS2 applies to the building and part.

text: C1-C6 Protection from Fire; It covers buildings or parts of buildings where people: Are unable to self-evacuate without assistance through requiring special care or treatment, or they are restrained, or their liberties are restricted (SI).
paraphrase: If either a buildings is either activity care or detention, or risk group SI, or parts of buildings is either activity care or detention, or risk group SI, then CAS2 applies to the building and part.

text: C1-C6 Protection from Fire; It covers buildings or parts of buildings where people: Congregate, participate in group activities or where professional services or retail are provided (CA).
paraphrase: If either a building is activity crowd, educational or personal service or risk group CA, or parts of a building are activity crowd, educational or personal service or risk group CA, then CAS2 applies to the building and part.

text: C1-C6 Protection from Fire; It covers buildings or parts of buildings where people: Work (WB - Business, professional services, industrial).
paraphrase: If either a building is activity business, professional service or industrial or risk group wb, or parts of buildings are activity business, professional service or industrial or risk group wb, then CAS2 applies to the building and part.

text: C1-C6 Protection from Fire; It covers buildings or parts of buildings where people: Store goods and other materials (WS - Storage and trade service).
paraphrase: If either a buildings has activity storage or trade service or risk group ws, or parts of buildings has activity storage or trade service or risk group ws, then CAS2 applies to the building and part.

text: C1-C6 Protection from Fire; It covers buildings or parts of buildings where people: Park vehicles (VP).
paraphrase: If a buildings or parts of buildings has activity vehicle parking or risk group VP, then CAS2 applies to the building and part.

text: 1.2.2 If a building contains a number of different activities which individually may be categorised in different risk groups, the risk group designated for a particular firecell within the building shall be that of the primary risk group. The primary risk group shall be that one within the firecell that has the most onerous fire safety requirements.
paraphrase: If a building contains a number of different activities, then the risk group designated for a particular firecell within the building shall be that of the primary risk group. The primary risk group shall be the firecell's risk group that has the maximum fire safety requirements.

text: 2.3 Fire resistance ratings 2.3.6 Floors shall have an FRR for exposure from the underside.
paraphrase: If a floor exists, then the underside of floors shall have an fire resistance ratings.

text: 2.3 Fire resistance ratings 2.3.7 The FRR of a primary element integral with a fire separation shall be no less than that of the fire separation.
paraphrase: If a primary element is part of a fire separation, then the element's fire resistance ratings shall be no less than the fire resistance rating of the fire separation.

text: 2.3.11 Structural framing members connected to building elements with an FRR shall be rated at no less than the building elements to which they are connected.
paraphrase: If the building's structural framing members and elements are connected and the element has a fire resistance rating, then the structural framing member's fire resistance rating shall be no less than the element's fire resistance rating.

text: 3.1.1 All buildings shall have means of escape from fire which include escape routes. An escape route (see Figure 3.1) shall provide protection to any occupant escaping to a safe place from a fire within a building.
paraphrase: If a building exists, then the building shall have means of escape from fire. The means of escape from fire includes escape routes. An escape route shall provide fire protection.

text: 3.1.2 The components of an escape route, in ascending order of protection, are the: a) Open paths, and b) Exitways, and c) Final exits (see Figure 3.1). Two or more of these components will be necessary.
paraphrase: If the component of an escape route includes Open paths, and Exitways, and Final exits, then the exitway's degree of protection shall be greater than the open path's degree of protection, and the final exit's degree of protection shall be greater than the exitway's degree of protection. Two or more of the escape route's components will be necessary.

text: 3.1.2 Exitways (these may comprise of smoke lobbies and safe paths).
paraphrase: If an exitway exists, then the exitway may include smoke lobbies and safe paths.

text: 3.1.3 Provided the allowable lengths of open paths (Table 3.2) are not exceeded, an escape route may comprise only an open path and final exit.
paraphrase: If the lengths of the escape route's open paths are as described in C/AS2 Table 3.2, then an escape route may comprise only an open path and final exit.

text: 3.1.4 Escape routes shall comply with NZBC D1.
paraphrase: If escape routes exist, then the escape routes shall comply with NZBC D1.

text: Ramps, stairs, ladders, landings, handrails, doors, vision panels and openings shall comply with Acceptable Solution D1/AS1.
paraphrase: If the building's elements are ramps, stairs, ladders, landings, handrails, doors, vision panels and openings, then the building's element shall comply with D1/AS1.

text: 3.2.1 Except where Paragraph 3.13 allows the use of single escape routes, every occupied space in a building shall be served by two or more escape routes (see Figure 3.2).
paraphrase: If the space's occupand load is greater 0 and C/AS2 3.13 does not allow the space to have single escape routes, then the spaces espace routes should be two ore more.

text: 4.1.1 Adjoining firecells are required to be fire separated from each other by the highest: a) Life rating specified in Paragraph 2.3 if both firecells are under common ownership, or b) Property rating specified in Paragraph 2.3 if both firecells are under different ownership.
paraphrase: If multiple firecells are adjoining, then there shall be a fire separation between the firecells, the fire separation's fire resistance rating shall be either the highest life rating of the firecells as specified in C/AS2 Paragraph 2.3 and both firecells have the same owner, or the fire separation's fire resistance rating shall be the highest property rating of the firecells as specified in C/AS2 Paragraph 2.3 and both firecells have not the same owner.

text: 1.0.1 This acceptable solution applies to below ground and above ground piped water supply systems.
paraphrase: If a piped water supply systems is below ground or above ground, then G12/AS1 applies to the piped water supply systems.

text: Piped water supply systems 2.1.1 Components of the water supply system shall not contaminate potable water.
paraphrase: If piped water supply system have components, then the components shall not cause contamination of potable water.

text: Piped water supply systems 2.2.1 Pipe and pipe fitting materials shall comply with Table 1.
paraphrase: If materials are for pipe and pipe fitting, then the materials shall comply with G12/AS1 Table 1.

text: Water tanks in roof spaces shall be located and supported as detailed in Figure 4.
paraphrase: If water tanks are in roof spaces, then the water tanks shall be located and supported as detailed in G12/AS1 Figure 4.

text: Piped water supply system 5.2.4 Covers; Covers shall be provided to: a) Potable water tanks to prevent contamination and the entry of vermin.
paraphrase: If a piped water supply system has a potable water tank, then the potable water tank shall have a cover.

text: Piped water supply system; Covers shall be provided to: All tanks located in roof spaces to prevent condensation damaging building elements.
paraphrase: If a piped water supply system has a water tank and the water tank is located in roof spaces, then the water tank shall have a cover.

text: Covers to water tanks shall be removable or shall contain a covered opening to allow access for inspection and maintenance. A minimum height clearance of 350 mm above the opening is necessary for easy access.
paraphrase: If water tanks have covers, then the cover shall be removable or shall have a covered opening. A minimum height clearance of 350 mm above the opening is necessary.

text: Structural support; The method illustrated in Figure 4 is acceptable for water tanks up to 150 litre capacity and the maximum height to breadth ratio of 1:1.
paraphrase: If a water tank has up to 150 litre capacity and the maximum height to breadth ratio of 1:1, then the structural support method illustrated in G12/AS1 Figure 4 is acceptable.

text: 5.3.1 Pipe sizing; Pipes shall be sized: a) To achieve the flow rates given in Table 3, or b) Using the sizes given in Table 4.
paraphrase: If pipes exist, then the pipes shall be sized to achieve the flow rates given in G12/AS1 Table 3, or the pipes shall use the sizes given in G12/AS1 Table 4.

text: 5.4.3 Provision shall be made for draining storage water heaters in accordance with Figure 7.
paraphrase: If storage water heaters exist, then the storage water heaters shall be drained in accordance with G12/AS1 Figure 7.

text: 6.1.1 Water heaters shall comply with Table 5.
paraphrase: If water heaters exist, then the water heaters shall comply with G12/AS1 Table 5.

text: 6.2.1 Storage water heaters shall be supplied with cold water at a pressure not exceeding their working pressure by means of a: a) Water tank, b) Pressure reducing valve, c) Pressure limiting valve, or d) Mains pressure supply.
paraphrase: If a storage water heater exists, then the storage water heater shall have cold water supply at a pressure not exceeding the storage water heaters working pressure by means of a: a) Water tank, b) Pressure reducing valve, c) Pressure limiting valve, or d) Mains pressure supply.

text: 6.2.2 Storage water heaters supplied by other than a water tank shall include a non-return valve as shown in Figures 7, 8, 9 and 10 to prevent the storage water heater emptying and hot water flowing into the cold water supply and thence from the cold water taps.
paraphrase: If storage water heaters have water supply not by a water tank, then the storage water heaters shall include a non-return valve as shown in G12/AS1 Figures 7, 8, 9 and 10.

text: 6.3.1 Electric and gas storage water heaters shall have their temperature controlled by a thermostat on each heating unit.
paraphrase: If storage water heaters are of type electric or gas, then for each heating unit of the storage water heater, the storage water heaters shall have a thermostat.

text: 6.3.2 Open vented storage water heaters shall have a vent pipe complying with Paragraph 6.8.
paraphrase: If storage water heaters are type open vented, then the storage water heaters shall have a ventilation pipe complying with G12/AS1 Paragraph 6.8.

text: Water heater system 6.3.3 Valve vented (unvented) systems shall have: a) An expansion control valve b) A vacuum relief valve to prevent collapse of the storage water heater where it is not designed to withstand a full vacuum, and c) Valves complying with Table 6.
paraphrase: If water heater system are type valve vented or unvented, then the water heater system shall have: a) An expansion control valve b) A vacuum relief valve or a design to withstand a full vacuum, and c) Valves complying with G12/AS1 Table 6.

text: 6.4.2 Free outlet (push through) water heaters shall have a relief valve.
paraphrase: If water heaters are type free outlet or push through, then the water heaters shall have a relief valve.

text: 3.4.1 Backflow protection shall be provided where it is possible for water or contaminants to backflow into the potable water supply system.
paraphrase: If in a potable water supply system backflow of water or contaminants is possible, then the water supply system shall have backflow protection.

text: Water supply system 3.4.5 The selection of the appropriate backflow protection for the cross connection hazard is given in Table 2.
paraphrase: If a water supply system has cross connection hazard, then the water supply system's backflow protection is given in G12/AS1 Table 2.

text: 3.4.6 All backflow prevention devices must be testable in service to verify effective performance.
paraphrase: If backflow prevention devices exist, then the backflow prevention devices must be testable in service.

text: Water supply system. Backflow protection. Air gap. 3.5.2 To ensure the air gap distance is maintained the overflow pipe discharge flow rate shall be no less than the inlet pipe flow rate.
paraphrase: If the water supply system's backflow protection is an air gap, then the overflow pipe discharge flow rate shall be no less than the inlet pipe flow rate.

text: 3.5.4 Where any fixture or tank has more than one supply pipe, the air gap separation shall be the greater of 25 mm or twice the sum of the inlet pipe diameters and shall also comply with Paragraph 3.5.2.
paraphrase: If any fixture or tank has more than one inlet pipe, then the air gap separation shall be greater than 25 mm and greater than twice the sum of the inlet pipe diameters and shall also comply with G12/AS1 3.5.2.

text: 3.6.2 Manufacture; Backflow prevention devices shall be manufactured as follows: a) Reduced pressure zone devices to AS/NZS 2845.1 Section 12 (see Figure 2 (a)).
paraphrase: If a backflow prevention device is a reduced pressure zone device, then the backflow prevention device shall be manufactured to AS/NZS 2845.1 Section 12.

text: 3.6.2 Manufacture; Backflow prevention devices shall be manufactured as follows: Double check valve devices to AS/NZS 2845.1 Section 10 (see Figure 2 (b)).
paraphrase: If a backflow prevention device is a double check valve device, then the backflow prevention device shall be manufactured to AS/NZS 2845.1 Section 10.

text: 3.6.2 Manufacture; Backflow prevention devices shall be manufactured as follows: Pressure type vacuum breakers to AS/NZS 2845.1 Section 9, (see Figure 2 (c)).
paraphrase: If a backflow prevention device is a pressure type vacuum breaker, then the backflow prevention device shall be manufactured to AS/NZS 2845.1 Section 9.

text: Backflow prevention devices shall be manufactured as follows: Atmospheric vacuum breakers to AS/NZS 2845.1 Section 4 for atmospheric vacuum breakers (see Figure 2 (d)).
paraphrase: If a backflow prevention device is a atmospheric vacuum breaker, then the backflow prevention device shall be manufactured to AS/NZS 2845.1 Section 9.

text: 3.6.2 Manufacture; Backflow prevention devices shall be manufactured as follows: AS/NZS 2845.1 Section 5 for hose tap vacuum breakers.
paraphrase: If a backflow prevention device is a hose tap vacuum breaker, then the backflow prevention device shall be manufactured to AS/NZS 2845.1 Section 5.

text: Piped Water Supply System 3.7.2 Reduced pressure zone devices shall be tested and verified as meeting the test requirements of AS 2845.3 or NZ backflow testing standard.
paraphrase: If the piped water supply system has a reduced pressure zone device, then the reduced pressure zone device shall be tested and verified as of AS 2845.3 or NZ backflow testing standard.

text: Piped Water Supply System 3.7.2 Double check valves shall be tested and verified as meeting the test requirements of AS 2845.3 or NZ backflow testing standard.
paraphrase: If the piped water supply system has a double check valve, then the double check valve shall be tested and verified as of AS 2845.3 or NZ backflow testing standard.

text: Piped Water Supply System 3.7.2 Pressure vacuum breakers shall be tested and verified as meeting the test requirements of AS 2845.3 or NZ backflow testing standard.
paraphrase: If the piped water supply system has a pressure vacuum breaker, then the pressure vacuum breaker shall be tested and verified as of AS 2845.3 or NZ backflow testing standard.

text: 5.1.1 To ensure the health and safety of people in the event of the water main supply being interrupted, buildings having the classification of Community Care (e.g. hospitals, old people's homes, prisons) shall be provided with cold water storage of no less than 50 litres per person.
paraphrase: If buildings have the classification of Community Care, then the building shall be provided with cold water storage with a capacity of no less than 50 litres per person.

text: A direct connection to Fire and Emergency New Zealand is not required if automatic heat or smoke detection systems are provided in addition to the systems required by this Acceptable Solution.
paraphrase: If a space has an supplementary fire safety system for automatic heat or smoke detection, then a fire service direct connection is not required.

text: a) In single storey early childhood centres, dedicated sleeping areas shall be protected with supplementary smoke detectors. The alarm system and any smoke detection system shall comply with NZS 4512.
paraphrase: If there is one building storey and the space activity is early childhood and sleeping, then the space shall be protected with supplementary smoke detectors complying with NZS 4512.

text: the fire safety systems required for firecells in early childhood centres shall be as follows: Where the escape height of the early childhood centre is greater than 2.0 m, a Type 7 system shall be installed throughout the building.
paraphrase: If the firecell activity is early childhood centre and the firecell escape height is greater than 2.0 m, then a Type 7 fire safety system shall be installed throughout the building.

text: 2.2.2 In addition to Paragraph 2.2.1, the fire safety systems required for firecells in early childhood centres shall be as follows: If the early childhood centre is not located on the ground floor at least two separate places of safety shall be provided. Each place of safety shall be separated with fire separations designed to the property rating and have direct access to a safe path or final exit.
paraphrase: If firecell activity is early childhood centre and it is not located on the ground floor, then at least two places of safety shall be provided. Each place of safety shall be separated with fire separations designed to the property rating and the place of safety shall have direct access to a safe path or final exit.

text: 2.2.4 For risk group VP firecells that require a fire sprinkler system (refer to Table 2.2d), the fire sprinkler system does not need to be extended throughout the remainder of the building where the risk group VP firecells are fire separated from the adjacent firecells. The fire separation between adjacent firecells is required to be provided with the greater of the property rating of the adjacent firecells (refer to Table 2.4).
paraphrase: If the firecell's risk group is VP and the firecell require a fire sprinkler system as per C/AS2 Table 2.2.d and the risk group VP firecells are fire separated from the adjacent firecells and the fire resistance rating of the fire separation is the greater of the property rating of the adjacent firecells, with the property rating as in C/AS2 Table 2.4, then the remainder of the building may not have the fire sprinkler system.

text: 2.2.6 Where fire separations are not needed between different risk groups on the same floor level, the fire safety systems adopted for the firecell shall be those of the primary risk group (as defined in Paragraph 1.2.2).
paraphrase: If there are different risk groups on the same floor level and fire separations are not needed between different risk groups, then the firecell's fire safety systems should be the fire safety systems of the primary risk group and the primary risk group shall be as defined in C/AS2 Paragraph 1.2.2.

text: 2.2.8 The alarm systems required in a building shall be configured to alert all building occupants in the event of fire.
paraphrase: If the fire alarm systems is required in a building, then the fire alarm system shall be configured to alert all building occupants in the event of fire.

text: 2.3.1 Unless explicitly stated otherwise in this Acceptable Solution, the fire resistance ratings (FRRs) that apply for each risk group shall be in accordance with Table 2.4.
paraphrase: If risk groups fire resistance rating has no exception in C/AS2, then the fire resistance ratings for each risk group shall be in accordance with C/AS2 Table 2.4.

text: 2.3.2 Structural elements in a single storey building need not be fire rated if FRRs are not required for any other reason.
paraphrase: If a building has one storey and the building's structural elements require no fire resistance rating, then the element may not have fire resistance rating.

text: 2.3 Fire resistance ratings 2.3.3 If there is more than one risk group on one floor in the building, the highest required FRR shall be applied to common spaces and shared escape routes for that floor level.
paraphrase: If there is more than one risk group on one floor and the floor's space is a common space or shared escape route, then the highest fire resistance rating of the risk groups shall be applied to the space.

text: 2.3 Fire resistance ratings 2.3.4 FRRs shall apply to the sides of primary elements and secondary elements which are exposed to fire.
paraphrase: If an element is primary or secondary and has a fire resistance rating and a side is exposed to fire, then the fire resistance rating shall apply to this side.

text: 6.8.1 Vent pipes for open vented storage water heaters shall comply with the provisions of Paragraphs 6.8.2 and 6.8.3.
paraphrase: If an open vented storage water heater has a ventilation pipe, then the ventilation pipe shall comply with G12/AS1 6.8.2 and 6.8.3.

text: 6.9.1 NZS 4603 is an acceptable solution for open vented low pressure storage water heaters, but may exceed the performance criteria of NZBC G12.
paraphrase: If storage water heaters are type open vented and low pressure, then the storage water heaters may comply with NZS 4603.

text: 6.10.1 NZS 4607 is an acceptable solution for unvented (valve vented) storage water heaters, but may exceed the performance criteria of NZBC G12.
paraphrase: If storage water heaters are type unvented or valve vented, then the storage water heaters may comply with NZS 4607.

text: 6.11.1 Water heaters shall be installed in accordance with the manufacturer's instructions.
paraphrase: If water heaters exist, then the water heaters shall be installed in accordance with the manufacturer's instructions.

text: 6.12.1 The diameter of hot water supply pipes from storage water heaters and to sanitary fixtures shall be no less than those required by Table 4.
paraphrase: If hot water supply pipes are between storage water heaters and sanitary fixtures, then the diameter of the hot water supply pipes shall be according to G12/AS1 Table 4.

text: 6.13.1 Wet-back water heaters shall be: a) Connected only to open vented storage water heaters, or a water storage vessel (see Figure 15), and b) Made of copper.
paraphrase: If water heaters are type wet-back, then the water heaters shall be connected to open vented storage water heaters or a water storage vessel, and the water heaters shall be made of copper.

text: Wet-back water heater 6.13.2 Copper pipework shall be used between the wet-back and the water tank.
paraphrase: If pipework is between the wet-back water heater and the water tank, then the pipe work material shall be copper.

text: 6.14.3 Legionella bacteria; Irrespective of whether a mixing device is installed, the storage water heater control thermostat shall be set at a temperature of not less than 60°C to prevent the growth of Legionella bacteria.
paraphrase: If the storage water heater has a control thermostat, then the control thermostat shall be set at a temperature of not less than 60 degC.

text: 3.5.1 All joints in drains shall be watertight and prevent the infiltration of groundwater and the intrusion of tree roots.
paraphrase: If the drain has joints, the joints shall be watertight and prevent the infiltration of groundwater and the intrusion of tree roots.

text: 3.5.2 Acceptable jointing methods and the relevant standards are given in Table 3. Jointing of drains shall be subject to the tests called for in Paragraph 3.8.
paraphrase: If the drain has a joint, then the joint shall be as given in E1/AS1 Table 3 and tested as in E1/AS1 Paragraph 3.8.

text: 3.6.1 All surface water, except that collected directly from a roof, shall enter the drain via a sump.
paraphrase: If the drain is for surface water, and the surface water is not from the roof, then the surface water shall enter the drain via a sump.

text: 3.6 Surface water inlets to drains; Via a sump which has: a) A grating, hinged or removable for maintenance access. The grating shall comprise at least 35% openings. The smaller dimension of any individual opening shall not exceed 35 mm.
paraphrase: If a sump exists, then the sump shall have a grating that is hinged or removable. The grating shall have openings, where the openings area is at least 35 percent of the gratings area. The smaller dimension of any individual opening shall not exceed 35 mm.

text: 3.6 Surface water inlets to drains; Via a sump which has: Capacity at the bottom for settlement of silt and debris.
paraphrase: If a sump exists, then the sump shall have capacity at the bottom for settlement of silt and debris.

text: 3.6 Surface water inlets to drains; Via a sump which has: A submerged (or trapped) outlet which prevents floatable solids entering the drain.
paraphrase: If a sump exists, then the sump shall have a submerged or trapped outlet.

text: 3.7.1 Access for maintenance shall be provided on all drains.
paraphrase: If a drain exists, then the drain shall have access points.

text: 3.7.2 Points of access shall be spaced at no further than: a) 50 m where rodding points are used.
paraphrase: If access points are rodding points, then the access points shall be spaced at no further than 50 m.

text: 3.7.2 Points of access shall be spaced at no further than: 100 m where inspection points, inspection chambers or access chambers are used.
paraphrase: If access points are inspection points, inspection chambers or access chambers, then the access points shall be spaced at no further than 100 m.

text: 3.7.3 Points of access are required at: Changes in direction of greater than 45°,.
paraphrase: If a drain has changes in direction of greater than 45 deg, then the drain shall have an access point at the change in direction

text: 3.7.3 Points of access are required at: Changes in gradient of greater than 45°.
paraphrase: If a drain has changes in gradient of greater than 45 deg, then the drain shall have an access point at the change in gradient.

text: 3.7.3 Points of access are required at: Junctions of drains other than a drain, serving a single downpipe, that is less than 2.0 m long.
paraphrase: If a drain has a junction, and the drain flows not into a single downpipe, that is less than 2 m long, then the drain shall have an access point at the junction.

text: 3.7.4 Inspection chambers or access chambers (see Figures 11 and 12) shall be provided where changes in both gradient and direction occur and where either is greater than 22.5°.
paraphrase: If changes in both gradient and direction occur in the same location and either the change in gradient or change in direction is greater than 22.5 deg, then access points shall be provided as inspection chambers or access chambers at the location of the change.

text: 3.7.5 Where the depth to the invert of the drain exceeds 1.0 m, an inspection chamber is not acceptable and an access chamber shall be used.
paraphrase: IF the depth to the invert of the drain exceeds 1 m, then an inspection chamber is not acceptable as access point but an access chamber shall be used.

text: 3.7.6 Drain under buildings; Any drain laid under a building shall be run in a straight line from one side to the other.
paraphrase: If the drain's section is under a building, then the drain's section shall not include any changes in direction.

text: 3.7.7 Access to a drain laid under a building shall be provided immediately outside the building. These points of access shall be located within 2.0 m of an exterior wall.
paraphrase: If a drain is under a building, then the drain's access point location shall be outside the building. These access points shall be located within 2 m of an exterior wall of the building.

text: 3.7.8 Under a building the only acceptable inlets to a drain are from sealed roof-water downpipes.
paraphrase: If the drain inlet is under the building, then the inlet shall be a sealed roof-water downpipe.

text: 6.14.4 The water temperatures within flow and return circulating systems shall be maintained at not less than 60°C.
paraphrase: If flow and return circulating systems exist, then the flow and return circulating systems shall have water temperatures of not less than 60 degC.

text: 7.0.1 Water supply systems shall be installed to comply with the durability requirements of NZBC B2.
paraphrase: If water supply systems exist, then the durability of water supply systems shall comply with NZBC B2.

text: 7.1.1 Pipes and their supports shall be electrochemically compatible.
paraphrase: If pipes have support, then the pipes and supports shall be electrochemically compatible.

text: Pipes penetrating concrete or masonry elements shall be either wrapped with a flexible material, or passed through a sleeve or duct, to permit free movement for expansion and contraction.
paraphrase: If pipes go into concrete or masonry elements, then the pipes shall be either wrapped with a flexible material, or passed through a sleeve or duct.

text: Piped water supply system; 7.4.1 An acceptable method of installing uPVC pipe is given in NZS 7643.
paraphrase: If pipes are material uPVC, then the installation of the pipe may follow NZS 7643.

text: 1.0.1 This Acceptable Solution is limited to buildings and sitework having a catchment area of no more than 0.25 hectares and which are: a) Free from a history of flooding, b) Not adjacent to a watercourse, c) Not located in low lying area, and d) Not located in a secondary flow path.
paraphrase: If either buildings have a catchment area of no more than 0.25 hectares and which are not flood prone, not adjacent to a watercourse, not located in low lying area, and not located in a secondary flow path, or sitework has a catchment area of no more than 0.25 hectares and which are not flood prone, not adjacent to a watercourse, not located in low lying area, and not located in a secondary flow path, then E1/AS1 applies to the building or sitework.

text: 2.0.1 Suspended floors and slabs on ground shall be at least 150 mm above the finished level of the surrounding ground immediately adjacent to the building.
paraphrase: If floors are type suspended or slabs are on ground, then the elevation of the floor and slab shall be at least 150 mm above the elevation of the ground adjacent to the building.

text: 2.0.1 Suspended floors and slabs on ground: a) For sites level with or above the road shall no less than 150 mm above the road crown.
paraphrase: If the site's elevation is with or above the road and floors are suspended and slabs are on ground, then the floors and slabs shall be no less than 150 mm above the road crown.

text: 2.0.1 Suspended floors and slabs on ground shall be, for sites below the road, no less than 150 mm above the lowest point on the site boundary (see Figure 2).
paraphrase: If sites are below the road and floors are suspended or slabs are on ground, then the floors and slabs shall be no less than 150 mm above the lowest point on the site boundary.

text: 3.1.1 Pipe materials shall comply with the standards given in Table 1.
paraphrase: If pipes exist, then the pipe materials shall comply with E1/AS1 Table 1.

text: Drains shall be capable of handling the rainfall during a storm. No drain shall have an internal diameter of less than 85 mm.
paraphrase: If drains exist, then the drains shall be for storm water. Drain shall have an internal diameter of no less than 85 mm.

text: 3.2.2 Figure 3 provides a method for selecting the correct pipe size for a calculated modified catchment area, given as: Modified catchment area = 0.01 Al, where A = area being drained comprising plan roof area (m2) plus paved area (m2), and l is rainfall intensity.
paraphrase: If a modified catchment area exists, then the pipe for the modified catchment area may have a pipe size as provided in E1/AS1 Figure 3. The modified catchment area equals 0.01 Al, where A is the plan roof area plus paved area and l is rainfall intensity.

text: 3.3.1 Drains shall be laid on a uniform line and gradient between points of access (see Paragraph 3.7).
paraphrase: If a drains section is between points of access, then the drain section shall not include any changes in direction and gradient.

text: The change in direction of a drain shall not exceed 90° at any point.
paraphrase: If a drain has a change in direction, then the change in direction shall not exceed 90 deg.

text: The change in direction of a drain where practical should be kept to less than 45° as illustrated in Figure 4.
paraphrase: If a small change in direction of a drain is practical, then the change in direction should be less than 45 deg.

text: 3.3.2 Where two drains intersect, the directions of flow as shown in Figure 5 shall be at an angle of 60° or less.
paraphrase: If drains intersect, then the drain's flow directions shall be 60 deg or less.

text: 3.4.1 Minimum acceptable gradients for surface water drains are given in Table 2.
paraphrase: If the drain is a surface water drain, then the drains gradients shall be greater or equal as the value given in E1/AS1 Table 2.

text: 3.0 Drainage System Materials and Construction; 3.4.2 Restricted fall to outlet; Where the surface water sewer, road channel or other outfall is at too high a level to allow the gradient required by Table 2, the bubble-up chamber system shown in Figures 6 and 7 may be used.
paraphrase: If the outfall elevation has a greater value as required by E1/AS1 Table 2, then the drain may have a bubble-up chamber.

text: The ground level adjacent to any downpipe discharging to the bubble-up chamber is at least 150 mm higher than the level of the top of the chamber outlet.
paraphrase: If adownpipe is discharging to the bubble-up chamber, then the elevation of the ground adjacent to the downpipe shall be at least 150 mm higher than the elevation of the top of the bubble-up chamber outlet.

text: 3.0 Drainage System Materials and Construction; The bubble-up chamber system shown in Figures 6 and 7 may be used provided that: The connections between the drain and downpipes are sealed.
paraphrase: If the drain has a bubble-up chamber, then the connections between the drain and downpipes shall be sealed.

text: 3.0 Drainage System Materials and Construction; The bubble-up chamber system shown in Figures 6 and 7 may be used provided that: The total chamber depth does not exceed 1.0 m.
paraphrase: If the drain has a bubble-up chamber, then the bubble-up chamber depth shall not exceed 1 m.

text: 6.5.1 Electric thermostats and energy cut-off devices shall comply with NZS 6214 or AS 1308.
paraphrase: If a device is an electric thermostats or an energy cut-off devices, then it shall comply with NZS 6214 or AS 1308.

text: 6.5.2 Energy cut-off devices shall be designed to: a) Be reset manually.
paraphrase: If energy cut-off devices exist, then the energy cut-off devices shall be designed to have a manual reset.

text: 6.6.2 Pressure relief valves and expansion control valves shall have: a) A flow rate capacity of no less than the rate of cold water supply, and b) A maximum pressure rating of no more than the working pressure of the hot water storage vessel.
paraphrase: If valves are pressure relief valves or expansion control valves, then the valves shall have: a) A flow rate capacity of no less than the flow rate of the cold water supply, and b) A maximum pressure rating of no more than the working pressure of the hot water storage vessel.

text: 6.6.3 Expansion control valves shall have a pressure rating of no less than that of the water supply pressure to the storage water heater, but less than the pressure rating of the relief valve.
paraphrase: If a storage water heater has an expansion control valves, then the expansion control valves shall have a pressure rating of no less than that of the water supply pressure to the storage water heater, but the expansion control valves shall have a pressure rating less than the pressure rating of the relief valve.

text: 6.6.4 The following valves shall have an energy rating greater than that of the energy sources heating the water: Temperature/pressure relief valve.
paraphrase: If the water heater has a temperature pressure relief valve, then the valve shall have an energy rating greater than that of the energy sources of the water heater.

text: Pressure relief valves shall be located no further than 1 metre from the storage water heater.
paraphrase: If the storage water heater hast a pressure relief valves, then the pressure relief valves shall be located no further than 1 metre from the storage water heater's location.

text: 6.7.1 Relief valve drains (see Figures 12 and 13) shall be fitted to: a) Temperature/pressure relief valves, Pressure relief valves, and c) Expansion control valves.
paraphrase: If the valve is either a temperature pressure relief valve, pressure relief valve, or expansion control valve, then the valve shall have a relief valve drains.

text: 4.1.2 Downpipes, gutters, roofing, fastenings and all adjoining components shall be of the same or a compatible material to eliminate the risk of galvanic corrosion.
paraphrase: If given two components, either both componenst are downpipes, gutters, roofing, or fastenings, or if one component is downpipes, gutters, roofing, fastenings and the other component is adjoining, then the components materials shall either be equal or have galvanic compatibility between them.

text: 4.2.1 Downpipes sized using Table 5 are acceptable. Other downpipes are acceptable provided their cross-sectional area is no less than that required by Table 5, and they permit passage of a 50 mm diameter sphere.
paraphrase: If downpipes exist, then the downpipes shall have either a size acoording to E1/AS1 Table 5, or the downpipe have a cross-sectional area complying with E1/AS1 Table 5 and a diameter greater than 50 mm.

text: 4.3.1 Where thermal movement of downpipes cannot be accommodated by movement of the guttering, expansion joints shall be incorporated.
paraphrase: If the downpipe's thermal expansion is greater than the movement of the downpipe's guttering, then the downpipe shall have expansion joints.

text: 4.3.2 All internal downpipes shall withstand without leakage, a water test with an applied head of 1.5 m of water, or a high pressure air test as described in E1/VM1 Paragraph 8.3.
paraphrase: If the downpipes is located internal, then the downpipe shall be either tested with a water test with an applied head of 1.5 m, or tested with a high pressure air test as described in E1/VM1 Paragraph 8.3.

text: 5.1.1 Roof gutters shall discharge to downpipes that are sized as given in Paragraph 4.2.
paraphrase: If roof gutters exist, then the roof gutters shall discharge to downpipes that are sized as given in E1/AS1 Paragraph 4.2.

text: 5.0 Roof Gutters 5.1.4 In no case shall the cross-sectional area of any gutter be less than 4000 mm2.
paraphrase: If roof gutters exist, then the roof gutters shall have a cross-sectional area of no less than 4000 mm2.

text: 5.2.1 Roof gutter materials shall comply with the standards stated in Table 6.
paraphrase: If roof gutters exist, then the roof gutter's materials shall comply with the standards as given in E1/AS1 Table 6.

text: 5.3.1 Roof gutters shall fall to an outlet.
paraphrase: If roof gutters exist, then the roof gutters shall fall to an outlet.

text: 5.0 Roof Gutters 5.5.1 All internal gutters shall be fitted with overflow outlets which drain to the exterior of the building. The top of the outlet shall be set at least 50 mm below the top of the gutter.
paraphrase: If a roof gutter is internal, then the roof gutter shall be fitted with overflow outlets which drain to the exterior of the building. The top of the overflow outlet shall be set at least 50 mm below the top of the gutter.

text: 5.0 Roof Gutters 5.5.2 External gutters do not require overflow outlets but shall be installed to ensure any overflow from the gutter spills to the outside of the building.
paraphrase: If roof gutters are external, then the roof gutters do not require overflow outlets but overflow from the gutter shall go to the outside of the building.

text: 1.1.1 Building elements, including materials, components and systems, complying with a publication referenced in the Acceptable Solutions and Verification Methods, satisfy B2 requirements only when the conditions of use stated in the publication and Acceptable Solutions and Verification Methods prevail.
paraphrase: If a publication is referenced in B2/AS or B2/VM, and either building elements, materials, components or systems comply with the publication, and the conditions of use stated in the publication and B2/AS and B2/VM are true, then the building elements, materials, components or systems comply with NZBC B2.

text: 2.1.2 It is the responsibility of the person specifying the building element to determine normal maintenance requirements. These may be based on the manufacturer's recommendations and may also include periodic inspections of elements not readily observable without a specific effort (e.g. access to roof or subfloor spaces).
paraphrase: If a building element has a specifier, then the building element shall have maintainance requirements specified by this specifier. These maintainance requirements may include manufacturer's recommendations and periodic inspections of elements not observable.

text: All slab-on-ground reinforcing shall extend to within 75 mm of the outside edge of the slab (including the foundation wall) and shall consist of a minimum 2.27kg/m2 welded Grade 500E reinforcing mesh sheets (1.14 kg/m2 in each direction), which shall be lapped at sheet joints such that the overlap measurement between the outermost cross wires of each fabric sheet is equal to the greater of one of the following: the spacing of cross wires plus 50 mm, 150 mm, or the manufacturer's requirements. Slabs shall have a maximum dimension of 18 m between free joints.
paraphrase: If slabs are on ground and have reinforcing, the reinforcing shall extend to within 75 mm of the outside edge of the slab and the reinforcing shall consist of sheets from welded reinforcing mesh with grade 500E and weight of minimum 2.27kg/m2 and the sheets shall have minimum 1.14 kg/m2 for each direction of the slab, and sheet joints shall be lapped such that the lap measurement is between the outermost cross wires of each fabric sheet and is greater than or equal the spacing of cross wires plus 50 mm, 150 mm, or the manufacturer's requirements. Slabs shall have a maximum dimension of 18 m between free joints.

text: 2.1.3 NZS 4229; Grade 500E welded steel mesh; Where Grade 500E welded steel mesh is specified, it shall meet the requirements of Paragraph 14.0 in B1/VM1.
paraphrase: If Grade 500E welded steel mesh is used, then the welded steel mesh shall meet the requirements of Paragraph 14.0 in B1/VM1.

text: Structure Design 3.0 Timber 3.1 NZS 3604.
paraphrase: If the material of a structure is timer, then the structures design shall comply with NZS 3604.

text: All the area within the Christchurch City Council boundary is within Zone 2.
paraphrase: If an area is within the Christchurch City Council boundary, then the area is within Zone 2.

text: The lowest zone within the Selwyn or Waimakariri District Council boundaries is within Zone 2. Areas within Selwyn District that are designated as Zone 1 in NZS 3604 shall become Zone 2.
paraphrase: If either the zone is the lowest and either within the Selwyn District Council or Waimakariri District Council boundaries is within Zone 2, or the areas within Selwyn District Council are designated as Zone 1 in NZS 3604, then the zone is is within Zone 2 and the area is is Zone 2.

text: 2.1.3 Basic normal maintenance tasks shall include but not be limited to: a) Where applicable, following manufacturers' maintenance recommendations, b) Washing down surfaces, particularly exterior building elements subject to wind driven salt spray, c) Re-coating interior and exterior protective finishes, d) Replacing sealant, seals and gaskets in joints, e) Replacing valves, washers and similar high wear components in easily accessed service equipment and other building elements, f) Cleaning and replacing filters in building services systems, g) The regular servicing of boilers, cooling towers, lifts, escalators, emergency lighting and fire protection equipment, and h) The maintenance of signs for access, escape routes, emergency equipment and hazardous areas.
paraphrase: If the the maintenance is basic or normal, then the maintenance's tasks shall include the manufacturers recommendations, and the maintenance tasks shall include washing down surfaces, and the maintenance tasks shall include recoating interior protective finishes and exterior protective finishes, and the maintenance tasks shall include replacing joint sealant, joint seals, joint gaskets, valves, washers and high wear components, and the maintenance tasks shall include cleaning building services system filters and replacing building services system filters, and the maintenance tasks shall include the regular servicing of boiler, cooling tower, lift, escalator, emergency lighting, fire protection equipment, and the maintenance tasks shall include maintaining signs type access, escape route, emergency equipment and hazardous area.

text: 2.2.1 Scheduled maintenance comprises the inspection, maintenance and reporting procedures for building elements required to have a compliance schedule in terms of section 44 of the Building Act. The relevant maintenance procedures may include total replacement.
paraphrase: If building elements are required to have a maintenance schedule in terms of section 44 of the Building Act, then the maintenance schedule includes procedures for inspection, maintenance and reporting. The procedures may include total replacement.

text: 3.3.1 NZS 4251: Part 1 is an acceptable solution for meeting the durability requirements of cement plasters for walls, ceilings and soffits within its scope.
paraphrase: If cement plasters are for walls, ceilings and soffits, then the cement plaster's durability may comply with NZS 4251: Part 1.

text: 3.4.1 NZS 4297 and NZS 4299 are acceptable solutions for meeting the durability requirements of earth buildings within their scope.
paraphrase: If building material is earth, then the buildings durability may comply with NZS 4297 and NZS 4299.

text: 3.5.1 NZS 4223.2 is an Acceptable Solution for meeting the durability requirements of insulating glass units, within its scope.
paraphrase: If insulating glass units exist, then the durability of insulating glass units may comply with NZS 4297 and NZS 4299.

text: 3.6.1 SNZ TS 3404: SNZ TS 3404 is an Acceptable Solution for meeting the durability requirements of steel building elements within its scope.
paraphrase: If building elements are steel, then the building elements durability may comply with SNZ TS 3404.

text: Structure Design 1.1 B1/AS1 contains Acceptable Solutions for Masonry (Paragraph 2.0), Timber (Paragraph 3.0), Earth Buildings (Paragraph 4.0) and Stucco (Paragraph 5.0), Drains (Paragraph 6.0) and Glazing (Paragraph 7.0).
paraphrase: If either the structure materials are Masonry, Timber, Earth or Stucco, or structures for Drains or glazing is part of structures, then B1/AS1 applies to the structure.

text: Structure Design 1.2 B1/AS gives an Acceptable Solution for small chimneys (referred to in Paragraph 8.0).
paraphrase: If the structure is a small sized chimney, then B1/AS1 applies to the structure.

text: Inlet to a drain under a building; Access shall be provided to the drain via a sealed access point in the downpipe immediately above ground floor level.
paraphrase: If the drain inlet is under the building, then the drain shall have an sealed access point in the downpipe, the elevation of the access point shall be above ground floor.

text: 3.8.1 Surface water drains shall be capable of passing one of the tests described in E1/VM1 Paragraph 8.0.
paraphrase: If the drain type is surface water, then the drain shall pass one of the tests described in E1/VM1 Paragraph 8.0.

text: 3.9.2 Bedding and backfilling; Figure 13 gives acceptable solutions for the bedding and backfilling of the drainage pipes listed in Table 1 except where: a) The trench is located within or above peat, or b) Scouring of the trench is likely due to unstable soils, or d) The cover H to the pipe is more than 2.5 m.
paraphrase: If bedding and backfilling of the drainage pipes are listed in E1/AS1 Table 1, and the trench, the drainage pipe is in, is not located within or above peat, and the trench soil is not unstable, and the cover height to the pipe is not more than 2.5 m, then the bedding and backfilling may comply with E1/AS1 Figure 13.

text: 3.9.3 Trench slope; Where the slope of the trench is 1 in 8 or greater, anti-scour blocks shall be provided.
paraphrase: If the slope of the trench is 1 in 8 or greater, then the trench shall have anti-scour blocks.

text: These anti-scour blocks shall be: Constructed from 150 mm thick concrete (17 MPa).
paraphrase: If anti-scour blocks exist, then the anti-scour blocks shall be made of 150 mm thick concrete with strength 17 MPa.

text: 3.9.3 Trench slope; These anti-scour blocks shall be: Extended to ground level where the drain cover is less than 300 mm.
paraphrase: If the trench has anti-scour blocks, the drain is in the trench, and the drain cover is less than 300 mm, then these anti-scour blocks shall be ground level elevation.

text: 3.9.3 Trench slope; These anti-scour blocks shall be: Spaced at: 7.5 m centres for trench slopes between 1 in 8 and 1 in 5.
paraphrase: If the trench has anti-scour blocks and the trench slopes greater than or equal 1 in 8 and less than or equal 1 in 5, then these anti-scour blocks shall be spaced at 7.5 m centres.

text: 3.9.3 Trench slope; These anti-scour blocks shall be: Spaced at: 5.0 m centres for trench slopes greater than 1 in 5.
paraphrase: If the trench has anti-scour blocks and the trench slopes greater than 1 in 5, then these anti-scour blocks shall be spaced at  5 m centres.

text: 3.9.4 Trench width; The width B of the trench shall be no less than the pipe diameter D plus 200 mm. Trench width at the top of the pipe shall be no more than 600 mm unless the pipe(s) in the trench are covered with concrete, as shown in Figure 13 (c).
paraphrase: If the pipe is in a trench, then the width of the trench shall be no less than the pipe diameter plus 200 mm. Either trench width at the top of the pipe shall be no more than 600 mm or the pipis covered with concrete.

text: Acceptable fill materials shown in Figure 13 are: Bedding material of clean granular non-cohesive material with a maximum particle size of 20 mm.
paraphrase: If the fill material is bedding material, then the fill material shall be of clean granular non-cohesive material with a maximum particle size of 20 mm.

text: Acceptable fill materials shown in Figure 13 are: Selected compacted fill of any fine-grained soil or granular material which is free from topsoil and rubbish and has a maximum particle size of 20 mm.
paraphrase: If the fill materials is selected compacted fill, then the fill materials shall be of any fine-grained soil or granular material, the fill material shall not include topsoil and rubbish and has a maximum particle size of 20 mm.

text: Acceptable fill materials shown in Figure 13 are: Ordinary fill which may comprise any fill or excavated material.
paraphrase: If the fill material is ordinary fill, then the fill material may include any fill or excavated material

text: Trench 3.9.6 Placing and compacting a) Granular bedding and selected fill shall be placed in layers of no greater than 100 mm loose thickness and compacted.
paraphrase: If granular bedding or selected fill exist, then the granular bedding and selected fill shall be placed in layers of no greater than 100 mm loose thickness and the layer shall be compacted.

text: 4.1.1 Materials for downpipes shall comply with Table 4.
paraphrase: If downpipes exist, then the materials of downpipes shall comply with E1/AS1 Table 4.

text: 3.0 Timber; The combined foundation and edge details shall be constructed as shown in Figures 7.13(B), 7.14(B) or (C).
paraphrase: If the consturction material is Timber, then the foundation and edge shall be constructed as shown in B1/AS1 Figures 7.13.b, 7.14.b or 7.14.c.

text: Figures 7.15(B) and 7.16(B) or (C) for foundations supporting a masonry veneer
paraphrase: If masonry veneer exists, then the foundations of masonry veneer shall be as shown in B1/AS1 Figures 7.15.b and 7.16.b or 7.16.c.

text: At free joints, slab reinforcement shall be terminated and there shall be no bonding between vertical concrete faces (prevented by using building paper or a bituminous coating).
paraphrase: If the slab has free joints and reinforcement, then the reinforcement shall be terminated  at the joint, and there shall be either building paper or a bituminous coating betwenn the faces.

text: Structure Design 4.0 Earth Buildings 4.1 NZS 4299
paraphrase: If the structure's material is earth, then the structure's design shall comply with NZS 4299

text: The earthquake zone factor > 0.6 shall apply to the Canterbury earthquake region.
paraphrase: The Canterbury earthquake region shall have a earthquake zone factor greater than 0.6.

text: for a single storey foundation, 15 Series masonry may be used and the minimum footing width may be 190 mm.
paraphrase: If the foundation is for a single storey, then the foundations material may be 15 Series masonry and the minimum footing width may be 190 mm.

text: Clause 7.5.8.1 All slab-on-ground floors shall be reinforced concrete in accordance with Clauses 7.5.8.3, 7.5.8.4 and 7.5.8.6.4. All reinforcing steel, including welded mesh, shall be Ductility Class E in accordance with NZS 4671.
paraphrase: If floors are slab-on-ground, then the floor shall have the material reinforced concrete in accordance with B1/AS1 Clauses 7.5.8.3, 7.5.8.4 and 7.5.8.6.4. The reinforcing steel and welded mesh of the reinforced concrete shall be Ductility Class E in accordance with NZS 4671.

text: Where Grade 500E welded steel mesh is specified, it shall meet the requirements of Paragraph 14.0 in B1/VM1.
paraphrase: If welded steel mesh is Grade 500E, then the welded steel mesh shall meet the requirements of Paragraph 14.0 in B1/VM1.

text: Structure Design; Interlinking rails are not required for a heat-strengthened or toughened laminated safety glass barrier that: has a top capping, corner brackets or a proprietary system and will, when both panes of the laminate are fractured, resist a 0.2 kN concentrated load and not deflect more than 250 mm (see note 2).
paraphrase: If the safety barrier is glass and the glass is laminated and heat-strengthened or toughened, and the safety barrier has a top capping, corner brackets or a proprietary protection system and both safety barrier panes of the laminate are fractured and the panes resists a 0.2 kN concentrated load and the panes deflection is less than or equal 250 mm, then the safety barrier may not have interlinking rails.

text: Structure Design; Interlinking rails are not required for a heat-strengthened or toughened laminated safety glass barrier that: has two or three edges supported by structural sealant joints or continuous clamps, and will, when both panes of the laminate are fractured, resist a 0.2 kN concentrated load and not deflect more than 250 mm (see note 2).
paraphrase: If the safety barrier is glass and the glass is laminated and heat-strengthened or toughened, and the safety barrier has two or three edges supported by sealant joints or continuous clamps and both safety barrier panes of the laminate are fractured and the panes resists a 0.2 kN concentrated load and the panes deflection is less than or equal 250 mm, then the safety barrier may not have interlinking rails.

text: Structure Design; Interlinking rails are not required for a heat-strengthened or toughened laminated safety glass barrier that: has a stiff interlayer and will, when both panes of the laminate are fractured, resist a 0.2 kN concentrated load and not deflect more than 250 mm (see note 2).
paraphrase: If the safety barrier is glass and the glass is laminated and heat-strengthened or toughened, and the safety barrier has a stiff interlayer and both safety barrier panes of the laminate are fractured and the panes resists a 0.2 kN concentrated load and the panes deflection is less than or equal 250 mm, then the safety barrier may not have interlinking rails.

text: Physical testing of glass barriers must include all components of the barrier system, including all structural connections. Loads and deflections must be applied and measured horizontally, at midspan, at the required barrier height. The concentrated load shall be applied over an area of 100 mm x 100 mm and for at least one minute.
paraphrase: If glass barriers have physical testing, then the physical testing must include all components and structural connections of the barrier system. Loads and deflections of the physical testing must be applied and measured horizontally, at midspan, at the required barrier height. The load shall be applied over an area of 100 mm x 100 mm and for at least one minute.

text: Structure Design; The design of structural connections, fasteners and mounting hardware, that are part of the glass barrier, is outside the scope of this Standard and must be specifically designed.
paraphrase: If structural connections, fasteners or mounting hardware are included in the glass barrier, then B1/AS1 does not apply to the structural connections, fasteners or mounting hardware and the structural connections, fasteners or mounting hardware shall have a specific design.

text: a) Masonry veneer b) Stucco c) Timber weatherboards d) Fibre cement weatherboards e) Profiled metal wall claddings f) Fibre cement sheet g) Plywood sheet h) EIFS. Other wall claddings are outside the scope of this Acceptable Solution.
paraphrase: If the wall cladding system is not masonry veneer, stucco, timber weatherboards, fibre cement weatherboards, profiled metal wall claddings, fibre cement sheet, plywood sheet, and EIFS, then E2/AS1 applies not to the wall cladding system.

text: Risk score 3.4.1.1 As all faces score low, cladding options from Table 3 are: a) Direct fixed claddings: i) Timber weatherboards – all types shown ii) Fibre cement weatherboards iii) Vertical profiled metal – corrugated and symmetrical trapezoidal only iv) Fibre cement sheet – not flush-finished v) Plywood sheet.
paraphrase: If the risk scores for all faces of the building are low, then the building cladding may be direct fixed and be of type Timber weatherboards, Fibre cement weatherboards, Vertical profiled metal, Fibre cement sheet, or Plywood sheet.

text: Cladding system 4.1 Materials for flashings; Acceptable materials for flashing junctions and penetrations are described in Paragraph 4.3.
paraphrase: If the flashing has junctions or penetrations, then the junction and penetration materials shall be as described in E2/AS1 Paragraph 4.3.

text: 4.2.2 Surrounding materials; Metals which are in contact in locations where they will become wet, or where water can flow over metals or certain plastics onto another metal, shall be selected in accordance with Table 21 and Table 22.
paraphrase: If the material is metals and has exposure to water, then the material shall be in accordance with E2/AS1 Table 21 and Table 22.

text: 4.3 Acceptable flashing materials; Tables 20, 21 and 22 shall be used to assess suitability of flashing materials for the required durability.
paraphrase: If flashing materials require durability, then the flashing material shall be as per E2/AS1 Tables 20, 21 and 22.

text: Where uPVC flashings are exposed to the weather, they shall also comply with Section 8 of AS/NZS 4256: Part 2.
paraphrase: If uPVC flashings are exposed to the weather, then the flashings shall comply with NZS 4256: Part 2 Section 8.

text: uPVC flashings shall have a finish colour with a reflectance of 40% or more, as outlined in Paragraph 2.4.
paraphrase: If the flashing material is uPVC, then the flashing shall have a finish colour with a reflectance of 40 percent or more and the finish colour reflectance shall be as outlined in E2/AS1 Paragraph 2.4.

text: 4.3.5 Stainless steel flashings; Stainless steel flashings shall be: a) Minimum thickness of 0.45 mm, and b) 304 or 316 stainless steel in accordance with Table 1 of ISO/TS 15510.
paraphrase: If flashing material is stainless steel, then the flashing shall be minimum thickness of 0.45 mm, and stainless steel grade 304 or 316 in accordance with ISO/TS 15510 Table 1.

text: 4.3.6 Copper flashings; Copper flashings shall be: a) A minimum thickness of 0.5 mm, b) In compliance with AS 1566, and c) Alloy, designation C11000 or C12200.
paraphrase: If flashings are copper, then the flashings shall be a minimum thickness of 0.5 mm and in compliance with AS 1566, and flashing type being Alloy C11000 or C12200.

text: Lead sheet flashings shall: a) Comply with AS 1804, and b) Have a minimum unit mass of 17 kg/m2.
paraphrase: If flashings are of material lead sheet, then the flashings shall comply with AS 1804, and the flashings shall have a minimum unit mass of 17 kg/m2.

text: Butyl rubber flashings shall only be used in accordance with Tables 20, 21 and 22.
paraphrase: If flashings are material butyl rubber, then the flashings shall be in accordance with E2/AS1 Tables 20, 21 and 22.

text: Butyl rubber and EPDM flashings shall be a minimum thickness of 1.0 mm, and shall comply with the following parts of Table 1 in ASTM D6134: a) Tensile strength, b) Elongation, c) Water absorption, d) Water vapour permeance, and e) Heat aging followed by: i) tensile strength ii) elongation.
paraphrase: If flashings are butyl rubber or EPDM, then the flashings shall be a minimum thickness of 1.0 mm, and the flashing's Tensile strength, Elongation, Water absorption, Water vapour permeance, Heat aging followed by tensile strength, and Heat aging followed by elongation shall comply with ASTM D6134 Table 1.

text: 4.3.10 Bituminous flashings; Bituminous flashings shall only be used in accordance with Table 20.
paraphrase: If flashing material is bituminous, then the flashing application shall be in accordance with E2/AS1 Table 20.

text: 4.3.10 Bituminous flashings; Flashings made from bitumen-impregnated material shall: a) Comply with AS/NZS 2904, and b) Be used only in fully concealed applications.
paraphrase: If flashings are made from bitumen-impregnated material, then the flashings shall comply with NZS 2904, and the flashings application shall be fully concealed.

text: 1.1.1 Accessible routes shall be provided to give direct access to the principal entrance to the building where practical.
paraphrase: If the entrance to the building is the principal entrance and the route to the building is direct, and the route's accessibility is practical, then the route shall be the accessible route.

text: If it is not practical, the alternative most direct practical route to the space served by the principal entrance shall be used.
paraphrase: If the entrance to the building is the principal entrance and the direct route to the entrance is not practical, then the alternative most direct practical route to the space served by the principal entrance shall be used.

text: 1.1.3 Where accessible units of Community service buildings are provided, an accessible route shall connect all accessible units to reception areas, offices, shops, dining rooms, kitchens, laundries, ablution blocks, recreation rooms and any other communal facilities.
paraphrase: If community service buildings have accessible units, then an accessible route shall be between units and communal facilities. Communal facilities shall include reception areas, offices, shops, dining rooms, kitchens, laundries, ablution blocks, recreation rooms.

text: 1.1.4 Figure 1 illustrates an acceptable solution with provision for people with disabilities to approach buildings.
paraphrase: If a building exists, then the building's accessibility route may comply with D1/AS1 Figure 1.

text: 1.1.5 Access routes which are part of an escape route shall also comply with NZBC C4.
paraphrase: If access routes are part of an escape route, then the access route shall comply with NZBC C4.

text: 1.2.1 Slope in direction of travel; Acceptable slopes for different types of access routes are shown in Figure 2.
paraphrase: If access routes exist, then the slope of access routes shall be as shown in D1/AS1 Figure 2.

text: 1.3.1 Except in household units (risk group SH1) or where permitted by Paragraph 1.3.2, a single isolated step shall not be permitted.
paraphrase: If a building is not classified as housing and not has risk group SH1 or a single isolated step for the building is permitted by D1/AS1 1.3.2, then it shall not be permitted that the building has a single isolated step.

text: Access Route; Single Isolated Step 1.3.2 Threshold weather stops projecting no more than 20 mm above the threshold finished surface are acceptable.
paraphrase: If an access route has a single isolated step as threshold weather stop projecting no more than 20 mm above the threshold finished surface, then the access route may have a single isolated step.

text: 1.4.1 Access routes shall have height clearances complying with Table 1 and as shown in Figure 3.
paraphrase: If access routes exist, then the access routes shall have height clearances complying with D1/AS1 Table 1 and as shown in D1/AS1 Figure 3.

text: Attached garages that are integral with the weathertightness envelope of the building are included within the scope of this Acceptable Solution.
paraphrase: If the building envelope is for weathertightness and the garage is part of the envelope, then E2AS1 applies to the garage.

text: Outbuildings, such as stand-alone garages and other structures that are unlined, are outside the scope of this Acceptable Solution.
paraphrase: If a building is a outbuilding and unlined, then E2AS1 does not apply to the building.

text: Cladding systems shall meet the requirements of NZBC E2.2 to E2.3.7.
paraphrase: If cladding systems exist, then the cladding systems shall meet the requirements of NZBC E2 2 to NZBC E2.3.7.

text: 3.3 Wall claddings; The following wall cladding systems are covered in this Acceptable Solution: a) Masonry veneer Paragraph 9.2 b) Stucco Paragraph 9.3 c) Timber weatherboards Paragraph 9.4 d) Fibre cement weatherboards Paragraph 9.5 e) Profiled metal wall claddings Paragraph 9.6 f) Fibre cement sheet Paragraph 9.7 g) Plywood sheet Paragraph 9.8 h) EIFS Paragraph 9.9.
paraphrase: If the wall cladding system is masonry veneer, stucco, timber weatherboards, fibre cement weatherboards, profiled metal wall claddings, fibre cement sheet, plywood sheet, or EIFS, then E2/AS1 applies to the wall cladding system.

text: Structure Design 5.0 Stucco 5.1 NZS 4251.
paraphrase: If the structure's material is stucco, then the structure's design shall comply with NZS 4299.

text: Structure Design 6.0 Drains 6.1 AS/NZS 2566.1 6.2 AS/NZS 2566.2 6.3 AS/NZS 2032 6.4 AS/NZS 2033.
paraphrase: If the structure is for drains, then the structure's design shall comply with NZS 2566.1 6.2, NZS 2566.2 6.3, NZS 2032 6.4, and NZS 2033.

text: NZS 4223.3 Glass design for these types shall comply with the following tables (see note 1): Table 14 - Structural balustrade – cantilevered glass;.
paraphrase: If the design of a structural balustrade is cantilevered glass, then the balustrade's design shall comply with NZS 4223 3 Table 14.

text: NZS 4223.3 Glass design for these types shall comply with the following tables (see note 1): Table 15 - Structural balustrade – two-edge point fixed;.
paraphrase: If the design of a structural balustrade is two-edge point fixed, then the balustrade' design shall comply with NZS 4223.3 Table 15.

text: NZS 4223.3 Glass design for these types shall comply with the following tables (see note 1): Table 16 - Structural balustrade – two-edge support;.
paraphrase: If the design of a structural balustrade is two-edge support, then the balustrade's design shall comply with NZS 4223.3 Table 16.

text: NZS 4223.3 Glass design for these types shall comply with the following tables (see note 1): Table 17 - Structural balustrade – three-edge support.
paraphrase: If the design of a structural balustrade is three-edge support, then the balustrade's design shall comply with NZS 4223.3 Table 17.

text: Structure Design 7.0 Glazing; Table 14 - Structural balustrade – cantilevered glass; Table 15 - Structural balustrade – two-edge point fixed; Table 16 - Structural balustrade – two-edge support; Table 17 - Structural balustrade – three-edge support. Design types and glass types not shown in Tables 14 to 17 require specific design.
paraphrase: If the design of a structural balustrade is not cantilevered glass, two-edge point fixed, two-edge support, and three-edge support, then the balustrade requires specific design.

text: Structure Design 7.0 Glazing; All structural glass barriers safeguarding a fall of 1000 mm or more shall have interlinking rails.
paraphrase: If a structure is made of glass and is a safety barrier against a fall of 1000 mm or more, then the structure shall have interlinking rails.

text: Rails, which in the event a glass pane breaks, spans the broken pane at the required barrier height and, i) resists Line and Concentrated design loads (SLS) specified in Tables 14 to 17, and ii) does not deflect more than 100 mm, in any direction, under the design loads.
paraphrase: If the rails are around a glass pane and the glass pane is broken, then the rail spans the broken pane at the barrier height and, the rails shall resist line design loads and concentrated design loads specified in B1/AS1 Tables 14 to 17, and the rails do not deflect more than 100 mm, towards any direction, by the design loads.

text: Metal cappings installed over parapets and enclosed balustrades. j) Where necessary, expansion joints shall be formed as shown in Figure 9 (g), and with: i) minimum 200 mm laps ii) sliding clips at both sides of the lap.
paraphrase: If metal cappings installed over parapets and enclosed balustrades, then the capping shall have expansion joints as shown in E2/AS1 Figure 9.g, and the expansion joint shall have minimum 200 mm sized laps and each side of the lap shall have sliding clips.

text: 6.5 Membrane cappings; Butyl rubber and EPDM cappings shall be in accordance with Paragraph 4.3.9, and comply with the following requirements: a) Tops of membrane cappings shall be free of any penetrations, and shall have a minimum slope of 10° (1:6).
paraphrase: If the capping material is butyl rubber or EPDM, then the capping shall be in accordance with E2/AS1 Paragraph 4.3.9, and the top of the capping shall be free of any penetrations, and shall have a minimum slope of 10 deg.

text: Butyl rubber and EPDM cappings shall comply with the following requirements: Joints shall be in accordance with Paragraph 8.5.5.2.
paraphrase: If cappings are material butyl rubber and EPDM, then the joints shall be in accordance with E2/AS1 Paragraph 8.5.5.2.

text: 7.1.1 Slatted decks; The level of the upper surface of the slatted deck: May be at the same level as the threshold for non-cantilevered decks that are formed as shown in Figure 14(c).
paraphrase: If the deck is slatted and not cantilevered and as shown in E2/AS1 Figure 14.c, then the deck's upper surface level may be equal to the deck's threshold level.

text: 7.1.2 Enclosed decks; This Acceptable Solution is limited to enclosed decks with a maximum area of 40 m2. For enclosed decks, the vertical separation between the opening threshold level and the upper surface of the finished deck surface shall be a minimum of 100 mm.
paraphrase: If enclosed decks have a maximum area of 40 m2, then E2/AS1 applies to the deck. The deck surface shall be finished and a separation between the threshold level and the deck's upper surface level shall be a minimum of 100 mm.

text: 7.2.1 Slatted timber decks to walls; Junctions of slatted timber decks with walls shall be made weathertight as shown in Figures 15 and 16.
