paraphrase: If the deck is slatted and deck material is timber and a junction is between the deck and wall, then the junction shall be made weathertight as shown in E2/AS1 Figures 15 and 16.

text: 8.2.1.1 Tile profiles; a) Type I: Double profile tiles having two distinct watercourses with a minimum watercourse depth of 18 mm.
paraphrase: If the tile type is double profile, then the tiles having two distinct watercourses with a minimum watercourse depth of 18 mm.

text: 8.2.1.1 Tile profiles; Type II: Single profile tiles having one water- course depth of a minimum of 25 mm.
paraphrase: If the tile type is single profile, then the tiles having one water- course depth of a minimum of 25 mm.

text: 8.2.1.1 Tile profiles; c) Type III: Tiles not fitting the Type I (Double profile) or Type II (Single profile) categories, and includes flat tiles and those resembling slates, shakes and shingles.
paraphrase: If the tile type is Type III, then Tiles types that are not Double profile or Single profile categories, and includes flat tiles and those similar to slates, shakes and shingles.

text: 8.2.3 Installation; Masonry tile roof cladding shall be installed in accordance with NZS 4206 or AS 2050 onto minimum H1.2 treated timber battens, except the minimum pitch shall be as specified in Table 10.
paraphrase: If roof cladding is masonry tile, then the roof cladding shall be installed in accordance with NZS 4206 or AS 2050 onto minimum H1.2 treated timber battens and the roof cladding pitch shall be as specified in E2/AS1 Table 10.

text: Roof cladding; Where required in AS 2050 and Table 20, underlay shall comply with Table 23.
paraphrase: If the roof cladding requires and underlay in AS 2050 and E2/AS1 Table 20, then the underlay shall comply with E2/AS1 Table 23.

text: 8.0 Roof claddings 8.2.3 Installation; Fixing and fixing patterns shall be to NZS 4206, with the exception that nails shall penetrate a minimum of 35 mm into timber battens, and the minimum pitches and roof underlay shall be as described in Table 10 and Table 23.
paraphrase: If roof claddings have fixings or fixing patterns, then the fixing and fixing patterns shall be to NZS 4206, with the exception that fixing include nails and nails shall penetrate a minimum of 35 mm into timber battens, and the roof cladding pitches and roof cladding underlay shall be as described in E2/AS1 Table 10 and Table 23.

text: Use 304 or 316 stainless steel fixings for corrosion zones B, C or hot dip galvanised fixings at 450 g/m2 for Zone B and Zone C.
paraphrase: If the corrosion zones for the fixing is B or C, then either the fixing material shall be 304 or 316 stainless steel or the fixing material shall be hot dip galvanised fixings at 450 g/m2.

text: Use 304 or 316 stainless steel fixings for corrosion zones D and E.
paraphrase: If the corrosion zones for the fixing is B or C, then fixing material shall be 304 or 316 stainless steel.

text: 8.2.3 Installation; Where masonry tiles have been shown to comply with the dynamic weathertightness test requirements of AS 4046: Part 9, a lower pitch (as in Table 10) may be used providing it is not less than 15°.
paraphrase: If the cladding type is masonry tiles and the cladding complies with the dynamic weathertightness test requirements of AS 4046 Part 9, then the cladding pitch may not be as in E2/AS1 Table 10 providing the cladding pitch is not less than 15 deg.

text: 8.1.1 Weathertightness; Roof claddings shall meet the requirements of NZBC E2.2, and be specified and constructed in accordance with the provisions of Paragraph 8.1.2 to Paragraph 8.5.
paraphrase: If roof claddings exist, then the roof cladding shall meet the requirements of NZBC E2 2, and be specified and constructed in accordance with E2/AS1 Paragraph 8.1.2 to Paragraph 8.5.

text: 8.1.2 Limitations; The following roof cladding systems are covered in this Acceptable Solution: a) Masonry tiles Paragraph 8.2 b) Pressed metal tiles Paragraph 8.3 c) Profiled metal roof claddings Paragraph 8.4 d) Membrane roofing Paragraph 8.5.
paraphrase: If the roof cladding is Masonry tiles, Pressed metal tiles, Profiled metal roof claddings, or Membrane roofing, then E2/AS1 applies to the roof cladding

text: a) Masonry tiles Paragraph 8.2 b) Pressed metal tiles Paragraph 8.3 c) Profiled metal roof claddings Paragraph 8.4 d) Membrane roofing Paragraph 8.5. Other roof claddings are beyond the scope of this Acceptable Solution.
paraphrase: If the roof cladding is not Masonry tiles, Pressed metal tiles, Profiled metal roof claddings, and Membrane roofing, then E2/AS1 applies to the roof cladding

text: Projecting eaves; Soffits and verges of all projecting eaves shall be closed in.
paraphrase: If eaves are type projecting and has soffits and verges, then the soffits and verges shall be closed in.

text: 8.0 Roof Claddings 8.1.4 Fixings; Fixings shall be as specified in Paragraph 8.2 to Paragraph 8.5. Materials for fixing roof claddings and flashings, where necessary, shall be selected from Tables 20, 21 and 22 to minimise corrosion.
paraphrase: If roof claddings or flashings have fixings, then the fixings shall be as specified in E2/AS1 Paragraph 8.2 to Paragraph 8.5. The fixing materials shall be selected from Tables 20, 21 and 22.

text: 8.1.5 Roof underlays; Roof underlays shall be to Table 23 and NZS 2295, and be either: R1 heavy weight kraft, or R2 self supporting kraft.
paraphrase: If the roof has underlays, then the underlay shall comply with E2/AS1 Table 23 and NZS 2295, and the underlay type shall be R1 heavy weight kraft or R2 self supporting kraft.

text: 8.1.5 Roof underlays; Underlays shall be: • Layed with minimum numbers of laps • Lapped at all side and end laps by minimum 150 mm • Run horizontally for roof pitches below 10° • Run horizontally or vertically for roof pitches above 10° • Have anti-ponding boards at lower edges of masonry tiles, refer Figure 25(b) and Paragraph 8.2.5.
paraphrase: If the roof has underlays, then the underlay shall have a minimum cound of laps. The underlay shall have laps and the side laps and end laps shall be minimum 150 mm size. The underlay shall be either horizontally and roof pitches below 10 deg or the underlay shall be horizontally or vertically for roof pitches above 10 deg. The underlay shall have anti-ponding boards at lower edges of masonry tiles.

text: 8.1.6 Gutters general; Gutters, downpipes and spreaders, including eaves gutters/spoutings are required for the drainage of roof water.
paraphrase: If a roof exists, then the roof drainage shall have gutters, downpipes and spreaders, and the roof drainage shall have eave gutters or eave spoutings.

text: 8.1.6 Gutters general; Gutters, downpipes and spreaders required for the drainage of roof water shall: a) Be to the minimum dimensions shown in this Acceptable Solution, or calculated to E1/AS1, whichever is the greater.
paraphrase: If the roof drainage requires gutters, downpipes and spreaders, then the gutters, downpipes and spreaders shall comply with the dimensions in E2/AS1 and E1/AS1.

text: 8.1.6.1 Internal gutters; Internal gutters shall: a) Be formed with continuous butyl or EPDM strip complying with Paragraph 4.3.9, with no cross-joints in the gutter, or aluminium, copper, stainless steel, or zinc sheet to Paragraph 4.3, with joints that are welded.
paraphrase: If gutters are internal, then either the gutter material shall be butyl or EPDM and comply with E2/AS1 Paragraph 4.3.9, with no cross-joints in the gutter, or the gutter material shall be aluminium, copper, stainless steel, or zinc to E2/AS1 Paragraph 4.3, with gutter joints that are welded.

text: 8.1.6.1 Internal gutters; Internal gutters shall: b) Where butyl or EPDM, be minimum 1.5 mm membrane thickness, or 1.0 mm thickness for gutters less than 1 metre wide.
paraphrase: If gutters are internal and gutter material is butyl or EPDM, then either the gutter shall be minimum 1.5 mm thickness and not less than 1 metre wide, or the gutter shall be 1 mm thickness and gutters less than 1 metre wide.

text: 8.1.6.1 Internal gutters; Internal gutters shall: c) Have a minimum slope of 1:100.
paraphrase: If gutters are internal, then the gutter shall have a minimum slope of 1:100.

text: 8.1.6.1 Internal gutters; Internal gutters shall: For roofs other than membrane roofs: e) Discharge into a rainwater head as shown in Figure 63 (a) and (b).
paraphrase: If gutters are internal and roof type is not membrane roofs, then the gutter shall discharge into a rainwater head, and the gutter discharge shall be as shown in E2/AS1 Figure 63.a and Figure 63.b.

text: In addition: f) Have minimum slopes of 8° for hidden gutters g) Hidden gutters receive no discharge from downpipes or spreaders.
paraphrase: If the gutter type is hidden, then the gutter shall have minimum slopes of 8 deg and the gutter shall not receive discharge from downpipes or spreaders.

text: 8.1.7 Roof penetrations; Roof penetrations shall be made weathertight in accordance with Paragraph 8.2 to Paragraph 8.5.
paraphrase: If the roof has penetrations, then the penetration shall be made weathertight in accordance with E2/AS1 Paragraph 8.2 to Paragraph 8.5.

text: Where roof penetrations are required for large openings such as roof lights and chimneys, this Acceptable Solution is limited to the following requirements: Rules 8.1.7.0.2.a.1 and 8.1.7.0.2.b.1.
paraphrase: If roof penetrations are for large openings such as roof lights and chimneys, then E2/AS1 Rules 8.1.7.0.2.a.1 and 8.1.7.0.2.b.1 apply to the penetration.

text: For the catchment area of the roof above the penetration as shown in Figure 22, the roof length shall be limited to: i) for profiled metal roofing, Table 17 ii) for other roof claddings, the areas shown in Table 9.
paraphrase: If the roof has a penetration and the catchment area of the roof is above the penetration and the catchment area is as shown in E2/AS1 Figure 22, then the roof length shall be limited to E2/AS1 Table 17 and roof type is profiled metal, or roof type is not profiled metal and the roof length is as shown in E2/AS1 Table 9.

text: 8.2.1 Materials; Concrete tiles shall meet the requirements of NZS 4206 or AS 2049.
paraphrase: If the tile material is concrete, then the tile shall meet the requirements of NZS 4206 or AS 2049.

text: 8.2.1 Materials; Clay tiles shall meet the requirements of AS 2049.
paraphrase: If the tile material is clay, then the tile shall meet the requirements of AS 2049.

text: 4.4 Fixings; Fixings of metal flashings shall comply with Tables 20, 21 and 22.
paraphrase: If flashings have fixings and the flashing material is metal, then the fixing shall comply with E2/AS1 Tables 20, 21 and 22.

text: 4.5.1 Edge treatments for flashings; Flashings shall be to the dimensions shown throughout this Acceptable Solution.
paraphrase: If flashings exist, then the flashings shall be to the dimensions shown throughout E2/AS1.

text: Joins of metal flashings shall have the following features: Where both ends of a flashing are constrained, allowance shall be made for expansion.
paraphrase: If flashings are material metal and have joins and each end of a flashing is constrained, then the join shall have expansion allowance.

text: Where necessary, expansion joints shall be formed as shown in Figure 6, with: i) minimum 200 mm laps, and ii) sliding clips at both sides of the lap.
paraphrase: If an expansion joint exist, then the expansion joint shall be as shown in E2/AS1 Figure 6, has laps, and the laps are minimum 200 mm wide and the sides of the lap have sliding clips.

text: When using uncoated galvanized steel, zinc, stainless steel or copper flashings, joints shall be riveted or soldered as described in the New Zealand Metal Roof and Wall Cladding Code of Practice.
paraphrase: If the flashing material is uncoated galvanized steel, zinc, stainless steel or copper and the flashing has an expansion joint, then the expansion joint shall be joined using rivets or solder as described in the New Zealand Metal Roof and Wall Cladding Code of Practice.

text: Where a notched turn-down is used there shall be a gap between the edge of the flashing and the pan of the roof cladding. The gap shall be a maximum of 5 mm.
paraphrase: If the flashing has a notched turn-down, then there shall be a gap between the edge of the flashing and the pan of the cladding. The gap shall be a maximum of 5 mm.

text: 6.1 Limitations; This Acceptable Solution does not cover parapet cappings that use stucco, EIFS and flush-finished fibre cement materials.
paraphrase: If the parapet cappings use stucco, EIFS and flush-finished fibre cement materials, then E2/AS1 does not apply to the capping.

text: 8.3 Pressed Metal Tiles; The roof shall be flashed at all boundaries, except at the discharge to a gutter, using the details shown in Figure 34 to Figure 37.
paraphrase: If the roof type is pressed metal tile, then the roof boundaries shall have flashings. The roof discharge to a gutter shall not have flashings. The flashings shall be as shown in E2/AS1 Figure 34 to Figure 37.

text: 8.0 Roof Claddings 8.3 Pressed Metal Tiles 8.3.10 Roof penetrations; Pipe penetrations shall be flashed using EPDM flashings similar to that shown for masonry tiles, Figure 29.
paraphrase: If the roof cladding type is pressed metal tiles and the roof cladding has pipe penetrations, then the penetrations shall be flashed using EPDM flashings similar to masonry tile flashing in E2/AS1 Figure 29.

text: 8.4 Profiled Metal Roof Cladding 8.4.3.3 Aluminium; Aluminium for the manufacture of profiled aluminium roofing shall comply with AS/NZS 1734, and be a minimum: a) Base metal thickness (BMT) of 0.7 mm, b) 5000 series.
paraphrase: If the material of profiled metal roof claddings is aluminium, then the aluminium shall comply with NZS 1734, and be a minimum base metal thickness of 0.7 mm, and minimum 5000 series.

text: 8.4 Profiled Metal Roof Cladding; Pre-painted aluminium roofing shall have a factory-applied finish complying with AS/NZS 2728.
paraphrase: If the material of profiled metal roof claddings is pre-painted aluminium, then the roof cladding shall have a factory-applied finish complying with NZS 2728.

text: 8.4 Profiled Metal Roof Cladding 8.4.4 Profiles; Profiles covered in this Acceptable Solution are shown in Figure 38, and consist of: a) Corrugated – curved with a crest height of 16.5 mm minimum, b) Trapezoidal – symmetrical or asymmetrical with a minimum crest height of 19 mm, and for asymmetrical a flat or lightly profiled pan width of 210 mm maximum between crests, and c) Trough profile – with vertical ribs at a minimum height of 38 mm, and flat or lightly profiled pans of 210 mm maximum between crests.
paraphrase: If Profiled Metal Roof Cladding have profiles as shown in  E2/AS1 Figure 38, and either the roof cladding profile is either corrugated and curved with a crest height of 16.5 mm minimum, or the roof cladding profile is trapezoidal and symmetrical with a minimum crest height of 19 mm or the roof cladding profile is trapezoidal and asymmetrical with a minimum crest height of 19 mm and have a flat or lightly profiled pan width of 210 mm maximum between crests, or the roof cladding profile is trough with vertically oriented ribs at a minimum height of 38 mm, and flat or lightly profiled pans of 210 mm maximum between crests, then E2/AS1 applies to the roof cladding.

text: 8.4 Profiled Metal Roof Cladding 8.4.5 Roof pitch; For roofs up to 18 metres in length without end laps, pitches shall be: a) Corrugated – not less than 8° (1:7). b) Trapezoidal – not less than: i) 4° (1:14) where the crest height is less than 27 mm, or ii) 3° (1:20) where the crest height is 27 mm or higher. c) Trough profile – not less than 3° (1:20).
paraphrase: If roofs are up to 18 metres in length and the roof length does not include end laps, then either roof claddings shall be corrugated and roof pitches shall be not less than 8 deg, or roof cladding profile shall be trapezoidal and roof pitches shall be not less than 4 deg and the roof cladding's crest height is less than 27 mm, or roof cladding profile shall be trapezoidal and roof pitches shall be not less than 3 deg and the roof cladding's crest height is 27 mm or higher, or roof cladding profile shall be trough and roof pitches shall be not less than 3 deg.

text: Steel; The maximum span and fixing patterns of profiled metal roof cladding between purlins to comply with this Acceptable Solution are given in Table 11, Table 12 or Table 13, 14 and 15.
paraphrase: If profiled metal roof cladding are from steel, then the maximum span between purlins and the fixing patterns between purlins are given in E2/AS1 Table 11, 12, 13, 14 and 15.

text: Hidden, valley and internal gutters shall be in accordance with Paragraph 8.1.6.
paraphrase: If gutters are type hidden, valley or internal, then the guttters shall be in accordance with E2/AS1 Paragraph 8.1.6.

text: Parallel hidden gutters shall be as shown in Figure 50 and Paragraph 8.1.6.2.
paraphrase: If hidden gutters are parallel, then the gutter shall be as shown in E2/AS1 Figure 50 and Paragraph 8.1.6.2.

text: Internal gutters shall be as shown in Figure 52 and Paragraph 8.1.6.1.
paraphrase: If gutters are internal gutters, then the gutter shall be as shown in E2/AS1 Figure 52 and Paragraph 8.1.6.1.

text: 8.4 Profiled Metal Roof Cladding 8.4.17 Roof penetrations; The maximum length of profiled roof cladding above penetrations shall be as shown in Table 17.
paraphrase: If the roof cladding is profiled metal roof and the roof cladding has a penetration, then the maximum length of the roof cladding above the penetration shall be as shown in E2/AS1 Table 17.

text: 8.4 Profiled Metal Roof Cladding 8.4.17 Roof penetrations; Roof penetrations shall be flashed as follows: a) Pipe penetrations up to 85 mm shall be flashed using an EPDM boot flashing as shown in Figure 53, b) Pipe penetrations up to 500 mm shall be flashed using a soaker flashing and EPDM boot flashing as shown in Figure 54, c) Rectangular penetrations up to 1200 mm wide shall be flashed using a soaker type flashing as shown in Figure 55.
paraphrase: If Profiled Metal Roof Cladding have penetrations, then the penetrations shall be either for pipes and the penetrations shall be up to 85 mm wide shall and have an EPDM boot flashing as shown in E2/AS1 Figure 53, or the penetrations shall be for pipes and the penetration is up to 500 mm wide shall have a soaker flashing and EPDM boot flashing as shown in E2/AS1 Figure 54, or the enetrations shall be rectangular and up to 1200 mm wide and have a soaker type flashing as shown in E2/AS1 Figure 55.

text: Membranes composed of butyl or EPDM installed over plywood substrates 8.5.5 Installation 8.5.5.1 Plywood Substrates must be dry when membranes are applied. The plywood and timber substructure must be a maximum moisture content of 20% when a membrane is adhered.
paraphrase: If membranes are of butyl or epdm and installed over substrate of plywood, then the plywood and timber substructure must be a maximum moisture content of 20 percent before the membrane is installed.

text: Membrane roofs shall be constructed to provide: a) Falls as shown in Figure 56 and details in Figures 57–64.
paraphrase: If roofs are membrane roofs, then the roof fall shall be as shown in E2/AS1 Figure 56 and roofs as in E2/AS1 Figures 57 to Figure 64.

text: 8.5.9 Penetrations; Penetrations through membrane roofs and decks shall be as shown in Figure 59 and Figure 60.
paraphrase: If the membrane is for roofs or decks and the membrane has a penetration, then the penetration shall be as shown in E2/AS1 Figure 59 and Figure 60.

text: Handrails; Fixing of posts for handrails into membrane roofs or decks is not covered by this Acceptable Solution.
paraphrase: If the membrane is for roofs and decks, and the fixing of a post goes into the membrane, and the fixing is for a handrail, then E2/AS1 does not apply to the fixing.

text: 9.1 General; Wall claddings shall meet the requirements of NZBC E2.3.2 to E2.3.7, and comply with the provisions of Paragraph 9.1.1 to Paragraph 9.9.
paraphrase: If wall claddings exist, then the wall cladding shall comply with NZBC E2 3.2 to E2 3.7, and E2/AS1 Paragraph 9.1.1 to Paragraph 9.9.

text: 9.0 Wall Claddings; Claddings in Extra High wind zones require: a) Rigid underlays to Paragraph 9.1.7.2 b) Drained cavities to Paragraph 9.1.8 c) Hooks and hems on flashing upstands.
paraphrase: If wall claddings are in Extra High wind zones, then the wall claddings shall have rigid underlays to E2/AS1 Paragraph 9.1.7.2 and the wall claddings shall have drained cavities to E2/AS1 Paragraph 9.1.8 and the wall cladding flashing upstands shall have hooks and hems.

text: 8.4 Profiled Metal Roof Cladding 8.4.7 Underlay; All profiled metal long-run roofing shall have a roof underlay installed to Table 23. See Paragraph 8.1.5 for installation details.
paraphrase: If Profiled Metal Roof Cladding is long-run, then the roof shall have a underlay complying with E2/AS1 Table 23 and the underlay installation shall be as seen in E2/AS1 Paragraph 8.1.5.

text: 8.4 Profiled Metal Roof Cladding 8.4.8 Fixings: corrugated and trapezoidal; Fixings shall be as shown in Tables 11, 12, 14 and 15, and shall be a minimum 12-gauge screw, as shown in Figure 39, which complies with Class 4 of AS 3566: Part 2.
paraphrase:
If the profile of Profiled Metal Roof Cladding is corrugated or trapezoidal, and the roof cladding has a fixing, then the fixing shall be as shown in E2/AS1 Tables 11, 12, 14 and 15, and the fixing shall be a minimum 12-gauge sized screw, as shown in 
E2/AS1 Figure 39, which complies with Class 4 of AS 3566: Part 2.

text: 8.4 Profiled Metal Roof Cladding; Fixings shall: Include sealing washers of: ii) profiled washer and EPDM washer where required to allow for expansion of the profiled metal roof cladding.
paraphrase: If the profile of Profiled Metal Roof Cladding has a fixing and the roof cladding requires expansion allowance, then the fixings shall shall include sealing washers of profiled washer and EPDM washer.

text: 8.4.10 Allowance for expansion; Allowance shall be made for expansion of corrugated and trapezoidal roof cladding as shown in Table 16.
paraphrase: If roof cladding is corrugated or trapezoidal, then the roof cladding shall have allowance for expansion as shown in E2/AS1 Table 16.

text: 8.4.11.1 Fixing flashings a) When fixing flashings to the structure, use screws as for roofing (see Paragraph 8.4.8).
paraphrase: If fixing flashings to the roof, then the fixing type shall be screws as for roofing.

text: 8.4.11.1 Fixing flashings b) When fixing flashings to other flashings or to roofing use: i) for galvanized steel, 4 mm diameter monel metal or stainless steel rivets, where compatible as per Table 21, ii) for aluminium-zinc coated steel, 4 mm diameter aluminium rivets, iii) for aluminium, 4 mm diameter aluminium rivets.
paraphrase: If fixing flashings to other flashings or to the roof, then either the flashing and roof shall be galvanized steel and the fixing 4 mm diameter monel metal or stainless steel rivets as per E2/AS1 Table 21, or the flashing and roof shall be aluminium-zinc coated steel or aluminium, and the fixings shall be 4 mm diameter aluminium rivets.

text: 8.4 Profiled Metal Roof Cladding 8.4.11.1 Fixing flashings c) Flashing joins, including expansion joints where required, shall be in accordance with Paragraph 4.5.2 and as shown in Figure 6.
paraphrase: If flashing have joins or require expansion joints, then the joins and expansion joints shall be in accordance with E2/AS1 Paragraph 4.5.2 and as shown in Figure 6.

text: 8.4.13 Stopends; The top ends of profiled metal roof cladding shall have stopends as shown in Figure 49 for trapezoidal and trough profile metal roof cladding, where: a) The roof pitch is less than 25°, or b) The building is in a High/Very High/Extra High wind zone.
paraphrase: If the roof cladding is profiled metal and the roof cladding have trapezoidal and trough profile and either the roof pitch is less than 25 deg, or the building is in a High, Very High, or Extra High wind zone, then the roof claddings top ends shall have stopends as shown in E2/AS1 Figure 49.

text: 8.4 Profiled Metal Roof Cladding; 8.4.14 Turn-downs at gutters; The lower ends of trapezoidal and trough profile roofing shall be turned down at gutters, where the roof pitch is less than 10°. The turn-down shall be 30° from the plane of the sheet.
paraphrase: If profiled metal roof cladding have trapezoidal or trough profile and the roof pitch is less than 10 deg, then the lower ends of the roof cladding shall be turned down at gutters. The turn-down angle between turn-down and roof cladding shall be 30 deg.

text: Masonry tile roofs with underlays shall have anti-ponding boards installed to Figure 25. Where anti-ponding boards are used, these shall be set to a minimum fall of 5° (1:12), and shall be treated minimum H1.2 for solid timber and H3 for plywood.
paraphrase: If the roof type is masonry tile and the roof has an underlay, then the roof shall have anti-ponding boards installed to E2/AS1 Figure 25 and the anti-ponding boards shall have a minimum fall of 5 deg, and either the anti-ponding boards shall be treated minimum H1.2 and material solid timber or the anti-ponding boards shall be treated minimum H3 and be material plywood.

text: 8.2 Masonry Tiles 8.2.7 Penetrations; Holes in tiles for pipe penetrations shall be machine-cut to minimise the size of the hole.
paraphrase: If masonry tiles have penetrations for pipes, then the penetrations shall be machine-cut.

text: This Acceptable Solution is limited to pressed metal tile roofs.
paraphrase: If the roof type is pressed metal tile, then E2/AS1 is applicable to the roof.

text: 8.0 Roof Claddings 8.3 Pressed Metal Tiles 8.3.3 Tiles and accessories; Tiles and their accessories shall meet the requirements of NZS 4217.
paraphrase: If the roof cladding type is pressed metal tile, then the pressed metal tile and their accessories shall comply with NZS 4217.

text: 8.3 Pressed Metal Tiles 8.3.4.2 Steel; Paint coatings may include factory-applied finishes complying with AS/NZS 2728.
paraphrase: If the pressed metal tile's material is steel and the stell has paint coatings, then the paint coatings may include factory-applied finishes complying with NZS 2728.

text: 8.0 Roof Claddings 8.3 Pressed Metal Tiles 8.3.4.3 Aluminium; Aluminium for the manufacture of pressed metal tiles and flashing systems shall comply with AS/NZS 1734, and shall: a) Have a base metal thickness (BMT) of 0.7 mm minimum, b) Be minimum 5000 series, c) For pre-painted aluminium, have a factory-applied finish complying with AS/NZS 2728.
paraphrase: If the material of pressed metal tiles and flashings is aluminium, then the aluminium shall comply with NZS 1734 and the aluminium shall have a base metal thickness of at least 0.7 mm, the aluminium shall be a minimum of 5000 series, and the alumenium shall either be pre-painted and have a factory-applied finish complying with NZS 2728 or the aluminium shall not be pre-painted.

text: 8.0 Roof Claddings 8.3 Pressed Metal Tiles; The minimum roof pitches for metal tiles where rafter length exceeds 12 m, increase minimum pitch (Rule 8.3.5.0.2) by 1° per additional 0.5 m.
paraphrase: If the roof has pressed metal tiles and a rafter, and the rafter length exceeds 12 m, then the roof pitch shall be the value from E2/AS1 Rule 8.3.5.0.2 plus 1 deg per additional 0.5 m rafter length.

text: 8.3 Pressed Metal Tiles; All metal tile roofing shall have a roof underlay installed. Roof underlay shall be to Table 23. Refer to Paragraph 8.1.5 for installation details.
paraphrase: If the roof type is pressed metal tile, then the roof shall have a underlay, and the underlay shall be as E2/AS1 Table 23, and the underlay installation as E2/AS1 Paragraph 8.1.5.

text: Pressed metal tiles; For fixings through the top of the tiles, use neoprene washers containing no more than 15% by weight carbon black content.
paraphrase: If the top of the pressed metal tile has a fixing, then the fixing shall be neoprene washers, and the neoprene washer's carbon black content shall be no more than 15 percent.

text: 9.1.3.4 Garages and openings to garages; Garage spaces within, or attached to, the building envelope shall have: a) Openings provided with a 50 mm minimum total level change between the interior and the exterior paving, b) Provision to drain water away from the threshold of the opening c) Rigid wall underlays, to Table 23, where external garage walls are unlined d) linings to garage walls adjoining habitable spaces e) weather resisting garage doors f) window and door details (where included) to Paragraphs 9.2 to 9.9.
paraphrase: If the garage is within or attached to the building envelope, then the garage shall have openings with an interior paving elevation 50 mm minimum greater than the exterior paving elevation, and the garage shall have drainage away from the opening, and the garage shall either have external garage walls and the walls have rigid wall underlays, to E2/AS1 Table 23, and the garage walls have no linings, or the external garage walls shall have linings, and garage walls adjoining habitable spaces shall have linings, and garage doors shall be weather resistant, and garage window and door shall be to E2/AS1 Paragraphs 9.2 to 9.9.

text: 9.1.3.5 Bottom of wall claddings for timber floor framing; Suspended timber floors shall meet the requirements of NZS 3604. Clearances from paved and unpaved surfaces to the wall framing shall be in accordance with NZS 3604, and Table 18.
paraphrase: If wall claddings are next to suspended timber floors, then the floor shall meet the requirements of NZS 3604. The wall cladding clearances towards paved and unpaved surfaces shall be in accordance with NZS 3604, and E2/AS1 Table 18.

text: 9.0 Wall claddings; 9.2.2 General 1) The materials and workmanship of masonry veneer shall be in accordance with SNZ HB 4236 and have a maximum mass of veneer of 220 kg/m2 and minimum veneer thickness of 70 mm.
paraphrase: If wall claddings are masonry veneer, then the materials and workmanship of masonry veneer shall be in accordance with SNZ HB 4236 and the masonry veneer shall have a maximum mass of 220 kg/m2 and minimum thickness of 70 mm.

text: 3.4.1 Storage tanks in solar water heaters must have operating and safety devices that meet the requirements of G12/AS1 Paragraph 6.
paraphrase: If storage tanks are in solar water heaters, then the storage tank must have operating and safety devices that meet the requirements of G12/AS1 Paragraph 6.

text: 3.0 Solar Water Heater Requirements; Vent pipes and outlets from pressure relief valves must be plumbed to a suitable drain point.
paraphrase: If a solar water heater has pressure relief valves, then ventilation pipes and outlets from pressure relief valves must have plumbing to a drain point.

text: 4.2.1 Solar collectors must face within +/- 90 degrees of geographic north (ie between east and west) to satisfy the requirements of NZBC Clause H1.3.4(a).
paraphrase: If solar collectors exist, then the solar collectors must face within +/- 90 degrees of geographic north.

text: 4.2.2 Solar collectors must be inclined at an angle within +/- 20 degrees of the angle of latitude (from the horizontal) to satisfy the requirements of NZBC Clause H1.3.4(a).
paraphrase: If solar collectors exist, then the solar collectors must be inclined at an angle within +/- 20 degrees of the angle of latitude.

text: 5.0.1 Solar water heaters must be installed in accordance with the requirements of AS/NZS 3500 Part 4, unless modified by this Acceptable Solution.
paraphrase: If solar water heaters exist, then the solar water heaters must either be installed in accordance with the requirements of NZS 3500 Part 4, or NZS 3500 Part 4 is modified by G12/AS2.

text: 5.0.2 Water storage tanks that form part of a solar water heater must have drain pipes that: a) have an easily reached isolating valve, and terminate with a cap or plug to empty the vessel for maintenance, or b) terminate outside the building with a cap only.
paraphrase: If water storage tanks are part of a solar water heater, then the water storage tank must have drain pipes that either have an easily reached isolating valve, and terminate with a cap or plug, or drain pipes that terminate outside the building with a cap.

text: 5.0.3 Fixings used for the installation of a solar water heater must meet the requirements described in Paragraphs 2.1.1, 2.1.2, 2.1.3 and 2.1.4.
paraphrase: If fixings are used for the installation of a solar water heater, then the fixing must meet the requirements described in G12/AS1 Paragraphs 2.1.1, 2.1.2, 2.1.3 and 2.1.4.

text: 5.1.1 Where water is heated by a wetback water heater and a solar collector, independent water pipe circuits must be installed for each heat source.
paraphrase: If a wetback water heater and a solar collector are used as water heater, then the water pipe circuits of the wetback water heater and the solar collectore must be independent.

text: 5.2.3 Penetrations through masonry tile roofs must be as shown in Figure 5.
paraphrase: If penetrations are through masonry tile roofs, then the penetrations must be as shown in G12/AS2 Figure 5.

text: 5.2.4 Pipe penetrations in pressed metal tile roofs must be flashed using EPDM or silicone rubber boot flashings as shown in Figure 6.
paraphrase: If a pipe penetrations is in pressed metal tile roofs, then the penetration must be flashed using EPDM boot flashings or silicone rubber boot flashings and the flashing shall be as shown in G12/AS2 Figure 6.

text: 5.2.5 Roof penetrations in profiled metal roofs must be flashed as follows. Pipe penetrations up to 60 mm diameter must be flashed using an EPDM boot flashing as shown in Figure 6.
paraphrase: If pipe penetrations in profiled metal roofs are up to 60 mm diameter, then the penetration must be flashed using an EPDM boot flashing and the flashing shall be as shown in G12/AS2 Figure 6.

text: 5.2.5 Roof penetrations in profiled metal roofs must be flashed as follows. b) Rectangular penetrations up to 1200 mm wide must be flashed using a soaker type flashing as shown in Figure 7.
paraphrase: If rectangular penetrations in profiled metal roofs are up to 1200 mm wide, then the penetration must be flashed using an soaker type flashing and the flashing shall be as shown in G12/AS2 Figure 7.

text: 5.2.7 Penetrations through membrane roofs must be as shown in Figure 8.
paraphrase: If penetrations are through membrane roofs, then the penetration must be as shown in G12/AS2 Figure 8.

text: 9.0 Wall Claddings 9.7.1 Limitations; This Acceptable Solution is limited to the following type of fibre cement sheet cladding systems: a) Flush-finished systems over a drained cavity using sheets of 7.5 mm minimum thickness, with i) fibre cement sheets manufactured with a rebated edge for this purpose, ii) if necessary for part sheets, rebated on site using a purpose-made tool, and iii) have all edges sealed, iv) joints, comprising a bedding compound and reinforcing tape, that are finished in accordance with Paragraph 9.7.10.4.
paraphrase: If there is a fibre cement sheet wall cladding, then the wall cladding shall be finished flush and the wall cladding shall be over a drained cavity and the sheets shall be of 7.5 mm minimum thickness and the sheets shall have a rebated edge, the rebated edge shall be manufactured or formed insitu and the sheet shall have all edges sealed, and the the sheet's joints shall comprise a bedding compound and reinforcing tape, and the sheet's joint is in accordance with E2/AS1 Paragraph 9.7.10.4.

text: 9.0 Wall Claddings; 9.7 Fibre Cement Sheet 9.7.2 Material and installation – both systems; Fibre cement shall comply with AS/NZS 2908: Part 2.
paraphrase: If wall claddings are sheets from fibre cement, then the fibre cement shall comply with NZS 2908: Part 2.

text: The bottom of the EIFS cladding shall be as shown in Figure 125.
paraphrase: If claddings are EIFS cladding, then the bottom of the cladding shall be as shown in E2/AS1 Figure 125.

text: 9.0 Wall Claddings; 9.9.8 Pipes and service penetrations; All pipes and service penetrations through the EIFS shall be made weatherproof.
paraphrase: If the wall claddings are EIFS and either pipes or service penetrations are through the wall clading, then the pipes and penetrations shall be weatherproof.

text: Parapets shall comply with Paragraph 6.0.
paraphrase: If parapets exist, then the parapets shall comply with E2/AS1 Paragraph 6.0.

text: Enclosed balustrades shall comply with Paragraph 7.4.
paraphrase: If balustrades are enclosed, then the balustrade shall comply with E2/AS1 Paragraph 7.4.

text: 1.0.1 This Acceptable Solution applies to solar water heaters installed in or on buildings.
paraphrase: If solar water heaters installed in or on buildings, then G12/AS2 applies to the solar water heaters.

text: 1.0.2 To comply with this Acceptable Solution solar water heaters must also comply with the appropriate requirements of G12/AS1.
paraphrase: If solar water heaters exist, then the solar water heaters must comply with G12/AS1.

text: Solar water heater; This Acceptable Solution meets the requirements of NZBC Clauses B1, B2, E2, G12 and H1.
paraphrase: If a solar water heater complies with G12/AS2, then the solar water heater complies with NZBC Clauses B1, B2, E2, G12 and H1.

text: 1.1.1 Where a building has not been specifically designed to support a solar water heater, this Acceptable Solution can be used for the support and fixing of a solar collector on buildings that meet the structural requirements specified in any one of the following: • NZS 3604: 1990 • NZS 3604: 1999 • NZS 3604: 2011 • NZS 4203 • AS/NZS 1170: Parts 0, 1, 2, 3 and NZS 1170: Part 5. But only when all of the following requirements are met: a) the weight of solar collector, including frames, fittings, and heat transfer fluid, has a combined weight of no more than 22 kg per square metre (based on the gross area of the solar collector), and b) the hot water storage tank is not installed on or above the roof.
paraphrase: If a building has not been specifically designed for a solar water heater, but the solar collector is on the building and the buildings structure complies with NZS 3604: 1990, NZS 3604: 1999, NZS 3604: 2011, NZS 4203, AS/NZS 1170: Parts 0, 1, 2, 3 or NZS 1170: Part 5. And only if the weight of solar collector, including frames, fittings, and heat transfer fluid, is no more than 22 kg per square metre (based on the gross area of the solar collector), and if the hot water storage tank is not installed on or above the roof. Then the support and fixing of a solar collector may comply with G12/AS2.

text: 2.1.1 All material used to install the solar water heater must: a) meet the durability requirements of NZBC Clause B2, and b) be suitable for their use, location and environment as shown in Table 1, and c) be compatible with adjoining materials as shown in Table 2, and d) be compatible with materials subject to run-off as shown in Table 3 (except as described in Paragraph 2.1.2).
paraphrase: If material is used to install the solar water heater, then the material must: a) meet the durability requirements of NZBC Clause B2, and b) be suitable for their use, location and environment as shown in G12/AS2 Table 1, and c) be compatible with adjoining materials as shown in G12/AS2 Table 2, and d) be compatible with materials subject to run-off as shown in G12/AS2 Table 3 and not as described in G12/AS2 Paragraph 2.1.2.

text: Solar Water Heaters 2.1.3 If the requirements described in Paragragh 2.1.2 are not met then either the EPDM boots or the galvanised roofing must be painted with a suitable protective coating.
paraphrase: If EPDM boots or the galvanised roofing are adjacent to solar water heater and the solar water heater does not compy with G12/AS2 Paragragh 2.1.2, then either the EPDM boots or the galvanised roofing must be painted with a suitable protective coating.

text: Solar Water Heaters 2.1.4 Table 2 shows that galvanized fixings must be used rather than stainless steel when in contact with galvanized cladding and zinc-aluminium-magnesium (combinations) coated cladding. (This includes mounting brackets and straps.).
paraphrase: If the solar water heater's fixings are in contact with galvanized cladding and zinc-aluminium-magnesium coated cladding, then galvanized fixings shall be used as per G12/AS2 Table 2.

text: 3.1.1 Solar water heaters must comply with AS/NZS 2712.
paraphrase: If solar water heaters exist, then solar water heaters must comply with AS/NZS 2712.

text: 3.1.2 Tanks installed as part of a pumped solar water heater where the tank is separately mounted from the collector must comply with the minimum tank insulation requirements of AS/NZS 4692.2.
paraphrase: If tanks are part of a pumped solar water heater and the tank is separated from the collector, then the tank's insulation must comply with AS/NZS 4692.2.

text: 3.2.1 Where a solar water heater has a controller, the controller must meet the requirements specified in AS/NZS 2712: clause 6.3.
paraphrase: If a solar water heater has a controller, then the controller must meet the requirements specified in AS/NZS 2712: clause 6.3.

text: 3.2.3 A solar water heater which meets the requirements described in Paragraphs 3.2.1 and/or 3.2.2 satisfies NZBC Clause H1.3.4.
paraphrase: If a solar water heater meets the requirements described in G12/AS2 Paragraphs 3.2.1 or 3.2.2, then the solar water heater satisfies NZBC Clause H1 3.4.

text: 3.3.1 Solar water heaters must have a minimum of 50 litres of hot water storage per square metre of collector area.
paraphrase: If a solar water heater exists, then the solar water heater must have a minimum of 50 litres of hot water storage per square metre of collector area.

text: 9.1.1 Limitations; This Acceptable Solution is limited to the wall cladding systems listed in Paragraph 3.3.
paraphrase: If wall claddings are listed in E2/AS1 Paragraph 3.3, then E2/AS1 applies to the wall cladding.

text: 9.1.2 Maintenance; Maintenance of wall claddings shall be carried out as necessary to achieve the expected durability of the material – refer to Paragraph 2.5.
paraphrase: If the wall cladding material has a durability as per E2/AS1 Paragraph 2.5, then the wall cladding shall have the necessary maintenence.

text: 9.0 Wall Claddings; Separations, clearances to ground level, and overlaps shall be as shown in Figure 65 and Table 18.
paraphrase: If there is a wall cladding, then the wall cladding's separations, clearances to ground level, and laps shall be as shown in E2/AS1 Figure 65 and Table 18.

text: 9.0 Wall Claddings; Clearances to roof claddings and decks shall be minimum 35 mm – refer to Table 7 and Figure 18.
paraphrase: If the wall cladding exists, then the clearance of the wall cladding to the roof cladding or the deck shall be minimum 35 mm as in E2/AS1 Table 7 and Figure 18.

text: 9.0 Wall Claddings; 9.1.3 Bottom of cladding; Clearances shall be measured to: b) The top surface of any adjacent sloped or horizontal apron flashing.
paraphrase: If the bottom of the wall cladding has a clearance, then the clearances shall be measured to the top surface of any adjacent sloped or horizontal apron flashing.

text: Roof Framing 6.2.7 The centre of all fixings must be no closer than 10 fixing diameters from the end of a piece of timber.
paraphrase: If a piece of timber has a fixing, then the centre of the fixing must be no closer than 10 fixing diameters from the end of the piece of timber.

text: 6.3.1 Solar collectors can be fixed directly to the roof as shown in Figures 10 and 11 or Figures 12 and 13, where the requirements described in Paragraph 6.3 are met.
paraphrase: If the solar collector complies with G12/AS2 Paragraph 6.3, then the solar collector can be fixed directly to the roof as shown in G12/AS2 Figures 10 and 11 or Figures 12 and 13.

text: 6.3.2 Solar collectors mounted on the roof cladding must meet the materials requirements described in Paragraph 2.
paraphrase: If solar collectors connected to the roof cladding, then the solar collector must meet the materials requirements described in G12/AS2 Paragraph 2.

text: 6.4.2 Solar collectors mounted parallel to the roof that are elevated up to 50 mm above the roof cladding must be supported by: a) underlying purlins conforming to Paragraph 6.4.1 (a) or (b), or b) underlying rafters or trusses with connections conforming with Paragraphs 6.4.1 (a) or (c), or c) collector support rails conforming to Paragraph 6.5.
paraphrase: If solar collectors are orientated parallel to the roof and elevated up to 50 mm above the roof cladding, then the solar collector must be supported by either: a) purlins under the solar collector with the purlins conforming to G12/AS2 Paragraph 6.4.1.a or 6.4.1.b, or b) rafters under the solar collector with the rafter connections conforming with G12/AS2 Paragraphs 6.4.1.a or 6.4.1.c or trusses under the solar collector with the truss connections conforming with G12/AS2 Paragraphs 6.4.1.a or 6.4.1.c, or c) support rails conforming to G12/AS2 Paragraph 6.5.

text: Solar collector 6.5.1 Collector support rails may either: a) run horizontally across the slope of the roof as provided for in Paragraph 6.5.2 and Figure 17, or b) run up the slope of the roof as provided for in Paragraph 6.5.3 and Figure 18.
paraphrase: If the solar collector has support rails, then the support rails shall either be oriented horizontally to the slope of the roof as provided for in G12/AS2 Paragraph 6.5.2 and Figure 17, or the support rails shall be oriented verically to the slope of the roof as provided for in G12/AS2 Paragraph 6.5.3 and Figure 18.

text: 6.6.1 Solar collectors mounted at a different pitch to the pitch of the roof must be installed with no less than 8 fixing points and must meet all the requirements described in Paragraph 6.6 and Figure 19.
paraphrase: If the roof has a pitch and the solar collector's pitch is not the roof pitch, then the solar collector must have fixing at no less than 8 locations and must meet all the requirements described in G12/AS2 Paragraph 6.6 and Figure 19.

text: 6.6.3 The edge of the panel elevated above the roof plane is to be supported by hot dip galvanized steel or stainless steel angle struts which are: a) 25 x 25 x 3 mm angle for struts up to 1.0 m long.
paraphrase: If the panel is elevated and above the roof and angle struts are over 1 m long, then the edge of the paned is to be supported by hot dip galvanized steel angle struts or stainless steel angle struts which are: a) 25 mm width, 25 mm length, snd 3 mm thickness.

text: 6.6.3 The edge of the panel elevated above the roof plane is to be supported by hot dip galvanized steel or stainless steel angle struts which are: 30 x 30 x 3 mm angle for struts up to 1.4 m long.
paraphrase: If the panel is elevated and above the roof and angle struts are over 1.4 m long, then the edge of the paned is to be supported by hot dip galvanized steel angle struts or stainless steel angle struts which are: a) 30 mm width, 30 mm length, and 3 mm thickness.

text: Cuts or holes made in steel after galvanizing are to be protected from corrosion.
paraphrase: If penetrations are made in steel after galvanizing, then the penetration are to be protected from corrosion.

text: 4.2.1 Access points shall be provided in discharge pipes to allow the easy clearance of blockages.
paraphrase: If discharge pipes exist, then the discharge pipes shall have access points.

text: 4.4.1 The gradient of discharge pipes shall be not less than that required in Table 4 for the relevant discharge unit loading.
paraphrase: If discharge pipes exist, then the gradient of discharge pipes shall be not less than that required in G13/AS1 Table 4.

text: 4.5.1 Waste water fixture discharge pipes shall discharge either to: a) A gully trap, in accordance with Figure 5 of G13/AS1 and Figure 3 of G13/AS2, or b) A discharge stack as in Paragraph 4.7 and Figures 7 and 8.
paraphrase: If waste water fixture have discharge pipes, then the discharge pipes shall discharge either to: a) A gully trap, in accordance with Figure 5 of G13/AS1 and Figure 3 of G13/AS2, or b) A discharge stack as in G13/AS1 Paragraph 4.7 and Figures 7 and 8.

text: 4.5.2 Water seal protection: Waste water fixture discharge pipes shall be vented to comply with Paragraph 5.0 and as required in Table 5.
paraphrase: If waste water fixture have discharge pipes, then the discharge pipes shall have ventilation to comply with G13/AS1 Paragraph 5.0 and as required in Table 5.

text: 4.6.1 Fixture discharge pipes serving soil fixtures shall discharge either: a) Directly to the drain, as shown in Figure 6(1), or b) To a stack, as in Paragraph 4.7 and as shown in Figures 7 and 8.
paraphrase: If a soil fixture has discharge pipes, then the dicharge pipes shall discharge either: a) To the drain, as shown in G13/AS1 Figure 6.1, or b) To a stack, as in G13/AS1 Paragraph 4.7 and Figures 7 and 8.

text: 4.6.2 Water seal protection: Soil fixture discharge pipes shall be vented to comply with Paragraph 5.0 and as required in Table 5 (see Figure 6(2)).
paraphrase: If discharge pipes have soil fixture, then the soil fixture shall have ventilation that complies with G13/AS1 Paragraph 5.0 and as required in Table 5.

text: 5.1.1 Discharge pipes shall be vented where required by Table 5.
paraphrase: If discharge pipes exist, then the discharge pipes shall be have ventilation where required by G13/AS1 Table 5.

text: 5.3.1 Fixture vent pipes, branch vent pipes, discharge stack vents and relief vents shall have a diameter of no less than that given in Table 6.
paraphrase: If ventilation pipes are either for fixtures or branches or ventilation for discharge stacks or reliefs, then ventilation pipe and ventilation shall have a diameter of no less than the value given in G13/AS1 Table 6.

text: 5.6.1 The discharge stack vent, if also acting as a drain vent pipe shall have a diameter of not less than 80 mm.
paraphrase: If the venilation is for discharge stack and drain vent pipe, then the ventilation shall have a diameter of not less than 80 mm.

text: Where not acting as a drain vent the discharge stack vent pipe shall have a diameter of not less than that required in Table 6.
paraphrase: If the ventilation pipe is for the discharge stack but not for the drain ventilation, then the ventilation pipe shall have a diameter of not less than the value required in G13/AS1 Table 6.

text: 5.7.1 Open vent pipes shall terminate outside the building in accordance with Paragraphs 5.7.2 and 5.7.3 or 5.7.4.
paraphrase: If vent pipes are open, then the vent pipes shall terminate outside the building in accordance with G13/AS1 Paragraphs 5.7.2 and eiter 5.7.3 or 5.7.4.

text: 5.8.1 General; Air admittance valves may be used as venting where specified in accordance with Table 5.
paraphrase: If air admittance valves are specified in accordance with G13/AS1 Table 5, then the air admittance valves may be used as venting.

text: 5.8.2 Air admittance valves shall be manufactured to ASSE 1050, ASSE 1051, EN 12380 or AS/NZS 4936.
paraphrase: If air admittance valves exist, then air admittance valves shall be manufactured to ASSE 1050, ASSE 1051, EN 12380 or AS/NZS 4936.

text: Solar Water Heating System 7.1.1 A permanent label must be fixed to a prominent part of the system which includes all markings required in the appropriate Standard identified in Paragraph 3.1.1.
paraphrase: If solar water heating systems exist, then the solar water heating systems shall have a permanent label on a prominent part of the system. The label content has all markings required in the appropriate Standard identified in G12/AS2 Paragraph 3.1.1.

text: 7.2.1 Solar water heaters and their components must meet the durability requirements specified in NZBC Clause B2.
paraphrase: If solar water heaters exist, then the solar water heaters and their components must meet the durability requirements specified in NZBC Clause B2.

text: 7.2.2 A solar water heater is easy to access and moderately difficult to replace and therefore the durability requirement is 15 years.
paraphrase: If solar water heater exist, then the durability of the solar water heater shall be 15 years.

text: 1.0.1 This Acceptable Solution applies to above-ground non-pressure (gravity flow) sanitary plumbing for buildings having 3 levels or less and includes all pipework for foul water within, or on the building, including any basements.
paraphrase: If sanitary plumbing is above-ground and non-pressure or gravity flow sanitary plumbing for buildings having 3 levels or less, then G13AS1 applies to the sanitary plumbing and includes all pipework for foul water within, or on the building, including any basements.

text: 1.0.2 The solution does not include: a) Specialised types of sanitary fixtures or sanitary appliances used within buildings such as hospitals, laboratories and factories.
paraphrase: If specialised types of sanitary fixtures or sanitary appliances are used within buildings such as hospitals, laboratories and factories, then G13/AS1 does not apply to the sanitary fixtures or sanitary appliances.

text: Sanitary Plumbing 1.0.2 The solution does not include: The conveyance of industrial liquid wastes, chemical or toxic wastes and other wastes which cannot be discharged to a sewer without pretreatment.
paraphrase: If the sanitary plumbing conveys industrial liquid wastes, chemical or toxic wastes or other wastes which cannot be discharged to a sewer if it has no treatment, then G13/AS1 does not apply to the sanitary plumbing

text: 2.1.1 Materials for sanitary plumbing systems using gravity flow shall comply with Table 1.
paraphrase: If sanitary plumbing uses gravity flow, then the material of the sanitary plumbing shall comply with G13/AS1 Table 1.

text: 3.1.1 Discharge points from sanitary fixtures and sanitary appliances shall have a water trap to prevent foul air from the plumbing system entering the building.
paraphrase: If sanitary fixtures or sanitary appliances have discharge points, then the discharge points shall have a water trap.

text: 3.1.2 Water traps shall be: a) Removable, b) Able to be dismantled, or c) Fitted with a cleaning eye.
paraphrase: If water traps exist, then water traps shall be either removable, able to be dismantled, or have a cleaning eye.

text: 3.2.1 Under normal operating conditions, fixture traps shall retain a water seal depth of not less than 25 mm (see Figure 1).
paraphrase: If the fixture trap's operating condition is normal, then the fixture trap shall retain a water seal depth of not less than 25 mm.

text: 3.2.2 The diameter of the water trap shall be not less than that given in Table 2.
paraphrase: If a water trap exists, then the diameter of the water trap shall be not less than that given in G13/AS1 Table 2.

text: 3.4.1 Floor waste outlets shall have a removable grating that is flush with the floor.
paraphrase: If the floor waste has outlets, then the outlets shall have a removable grating that is flush with the floor.

text: 3.4.2 The floor waste shall have a minimum diameter of 40 mm.
paraphrase: If a floor waste exists, then the floor waste shall have a minimum diameter of 40 mm.

text: 3.4.2 The floor waste, and the water trap if used, shall have a minimum diameter of 40 mm.
paraphrase: If a floor waste or water trap exist, then the floor waste and water trap shall have a minimum diameter of 40 mm.

text: Individual floor waste pipes connected to a floor waste stack need not be vented (see Figure 3).
paraphrase: If pipes are in a floor waste stack, the the pipes need not be vented.

text: All trap charging systems shall incorporate backflow prevention in accordance with G12/AS1.
paraphrase: If a trap charging system exists, then the trap charging system shall incorporate backflow prevention in accordance with G12/AS1.

text: 5.2.9 Sealant used in the installation of solar water heaters must be a neutral cure silicone sealant and must be used in conjunction with mechanical fasteners. The sealant must comply with: a) Type F, Class 2OLM or 25LM of ISO 11600, or b) low modulus Type II Class A of Federal Specification TT-S-00230C.
paraphrase: If the installation of solar water heaters uses sealant, then the sealant must be a neutral cure silicone sealant and must be used in conjunction with mechanical fasteners. The sealant must comply with: a) Type F of ISO 11600, Class 2OLM of ISO 11600 or Class 25LM of ISO 11600, or b) low modulus Type II Class A of TT-S-00230C.

text: 5.2.10 Acetic cured silicone sealants may be used with stainless steel but must not be used on zinc or aluminium-zinc coatings.
paraphrase: If sealant type is acetic cured silicone, then the sealant may be used with stainless steel but must not be used on zinc coatings or aluminium-zinc coatings.

text: 5.2.12 All fixings or penetrations through the roof must be through the crests of the roof cladding.
paraphrase: If there are fixings or penetrations through the roof, then those fixings or penetration must be through the crest of the roof cladding

text: 5.3.1 Pipes and their supports must be electrochemically compatible or be electrolytically separated (refer to Table 2).
paraphrase: If pipes have supports, then the pipe and support must be electrochemically compatible or be electrolytically separated, for the separation refer to G12/AS2 Table 2.

text: 5.3.2 Pipes must be installed and supported to permit thermal movement, except where anchor points are necessary.
paraphrase: If pipe anchor points are not necessary, then the pipe must be installed and supported to permit thermal movement

text: 5.4.1 Hot water pipes must be insulated to satisfy the requirements of NZBC Clause H1.3.4, except where connected to a heat dissipation device.
paraphrase: If hot water pipes are not connected to a heat dissipation device, then the hot water pipe must be insulated to satisfy the requirements of NZBC Clause H1 3.4.

text: 6.2.2 The installation of solar collectors must not dent, bend or distort the roof cladding or damage any protective coatings.
paraphrase: If solar collectors exist, then the installation of solar collectors must not cause damages in form of dent, bend or distort of the roof cladding and the installation of solar collectors must not damage any protective coatings of the roof claddings.

text: 6.2.3 All fixings that penetrate metal cladding must be provided with sealing washers or boots to prevent leakage in accordance with Paragraph 5.2.
paraphrase: If a fixing goes through metal cladding, then the fixing must be provided with sealing washers or boots in accordance with G12/AS2 Paragraph 5.2.

text: 6.2.4 Solar collectors must be supported at no less than four points.
paraphrase: If solar collectors exist, then solar collectors must have support at no less than four locations.

text: Solar collectors; The outermost support points must be within 200 mm of the outside edge of the solar collector.
paraphrase: If the support location of the solar collector is outermost, then the support location must be within 200 mm of the outside edge of the solar collector.

text: 6.2.6 All screw fixings into roof framing timber must be installed with minimum distances from the centre of the fixing to the edge of the timber of: a) 20 mm for 8 gauge screws.
paraphrase: If a roof framing timber has screw fixings and the screws have the size 8 gauge, then the fixings must be installed with minimum distances from the centre of the fixing to the edge of the timber of 20 mm.

text: 6.2.6 All screw fixings into roof framing timber must be installed with minimum distances from the centre of the fixing to the edge of the timber of: 25 mm for 14 gauge screws.
paraphrase: If a roof framing timber has screw fixings and the screws have the size 14 gauge, then the fixings must be installed with minimum distances from the centre of the fixing to the edge of the timber of 25 mm.

text: 6.2.6 All bolt fixings into roof framing timber must be installed with minimum distances from the centre of the fixing to the edge of the timber of: 40 mm for 10 mm bolts.
paraphrase: If a roof framing timber has bolt fixings and the bolts are 10 mm, then the fixings must be installed with minimum distances from the centre of the fixing to the edge of the timber of 40 mm.

text: 3.1.1 To reduce the risk of blockages, the foul water drainage system shall: a) Have a simple layout that incorporates the least number of changes of direction, b) Use bends having a radius of the practical maximum, and c) Be laid only in straight lines between bends or junctions (both horizontally and vertically).
paraphrase: If foul water drainage system exists, then foul water drainage system shall: a) Have a simple layout that incorporates the least number of changes of direction, b) Use bends having a radius of the practical maximum, and c) Be pipes between bends or junctions are straight.

text: 3.2.1 Any connection to a drain, excluding vent pipe connections, shall be made by means of sweep or oblique junctions. The angle that the branch makes at the point of entry with the main drain, shall be no greater than 60° (see Figure 1).
paraphrase: If a drain has a connection and the connection is not with the vent pipe, then the connection shall be a sweep junction or oblique junction. The angle of the conection shall be no greater than 60 deg.

text: Drainage 3.3.1 All gully traps shall be constructed to prevent the ingress of surface water and foreign bodies likely to cause a blockage, shall be located within the legal boundary of the land on which the building is erected.
paraphrase: If gully traps exists, then gully traps shall prevent the ingress of surface water and foreign bodies, and gully traps shall be located within the site boundary.

text: Drainage 3.3.1 All gully traps shall have (see Figures 2 and 3): The overflow level of the gully dish no less than: 25 mm above paved surfaces.
paraphrase: If gully traps exists, then gully traps shall have a overflow level if no less than 25 mm above paved surfaces.

text: Drainage; All gully traps shall have: b) A grating that will allow surcharge.
paraphrase: If gully traps exists, then gully traps shall have a grating that will allow surcharge.

text: Drainage 3.3.1 All gully traps shall have (see Figures 2 and 3): A minimum outlet pipe diameter of 100 mm.
paraphrase: If gully traps exists, then gully traps shall have a outlet pipe with diameter with minimum of 100 mm.

text: Drainage 3.3.1 All gully traps shall have (see Figures 2 and 3): A water seal depth of at least 65 mm.
paraphrase: If gully traps exists, then gully traps shall have a water seal with depth of at least 65 mm.

text: 5.1.1 Rigid pipes shall have flexible joints to resist damage from differential settlement.
paraphrase: If pipes are rigid, then the pipe shall have flexible joints.

text: 5.1.2 Jointing for PVC-U pipes and fittings shall be in accordance with the methods described in AS/NZS 2032.
paraphrase: If pipes or pipe fittings are PVC-U, then the pipe and pipe fitting joints shall be in accordance with AS/NZS 2032.

text: 5.3.1 Figure 7 gives acceptable methods for the bedding and backfilling of the drainage pipes listed in Table 1 except where: a) The trench is located within or above peat, b) Scouring of the trench is likely due to unstable soils, or d) The cover H to the pipe is more than 2.5 m.
paraphrase: If drainage pipes are listed in G13/AS2 Table 1, then the trench is not located within or above a peat, soil is not unstable, and the cover of the pipe is no more than 2.5 m, then bedding and backfilling may comply with G13/AS2 Figure 7.

text: The width B of the trench shall be no less than the pipe diameter D plus 200 mm.
paraphrase: If the trench is for the pipe, then the width of the trench shall be no less than the pipe diameter plus 200 mm.

text: Drainage; Junctions beneath the building joining at an angle of not more than 45° (see Figure 13).
paraphrase: If junctions are beneath the building, then the junctions shall have an angle of not more than 45 deg.

text: 5.9.1 Where two or more soil fixtures are connected to a branch drain beneath the building, access for cleaning shall be provided by a sealed floor level rodding point located downstream of the highest fixture connection to the branch drain (see Figures 10 and 13).
paraphrase: If two or more soil fixtures are connected to a branch drain beneath the building, then the drain shall have access for cleaning by a sealed floor level rodding point located at the highest fixture connection.

text: 5.9.3 Access points may be located in a space containing a soil fixture.
paraphrase: If access points exists, then access points may be located in a space containing a soil fixture.

text: 5.10.1 Where a drain or part of a drain is no longer required, it shall be disconnected from the foul water drainage system at the junction with the live drain or at the property boundary.
paraphrase: If a drain or part of a drain is not required, then the drain and part of a drain shall be disconnected at the live drain junction or at the property boundary.

text: 6.1.1 All sections of the drainage system shall be tested by water test or air test to ensure watertightness.
paraphrase: If a drain section is part of the drainage system, then the drain section shall be tested for watertightness by water test or air test.

text: 6.1.3 Air tests may be carried out in accordance with either clause 15.3 of AS/NZS 3500.2 or paragraph 8.3 of E1/VM1.
paraphrase: If air tests exists, then air tests may be in accordance with either NZS 3500.2 clause 15.3 or E1/VM1 paragraph 8.3.

text: 6.1.5 Where a building is proposed to be built over an existing drain, the drain shall be verified as being sound both before and after construction.
paraphrase: If a building is constructed over an existing drain, then the drain soundness shall have verification both before and after construction.

text: 1.0.1 The method of solid waste disposal in multi-unit and group dwellings shall be by the provision of moveable containers having a capacity of at least 80 litres for each dwelling unit.
paraphrase: If a building is a multi-unit dwelling or group dwelling, then the building shall have solid waste disposal and for each dwelling unit the method of solid waste disposal shall be a moveable container with capacity of at least 80 litres.

text: G15 Solid waste 1.0.2 Where containers are stored in a common area within a building or part of a building, a space of at least 0.5 m x 0.5 m by 1 m high shall be provided for each dwelling unit.
paraphrase: If the waste storage area is common and located within a building, then there shall be for each of the building's dwelling unit a space of at least 0.5 m length, 0.5 m width, and 1 m height.

text: G15 Solid waste 1.0.3 If a common storage area such as a ground floor rubbish area is provided within the building, it shall be adequately ventilated to the open air in compliance with NZBC G4.
paraphrase: If a waste storage area is common and located within the building, then the waste storage area shall be adequately ventilated to the open air in compliance with NZBC G4.

text: Drainage 3.3.1 All gully traps shall have (see Figures 2 and 3): Waste pipe outlets located at least 20 mm above water seal level, and at least 20 mm below the grating.
paraphrase: If gully traps exists, then gully traps shall have waste pipe outlets with elevation at least 20 mm above water seal elevation, and at least 20 mm below the grating elevation.

text: Drainage 3.3.1 All gully traps shall have (see Figures 2 and 3): i) Adequate support from bedding and backfilling with: i) concrete no less than 75 mm thick surrounding the entire gully dish and which is separated from the building foundation, where the gully trap is likely to be damaged, and j) A minimum of 600 mm clear access space above the gully dish.
paraphrase: If gully traps exists, then gully traps shall have: i) bedding and backfilling with: i) concrete no less than 75 mm thick surrounding the entire gully dish and either the concrete is away from the building foundation or the gully trap is not damage prone, and j) A minimum of 600 mm clear access space above the gully dish.

text: 3.3.2 In order to provide overflow relief for the drainage system, every building used for Housing shall be provided with at least one gully trap which shall:.
paraphrase: If a building classified use is housing, then the building shall have a gully trap

text: 3.3.2 Gully trap which shall: a) Be positioned so that the top of the gully dish is no less than 150 mm below the overflow level of the lowest sanitary fixture served by the drainage system.
paraphrase: If gully traps exists, then gully traps shall have the top of their gully dish no less than 150 mm below the overflow level of the sanitary fixture serving the gullyTrap with the lowest elevation.

text: Drainage 3.3.2 Gully trap which shall: Have a grating that will allow surcharge.
paraphrase: If gully traps exists, then gully traps shall have a grating for surcharge.

text: Drainage 3.3.2 Gully trap which shall: Be located in a visible position.
paraphrase: If gully traps exists, then gully traps shall be located in a visible position.

text: Drainage 3.3.2 Gully trap which shall: Be installed so that surcharge cannot enter into or under buildings.
paraphrase: If gully traps exists, then gully traps surcharge shall not enter into or under buildings.

text: 3.4.1 Grease traps shall be provided for any discharge pipe serving a sink(s) where the foul water discharges to a soak pit.
paraphrase: If a sink has a discharge pipe and the pipe discharges into a soak pit, then the dicharge pipe shall have grease traps.

text: 3.4.2 In buildings other than Housing, grease traps shall be provided where waste water is likely to convey grease.
paraphrase: If a buildings classified use is not Housing and its waste water is likely to convey grease, then grease traps shall be provided for the drain.

text: 3.4.3 The capacity of a grease trap shall be at least twice the capacity of all sanitary fixtures and sanitary appliances discharging to it, and in no case less than 100 litres as shown in Figure 4.
paraphrase: If grease traps exists, then the capacity of a grease trap shall be at least twice the capacity of all sanitary fixtures and sanitary appliances with discharge into it, and in no case less than 100 litres.

text: 3.4.4 For restaurants and cafés, the capacity of the grease trap shall be at least 5 litres for each person for whom seating is provided, and in no case less than that required by Paragraph 3.4.3.
paraphrase: If the building's acitivity is restaurant or cafe, then the capacity of the grease trap shall be at least 5 litres for each seating.

text: 3.4.5 Grease traps located outside a building shall be configured as shown in Figure 4.
paraphrase: If grease traps are located outside a building, then the grease trap shall be configured as shown in G13/AS2 Figure 4.

text: 3.4 Grease traps 3.4.6 The top of the outlet junction shall be extended to finished ground level and fitted with a watertight rodding point access cover as shown in Figures 4 and 10.
paraphrase: If the grease trap has a outlet junction, then the top of the outlet junction shall be extended to finished ground level and fitted with a watertight rodding point access cover as shown in Figures 4 and 10.

text: 3.5.1 Drains shall: a) Be laid at an even grade, and b) Have no obstructions to flow.
paraphrase: If drains exists, then drains shall be laid at an even grade, and have no obstructions to flow.

text: 3.5.2 Drains shall be installed at the maximum practicable gradient.
paraphrase: If drains exists, then drains shall be installed at the maximum practicable gradient.

text: 3.5.3 The gradient of drainage pipes shall be not less than that required in Table 2 for the relevant discharge unit loading.
paraphrase: If drain pipes exists, then the gradient of drain pipes shall be not less than the value required in G13/AS2 Table 2.

text: 3.6.1 The diameter of a drain shall not decrease in size in the direction of flow.
paraphrase: If drains exists, then the diameter of a drain shall not decrease in the direction of flow.

text: 3.6.2 Drains shall have a diameter of not less than 80 mm where the drain serves only waste water fixtures.
paraphrase: IF the drain serves waste water fixtures and not fixtures that are not waste water fixtures, then drains shall have a diameter of not less than 80 mm.

text: 3.6.2 Drains shall have a diameter of not less than 100 mm where the drain does not serve only waste water fixtures.
paraphrase: IF the drain serves fixtures that are not waste water fixtures, then the drain shall have a diameter of not less than 100 mm.

text: 4.1.1 The drainage system shall be ventilated to allow a flow of air and to minimise the build up of foul air.
paraphrase: If drains exists, then the drain shall be ventilated.

text: 4.1.2 Every main drain, and every branch drain longer than 10 m, shall be ventilated in accordance with Table 3.
paraphrase: If a drain is type main, and the branch drain is longer than 10 m, then the drain shall be ventilated in accordance with G13/AS2 Table 3.

text: 4.2.1 A main drain vent shall have a minimum diameter of 80 mm, and shall comply with termination requirements of Paragraph 5.7.3 of G13/AS1 "Sanitary Plumbing".
paraphrase: If a main drain has ventilation, then the ventilation shall have a minimum diameter of 80 mm, and the ventilation shall comply with termination requirements of G13/AS1 Paragraph 5.7.3.

text: 4.2.2 Branch drain vents shall be sized in accordance with Table 6 in G13/AS1.
paraphrase: If a branch drain has ventilation, then the ventilation shall be sized in accordance with Table 6 in G13/AS1.

text: Air admittance valves that form an integral part of a fixture trap shall only be used as a trap vent.
paraphrase: If air admittance valves are part of a fixture trap, then the air admittance valves shall be used as ventilation for the fixture trap but not for other.

text: 6.1.1 Jointing methods for PVC-U pipe shall comply with AS/NZS 2032.
paraphrase: If the pipe material is PVC-U, then the pipe jointing method shall comply with NZS 2032.

text: 6.2.1 Pipes shall be supported at centres not exceeding those in Table 7.
paraphrase: If pipes exist, then the pipes shall be supported at centres complying with G13/AS1 Table 7.

text: 6.4.1 Fire stopping shall be fitted to pipes passing through fire separations in accordance with C/AS2 Paragraph 4.4.
paraphrase: If pipes pass through fire separations, then fire stops shall be fitted to the pipe in accordance with C/AS2 Paragraph 4.4.

text: 1.0.1 This Acceptable Solution is for below ground non-pressure (gravity flow) foul water drains having a diameter of no greater than 150 mm.
paraphrase: If foul water drains are below ground, their type is non-pressure or gravity flow and the foul water drains diameter is no greater than 150 mm, then G13/AS2 applies to the foul water drain.

text: 1.0.2 It does not apply to foul water drainage systems where it is necessary to dispose of industrial liquid wastes, chemical or toxic wastes and other wastes which cannot be discharged to a sewer without pre-treatment.
paraphrase: If foul water drains are for industrial liquid wastes, chemical or toxic wastes or other wastes which cannot be discharged to a sewer without pre-treatment, then G13/AS2 does not apply to foul water drains.

text: 2.0.1 Materials for drainage pipes and joints shall comply with the appropriate standards shown in Table 1.
paraphrase: If drain pipes exists, then materials for drain pipes and drain pipe joints shall comply with G13/AS2 Table 1.

text: 4.0.1 Where waste chutes with side-entry hoppers (see Figure 2) are used as an alternative to common storage areas, the chute shall: a) Have a minimum internal diameter of 450 mm, b) Be self-cleaning, vertical and have smooth joints, c) Be vented at the top above the roof line, and at the bottom above the container, and d) Terminate centrally over a suitable container located in a room complying with Paragraphs 3.0.1 to 3.0.9.
paraphrase: If a waste chute has side-entry hoppers and no common waste storage area exists, then the waste chute shall have a minimum internal diameter of 450 mm, the waste chute shall be self-cleaning, vertical and have smooth joints, the waste chute shall have ventilation at the top above the roof line, and the waste chute shall have ventilation at the bottom above the container, and the waste chute shall terminate centrally over a suitable container located in a room complying with G15/AS1 Paragraphs 3.0.1 to 3.0.9.

text: 4.0.2 Side-entry hoppers (see Figure 2) shall: a) Have a maximum opening diameter of 250 mm, b) Have self-closing, tight-fitting doors to prevent odours escaping, c) Have an easily cleaned wall surface surrounding the opening for 300 mm (this may be galvanised steel, ceramic tiles or similar material), d) Be located outside any dwelling or enclosed stair access, and away from any habitable space or food preparation area, and e) Have adequate ventilation, preferably by being located in the open air (e.g. on an outside balcony). Where hoppers are inside buildings, they shall be located in separate ventilated compartments complying with NZBC G4.
paraphrase: If side-entry hoppers exist, then side-entry hoppers shall have a maximum opening diameter of 250 mm, side-entry hoppers shall have self-closing, tight-fitting doors, side-entry hoppers shall have an easily cleaned wall surface surrounding the opening for 300 mm, side-entry hoppers shall be located outside any dwelling or enclosed stair access, and located away from any habitable space or food preparation area, and side-entry hoppers shall have ventilation and side-entry hoppers is either located in the open air or located in separate ventilated compartments complying with NZBC G4.

text: 4.0.3 Buildings incorporating waste chutes, shall be provided with a water supply tap on every second floor, adjacent to the chute, to facilitate cleaning.
paraphrase: If buildings have waste chutes, then the buildings shall have a water supply tap on every second floor, the water supply tap shall be adjacent to the chute.

text: 1.1.1 Type; The acceptable solutions described in this document are for chimneys built of brickwork, concrete or precast pumice concrete, that are connected to timber frame or masonry buildings complying with NZS 3604 or NZS 4229.
paraphrase: If chimneys are built of brickwork, concrete or precast pumice concrete and the chimneys are connected to timber frame buildings or masonry buildings complying with NZS 3604 or NZS 4229, then B1/AS3 applies to the chimney.

text: 1.1.2 Height; The height of any chimney measured from the top of the chimney foundation slab to the top of the chimney stack shall not exceed 9 m.
paraphrase: If chimneys exist, then the height of the chimney measured from the top of the chimney foundation slab to the top of the chimney stack shall not exceed 9 m.

text: Chimneys shall not cantilever more than 2.4 m above the fixing at roof level (refer Paragraph 1.7).
paraphrase: If chimneys exist, then the chimney height above the fixing at roof level shall not be more than 2.4 m.

text: 1.1.3 Size; The width (measured along the building line) and depth (measured perpendicular to the building line) shall not exceed: a) For the foundation and chimney base – precast pumice concrete 1600 mm wide x 1050 mm deep.
