paraphrase: If the chimney is precast pumice concrete and has a foundation or chimney base, then the foundations or chimney base width measured along the building line and the the foundations or chimney base depth measured perpendicular to the building line shall not exceed 1600 mm width and 1050 mm depth.

text: 1.1.3 Size; The width (measured along the building line) and depth (measured perpendicular to the building line) shall not exceed: a) For the foundation and chimney base – brickwork or concrete 1200 mm wide x 1050 mm deep.
paraphrase: If the chimney is brickwork or concrete and has foundation or chimney base, then the foundation or chimney base width (measured along the building line) and the foundation or chimney base depth (measured perpendicular to the building line) shall not exceed 1200 mm width and 1050 mm depth.

text: 1.6.1 Reinforcing of foundation walls and chimney bases (including the gathers) (see Figures 2 to 5 inclusive) shall comprise: a) D12 bars at 400 mm maximum centres vertically. Laps in bars shall be no less than 300 mm. b) R6 bars at 200 mm centres horizontally. These will be in the form of U bars.
paraphrase: If reinforcing is part of foundation walls, chimney bases, and chimney gathers, then the reinforching shall include D12 reinforcing bars at 400 mm maximum centres vertically. Laps in reinforcing bars shall be no less than 300 mm and the reinforching shall include R6 reinforcing bars at 200 mm centres horizontally and the reinforcing bars are U bars.

text: 1.6.1 Reinforcing of chimney stacks (see Figures 2 to 5 inclusive) shall comprise: a) D12 bars at 400 mm maximum centres vertically. Laps in bars shall be no less than 300 mm. b) R6 bars at 200 mm centres horizontally. These will be in the form of closed stirrups in the stack.
paraphrase: If reinforcing is part of chimney stacks, then the reinforcing shall include D12 reinforcing bars at 400 mm maximum centres vertically and the laps in reinforcing bars shall be no less than 300 mm, and the reinforcing shall include R6 reinforcing bars at 200 mm centres horizontally and the reinforcing bars are closed stirrups.

text: 1.6.1 Reinforcing of foundation walls, chimney bases (including the gathers) and chimney stacks (see Figures 2 to 5 inclusive) shall comprise: Double horizontal reinforcing at any change in direction of the vertical steel (e.g. at the gather/stack intersection).
paraphrase: If reinforcing is for foundation walls, chimney bases, chimney gathers, and chimney stacks and includes a vertical reinforcing bar with change in direction, then the reinforcing shall include two horizontal reinforcing bars at the change in direction.

text: 1.7.2 Where a packer (see Figures 2, 3, 6 and 7(b)) is shown between the chimney and building it shall be: a) Concrete, brick, steel (angle, channel or Z section), or any insulating material which has a long term operating temperature of no less than 150°C, b) Secured in place to prevent it dislodging, and c) Capable of withstanding a compressive force of 10 kN without shortening by more than 1.5 mm.
paraphrase: If a packer is between the chimney and building, then the packer shall be concrete, brick, steel angle, steel channel or steel Z section, or any insulating material which has a operating temperature of no less than 150 deg C, and the packer shall be fixed, and the packer shall have compressive resistance of 10 kN force without the packer shortening by more than 1.5 mm.

text: The brackets shall comprise a 50 mm x 4 mm hot dip galvanised steel strap placed around the chimney.
paraphrase: If brackets exist, the brackets shall be a strap with 50 mm length, 4 mm depth with material hot dip galvanised steel and the strap is placed around the chimney.

text: 1.7.6 Brick chimneys; Brick chimneys shall be restrained at roof level by a zinc coated 50 x 1.0 mm mild steel 'U' strap used in conjunction with closely spaced wall ties.
paraphrase: If chimneys are brick, then the chimney shall be fixed at roof level by 'U' straps and wall ties. The 'U' straps are zinc coated 50 length, 1.0 mm depth, mild steel and wall ties are closely spaced.

text: 1.7.7 Wall ties (see Figure 7(a)) shall be located in mortar joints at 225 mm maximum centres up each side of the chimney for chimneys not wider than 600 mm.
paraphrase: If chimneys are not wider than 600 mm and have wall ties, then for each side of the chimney the wall tie shall be located in mortar joints at 225 mm maximum centres elevation.

text: 1.7.7 Wall ties (see Figure 7(a)) shall be located in mortar joints at 225 mm maximum centres up each side of the chimney, except that pairs of ties shall be used for chimneys wider than 600 mm.
paraphrase: If chimneys are wider than 600 mm and have wall ties, then for each side of the chimney two wall ties shall be located in mortar joints at 225 mm maximum centres elevation.

text: 1.1.3 Size; The width (measured along the building line) and depth (measured perpendicular to the building line) shall not exceed: For a brick chimney stack – single skin (see Figure 2) 500 mm wide x 500 mm deep.
paraphrase: If a chimney stack has material brick type single skin, then the chimney stack width (measured along the building line) and chimney stack depth (measured perpendicular to the building line) shall not exceed 500 mm width and 500 mm depth.

text: 1.1.3 Size; The width (measured along the building line) and depth (measured perpendicular to the building line) shall not exceed: For a brick chimney stack – double skin (see Figure 3) - 1200 mm wide x 680 mm deep.
paraphrase: If a chimney stack has material brick type double skin, then the chimney stack width (measured along the building line) and chimney stack depth (measured perpendicular to the building line) shall not exceed 1200 mm width and 680 mm depth.

text: 1.1.3 Size; The width (measured along the building line) and depth (measured perpendicular to the building line) shall not exceed: For a concrete or precast pumice concrete chimney stack - 1200 mm wide x 700 mm deep.
paraphrase: If a chimney stack is concrete or precast pumice concrete, then the chimney stack width (measured along the building line) and chimney stack depth (measured perpendicular to the building line) shall not exceed 1200 mm width and 700 mm depth.

text: 1.1.4 Chimney liners; Where chimney liners are used they are to be separated from the chimney to ensure free thermal movement. This shall be achieved by coating the liner with a suitable debonding agent or by wrapping it in a combustible material no less than 0.25 mm thick.
paraphrase: If the chimney has chimney liners, then the chimney liners shall have coating with a debonding agent or wrapping with combustible material and the wrapping is no less than 0.25 mm thick.

text: 1.2.1 Chimney wall thicknesses shall be no less than: a) Brick – single skin (see Figure 2) 155 mm.
paraphrase: If chimneys are material brick with single skin, then the chimney shall have a wall thicknesses of no less than 155 mm.

text: 1.2.1 Chimney wall thicknesses shall be no less than: a) Brick – double skin (see Figure 3) 245 mm.
paraphrase: If chimneys are material brick with double skin, then shall have a wall thicknesses of 245 mm.

text: 1.2.1 Chimney wall thicknesses shall be no less than: Concrete 170 mm.
paraphrase: If chimneys are concrete, then the chimney shall have a wall thickness of no less than 170 mm.

text: 1.2.1 Chimney wall thicknesses shall be no less than: Precast pumice concrete 85 mm.
paraphrase: If chimneys are precast pumice concrete, then the chimney shall have a wall thickness of no less than 85 mm.

text: 1.3.3 The chimney foundation walls shall be 150 mm thick reinforced concrete, 190 mm thick concrete masonry, or brick construction complying with Figures 2 or 3. Vertical and horizontal reinforcing steel shall be as given in Paragraph 1.6.
paraphrase: If the chimney has foundation walls, then the wall shall be either 150 mm thick reinforced concrete, 190 mm thick concrete masonry, or brick construction complying with B1/AS3 Figures 2 or 3. Reinforcing steel shall be as given in B1/AS3 Paragraph 1.6.

text: 1.4.1 Hearth slabs shall be of concrete no less than 75 mm thick, reinforced with D10 bars located centrally at 225 mm centres each way. See Figure 1.
paraphrase: If chimneys have hearth slabs, then the slab shall be of concrete no less than 75 mm thick and has reinforcing bar type D10 located at 225 mm centres each way of the slab.

text: 1.5.1 The widths of openings in chimney breasts, and their supporting lintels, shall comply with Table 1.
paraphrase: If chimney breasts exist, then the chimney breast openings' width and lintels shall comply with B1/AS3 Table 1.

text: 2.0.1 In multi-unit and group dwellings, the maximum carry distance between any occupancy and a common solid waste storage area or chute shall be 30 m.
paraphrase: In a building is a multi-unit dwelling or group dwelling, then for each building occupancy, the maximum carry distance between any occupancy and a solid waste storage area or chute shall be 30 m.

text: 3.0.1 An acceptable common storage area for solid waste (see Figure 1) shall: a) Have interior surfaces which are easily cleaned.
paraphrase: If a waste storage area is for solid waste and common, then the waste storage area shall have interior surfaces which are easily cleaned.

text: 3.0 Solid waste Storage Areas 3.0.1 An acceptable common storage area for solid waste (see Figure 1) shall: Be totally enclosed and separated from habitable spaces and food preparation areas.
paraphrase: If a waste storage area is for solid waste and common, then the waste storage area shall be totally enclosed and separated from habitable spaces and food preparation areas.

text: 3.0.1 An acceptable common storage area for solid waste (see Figure 1) shall: Be protected from high temperatures which could hasten putrification.
paraphrase: If a waste storage area is for solid waste and common, then the waste storage area shall be protected from high temperatures.

text: 3.0.1 An acceptable common storage area for solid waste (see Figure 1) shall: Be screened from habitable spaces to reduce visual impact.
paraphrase: If a waste storage area is for solid waste and common, then the waste storage area shall be screened from habitable spaces.

text: 3.0 Solid waste Storage Areas 3.0.2 Concrete floors are acceptable if they have a U5 trowelled finish complying with NZS 3114 and are graded at 1 in 50 to a floor drain. Floor drains shall comply with NZBC G13.
paraphrase: If there are concrete floors in waste storage areas, then the floor shall have a U5 trowelled finish complying with NZS 3114 and a gradient of 1 in 50 to a floor drain. The floor drains shall comply with NZBC G13.

text: 3.0.3 Walls in spaces where storage bins are likely to receive food wastes and are subject to spillage shall be constructed of concrete, galvanised sheet steel, vinyl or similar material.
paraphrase: If a space has walls and storage bins and the storage bins receive food waste and the storage bins may have spillage, then the walls of the space shall have the material of concrete, galvanised sheet steel, vinyl or material similar to concrete, galvanised sheet steel, vinyl.

text: 3.0.4 Windows facing north in any food waste storage area shall be screened from direct sunlight in order to reduce the likelihood of putrification.
paraphrase: If windows facing north in any food waste storage area, then the waste storage area shall be screened from direct sunlight.

text: 3.0.5 An alternative solution is for perishable wastes to be stored within a refrigerated store room.
paraphrase: If waste is perishable, then the waste storage room for the waste may have refrigeration.

text: Waste Storage Area 3.0.6 opening windows shall be screened to prevent entry by insects and other vermin.
paraphrase: If a waste storage area has openable windows, then the windows shall be screened from vermin.

text: 3.0.7 A water supply tap, complying with NZBC G12, shall be provided for washing down common waste storage areas.
paraphrase: If the waste storage area is type common, then the waste storage area shall have a water supply tap complying with NZBC G12.

text: 3.0.8 Ventilation: Storage areas located indoors shall be adequately ventilated to open air in compliance with NZBC G4.
paraphrase: If a waste storage area is located indoors, the waste storage area shall have ventilation to open air in compliance with NZBC G4.

text: 3.0.9 Mechanical ventilation: Where mechanical ventilation is used, it shall: a) Provide no less than 6 air changes per hour, b) Maintain a negative pressure within the storage area relative to adjacent areas (if any), and c) Discharge foul air to a safe place to avoid the likelihood of exhaust air entering any building.
paraphrase: If the waste storage area has ventilation and the ventilation is mechanical, then the ventilation shall have a ventilation rate of no less than 6 air changes per hour, the ventilation shall maintain a negative pressure within the storage area relative to adjacent areas, and the ventilation shall discharge to a safe place.

text: 3.0.10 Access between the storage area and collection vehicle shall comply with NZBC D1.
paraphrase: If a waste storage area exists, then the access between the waste storage area and collection vehicle shall comply with NZBC D1.

text: 3.1.1 NZS 4304 Section 6.2 is another Acceptable Solution for storage areas, but may exceed the performance criteria of NZBC G15.
paraphrase: If waste storage areas exist, then waste storage areas may comply with NZS 4304 Section 6.2.

text: 1.7.13 Precast pumice concrete chimneys; Precast pumice concrete chimneys shall be restrained at roof level either by a 50 x 1 mm 'U' strap wrapped around the chimney, or by a hot dip galvanised deformed 6 mm reinforcing bar placed into the grout around the reinforcing steel, together with either fixing brackets or fixing ties (see Figure 7(b)). Straps and bars shall satisfy the relevant requirements of Paragraphs 1.7.6 to 1.7.12.
paraphrase: If chimneys are precast pumice concrete, then the chimney shall be restrained at roof level either by a 50 x 1 mm 'U' strap wrapped around the chimney, or by a hot dip galvanised deformed 6 mm sized reinforcing bar placed into the grout around the reinforcing steel, the restraint shall include brackets or ties and be as seen in B1AS3 Figure 7.b. 'U' Straps and bars shall satisfy the relevant requirements of B1AS3 Paragraphs 1.7.6 to 1.7.12.

text: 1.7.14 Fixing brackets (see Figure 7(b)) shall be made from 5.0 mm thick mild steel angle and drilled with: a) A 50 mm diameter hole to suit the reinforcing duct location, and b) A 14 mm diameter hole for the 12 mm diameter coach screw fixing to the double stud.
paraphrase: If there are fixing brackets, then the brackets shall be made from 5 mm thick mild steel angle and drilled with two holes. A 50 mm diameter hole to suit the reinforcing duct, and a 14 mm diameter hole for the 12 mm diameter coach screw fixing to the double stud.

text: 1.7.15 Fixing brackets shall be located in mortar joints between the units.
paraphrase: If brackets are type fixing, then the brackets shall be located in mortar joints between the units.

text: 1.7.15 Fixing brackets shall be spaced at no less than 480 mm centres for stacks up to 600 mm wide.
paraphrase: If brackets are type fixing and stacks are up to 600 mm wide, then the brackets shall be spaced at no less than 480 mm centres.

text: 1.9.1 The bracing described in Paragraphs 1.9.2 to 1.9.6 shall be provided in those buildings where one or more of the following apply: a) The area of the room containing the chimney exceeds 24 m2, c) The floor area on any level of the building, for a given chimney type (see Table 2), is less than: i) 50 m2 for chimney Type 1, ii) 75 m2 for chimney Types 2, 3 and 4, iii) 150 m2 for chimney Types 5, 6 and 7.
paraphrase: If either the building's space containing the chimney exceeds an area of 24 m2, or the floor area of a building storey is less than 50 m2 and chimney is Type 1, or the floor area of a building storey is less than 75 m2 and chimney is Types 2, 3 or 4, or the floor area of a building storey is less than 150 m2 and chimney is Types 5, 6 and 7, then the building shall have bracing as described in B1/AS3 Paragraphs 1.9.2 to 1.9.6.

text: 1.9.3 The number of bracing units to be provided for each chimney connection (see Paragraph 1.9.4) is given in Table 2.
paraphrase: If a chimney exists, then for each chimney connection the number of bracing units shall be as given in B1/AS3 Table 2.

text: 1.9.4 A chimney shall be considered as connected to the building when: a) At roof level: it is held either by a roof bracket or by a roof tie.
paraphrase: If a chimney is fixed by a roof bracket or by a roof tie and the fixing elevation is roof level, then the chimney is considered connected to the building.

text: 1.9.4 A chimney shall be considered as connected to the building when: At ground floor level: it is held by a floor bracket or the chimney base is integral with the building foundation wall,.
paraphrase: If a chimney at ground floor level is either fixed by a floor bracket or the chimney base is part of the building foundation wall, then the chimney is considered connected to the building.

text: 1.9.4 A chimney shall be considered as connected to the building when: At an intermediate floor level: it is held either by a floor bracket or by closely spaced wall ties spanning the floor.
paraphrase: If a chimney at an intermediate floor level is fixed by either a floor bracket or by closely spaced wall ties spanning between the floor, then the chimney is considered connected to the building.

text: Structural diaphragms shall be provided at roof/ceiling level and at each floor level to which the chimney is connected. The diaphragms shall comply with all relevant clauses of NZS 3604 and NZS 4229.
paraphrase: If the building has a chimney and either the building storey is roof or ceiling level, or the building storey is connected to the chimney, then the building storey shall have diaphragms and the diaphragms shall comply with NZS 3604 and NZS 4229.

text: The bracing units required as determined from Paragraph 1.9.3 shall be provided solely by that wall.
paraphrase: If the bracing's units are determined from B1/AS3 Paragraph 1.9.3, then the bracing's units shall be provided by that wall.

text: 2.1.1 Chimneys for solid fuel burning appliances shall comply with Paragraph 1.0 or with the relevant sections of AS/NZS 3869 and AS/NZS 2918 for sheetmetal chimneys.
paraphrase: If chimneys are for solid fuel burning appliances, then the chimney shall either comply with B1/AS3 Paragraph 1.0 or chimneys shall be sheetmetal and comply with NZS 3869 and NZS 2918.

text: 1.7.15 Fixing brackets shall be spaced at no less than 320 mm centres for stacks wider than 600 mm.
paraphrase: If brackets are type fixing and stacks are wider than 600 mm, then the brackets shall be spaced at no less than 320 mm centres.

text: 1.7.16 Fixing ties shall comprise 4 mm galvanised wire hairpins, which are hooked behind the reinforcing ducts and secured to the required adjacent double studding with four heavy duty fencing staples.
paraphrase: If ties are type fixing, then the ties shall be 4 mm galvanised wire hairpins, which are hooked behind the reinforcing ducts and have fixing to the double studding adjacent to the reinforcing ducts. The ties fixing is done by four heavy duty fencing staples.

text: Fixing ties shall be located in mortar joints between the units.
paraphrase: If ties are type fixing, then the ties shall be located in mortar joints between the units.

text: Fixing Ties; The ties shall be located at no less than 320 mm centres for stacks up to 600 mm wide.
paraphrase: If the fixing ties are for stacks up to 600 mm wide, then the ties shall be located at no less than 320 mm centres.

text: Fixing Ties; The ties shall be at no less than 160 mm centres for stacks wider than 600 mm.
paraphrase: If fixing ties are for stacks wider than 600 mm, then the ties shall be at no less than 160 mm centres.

text: 1.8.1 Brickwork; Brick chimney construction shall conform to the relevant sections of NZS 4210.
paraphrase: If the chimney's construction is brick, then the chimney's construction shall conform to NZS 4210.

text: 1.8.2 Concrete; Chimneys of reinforced concrete, shall comply with the relevant clauses of NZS 3109 for ordinary grade concrete.
paraphrase: If chimneys are reinforced concrete and the reinforced concrete is ordinary grade, then the chimney shall comply with NZS 3109.

text: 1.8.2 Chimney foundations of reinforced concrete shall comply with the relevant clauses of NZS 3109 for ordinary grade concrete.
paraphrase: If chimneys foundations are reinforced concrete and the reinforced concrete is ordinary grade, then the foundations shall comply with NZS 3109.

text: 1.8.2 Chimney hearth slabs of reinforced concrete shall comply with the relevant clauses of NZS 3109 for ordinary grade concrete.
paraphrase: If chimneys hearth slabs are reinforced concrete and the reinforced concrete is ordinary grade, then the slab shall comply with NZS 3109.

text: Pumice concrete units for use in precast chimneys shall: a) Have pumice aggregate which: i) is free of combustible and organic matter, and ii) has a maximum aggregate size of no greater than 19 mm, with at least 40% but not more than 60% of the aggregate retained by a 4.75 mm standard test sieve, and b) Have a mix ratio by volume of no more than five parts of mixed pumice aggregate to one part of cement, c) Have a compressive strength of no less than 7 MPa at 28 days when cured and tested in accordance with NZS 3112: Part 2, d) After adequate curing, be air dried and kept under cover during storage, transport and on the site, e) Be laid dry. (Work left unfinished should be protected from rain.) f) Be joined with mortar which complies with NZS 4210, and g) Have ducts filled with grout complying with NZS 4210.
paraphrase: If precast chimneys have pumice concrete units, then the pumice concrete shall have aggregate which is free of combustible material and organic matter, and the aggregate size shall be no greater than 19 mm, a sieve shall test the aggregate, with the sieve size of 4.75 mm with sieve remainder of at least 40 percent but not more than 60 percent, and the pummiceConcrete shall have a mix ratio by volume of no more than five parts of mixed pumice aggregate to one part of cement, and the pumice concrete shall have a compressive strength of no less than 7 MPa at 28 days when cured and tested in accordance with NZS 3112: Part 2, and the pumice concrete shall have protection curing, air drying and covering during storage, transport and on the site, and should be protected from rain, the mortar that connects the pumice concrete shall comply with NZS 4210, and the unit shall have ducts filled with grout complying with NZS 4210.

text: 1.8.4 Concrete masonry; Concrete masonry construction for chimney foundation walls shall conform to the relevant sections of NZS 4229.
paraphrase: If the chimney's foundation walls are constructed with concrete masonry, then the wall construction shall conform to NZS 4229.

text: Reinforcing used in chimneys is to conform to AS/NZS 4671.
paraphrase: If the chimney has reinforcing, then the reinforcing shall conform to NZS 4671.

text: Reinforcing used in chimneys shall: a) For brick, be embedded centrally in the thickness of the grout.
paraphrase: If reinforcing is used in brick chimneys, then the reinforcing shall be embedded centrally in the grout.

text: 1.8.5 Reinforcing steel; Reinforcing used in chimneys shall: For in-situ concrete, have cover to the steel in accordance with NZS 3109.
paraphrase: If reinforcing steel is used in in-situ concrete chimneys, then the reinforcing steel shall have cover in accordance with NZS 3109.

text: 1.8.5 Reinforcing steel; Reinforcing used in chimneys shall: For precast pumice concrete, be placed with grout in the preformed ducts in the units.
paraphrase: If reinforcing steel is used in precast pumice concrete chimneys, then the reinforcing steel shall be placed with grout in the preformed ducts in the units.

text: Chimney 1.8.6 Hot dip galvanising; Hot dip galvanising shall comply with AS/NZS 4680.
paraphrase: If the chimney has hot dip galvanising, then the hot dip galvanising shall comply with NZS 4680.

text: 1.7.8 Wall ties shall be constructed from either 4 mm diameter galvanised bar or 25 x 1.5 mm zinc coated steel strip capable of withstanding a load of 1.2 kN without elongating or shortening by more than 1.5 mm.
paraphrase: If wall ties exist, then the wall ties shall be either a bar with 4 mm diameter and galvanised or the wall ties shall be e a strip with 25 x 1.5 mm size out of zinc coated steel and the strip shall be capable of withstanding a load of 1.2 kN force without the strip elongating or shortening by more than 1.5 mm.

text: 1.7.9 Where zinc coating of components is required it shall be no less than 300 g/m2 in accordance with AS 1397.
paraphrase: If zinc coating of components is required, then the zinc coating shall be no less than 300 g/m2 in accordance with AS 1397.

text: 1.7.10 Nails used to fix straps to roof or ceiling framing shall be spaced at no less than 35 m in Radiata Pine.
paraphrase: If straps are fixed to a framing and the framing is part of the roof or ceiling and framing material is Radiata Pine, then the nails used for the fixture shall be spaced at no less than 35 m.

text: 1.7.10 Nails used to fix straps to roof or ceiling framing shall be spaced at no less than 70 mm in other timbers than Radiata Pine.
paraphrase: If straps are fixed to a framing and the framing is part of the roof or ceiling and framing material is other timbers than Radiata Pine, then the nails used for the fixture shall be spaced at no less than 70 mm.

text: 1.4.1 Disposal systems shall be located: To ensure that spillage from storage tanks or ponds can be safely contained.
paraphrase: If disposal systems exists, then disposal systems shall have a location that ensures spillage containment.

text: 1.4.1 Collection facilities shall be located: In areas with sufficient access for cleaning, clearing of blockages, and maintenance.
paraphrase: If collection facilities exists, then collection facilities shall have a location with access for cleaning, clearing of blockages and maintenance.

text: 1.4.1 Storage facilities shall be located: In areas with sufficient access for cleaning, clearing of blockages, and maintenance.
paraphrase: If storage facilities exists, then storage facilities shall have a location with access for cleaning, clearing of blockages and maintenance.

text: 1.4.1 Treatment facilities shall be located: In areas with sufficient access for cleaning, clearing of blockages, and maintenance.
paraphrase: If treatment facilities exists, then treatment facilities shall have a location with access for cleaning, clearing of blockages and maintenance.

text: 1.4.1 Disposal systems shall be located: In areas with sufficient access for cleaning, clearing of blockages, and maintenance.
paraphrase: If disposal systems exists, then disposal systems shall have a location with access for cleaning, clearing of blockages and maintenance.

text: 1.4.2 Storage tanks may be placed below ground provided: a) Precautions are taken to avoid: i) health or safety hazards, ii) corrosion that threatens the integrity of the tank or associated plant, and b) Tanks are designed to withstand the effects of associated loads.
paraphrase: If a storage tank is located below ground, then the storage tanks should avoid health and safety hazards, corrosion, and be designed to withstand associated loads.

text: 1.5.1 All materials in contact with industrial liquid waste shall be resistant to corrosion, chemical attack, and any abrasion or physical abuse that can be reasonably expected.
paraphrase: If a material is exposed to industrial liquid waste, then the material shall be resistant to corrosion, chemical attack, abrasion and physical abuse.

text: 1.5.2 Any corrosion allowance provided in the design of equipment handling liquid waste shall be adequate for the intended life of the facilities.
paraphrase: If the design of equipment provides corrosion allowance and the equipment is for liquid waste, then the corrosion allowance shall be adequate for the intended life of the facilities.

text: 1.6.1 Industrial liquid waste systems, storage and treatment tanks and piping systems shall be tested on completion to avoid contamination of any soil, ground water or waterways through run-off from washing-down, rain, accidental overflows or other causes.
paraphrase: If industrial liquid waste or piping systems, or storage or treatment tanks are completed, then the systems and tanks shall be tested to avoid soil contamination, groundwater contamination and waterway contamination.

text: 1.6.2 The area containing waste storage facilities shall be impervious and contained so as to avoid contamination of any soil, ground water or waterways through run-off from washing-down, rain, accidental overflows or other causes.
paraphrase: If waste storage areas exists, then waste storage areas shall be impervious and contained.

text: 1.6.3 Industrial liquid waste facilities shall be installed to avoid contamination of any potable water supply, as required by NZBC G12 Water Supplies.
paraphrase: If facilities are for industrial liquid waste, then the facilities shall be installed to avoid contamination of any potable water supply and comply with NZBC G12.

text: 1.7.1 Separate systems shall be provided to convey and store industrial liquid wastes that require different treatment and/or disposal methods.
paraphrase: If multiple industrial liquid wastes require different treatment or disposal methods, then for each industrial liquid wastes, the industrial liquid waste conveying system and storage system shall be separate.

text: 1.7.1 Separate systems shall be provided to convey and store industrial liquid wastes that require different treatment methods, or where the wastes are incompatible.
paraphrase: If multiple industrial liquid wastes require different treatment methods or the industrial liquid wastes are incompatible, then for each industrial liquid wastes, the industrial liquid waste conveying system and storage system shall be separate.

text: 1.8.1 Vehicle access areas for the collection of industrial liquid waste shall: a) Comply with NZBC D1 Access Routes.
paraphrase: If a vehicle access area is for industrial liquid waste collection, then the vehicle access area shall comply with NZBC D1.

text: 1.8.1 Vehicle access areas for the collection of industrial liquid waste shall: where possible, access layout shall provide sufficient space for vehicles to drive in and out of the facility without reversing or interference with other activities on the site.
paraphrase: If a vehicle access area is for industrial liquid waste collection and if possible, then the vehicle access area shall provide sufficient space for turning.

text: Where a drain consists of concrete, ceramic, vitrified clay or rubber ring jointed steel or uPVC, a flexible joint shall be installed within 225 mm of the outside wall of any access chamber or inspection chamber, but outside the line of the base (see Figures 11 and 12).
paraphrase: If a drain consists of concrete, ceramic, vitrified clay or rubber ring jointed steel or uPVC, then the drain shall have a flexible joint located within 225 mm of the outside wall of any access chamber or inspection chamber of the drain, but outside the line of the drain base.

text: Rodding points rather than inspection points are preferred in landscaped or sealed areas.
paraphrase: If an area is landscaped or sealed, then the access points are preferred to be rodding points.

text: These anti-scour blocks shall be: Keyed into the sides and floor of the trench by 150 mm.
paraphrase: If anti-scour blocks exist, then the anti-scour blocks shall have keying into the sides and floor of the trench with a keying depth of 150 mm.

text: 1.1.1 Sanitary facilities are required in occupied buildings.
paraphrase: If a building has occupancy, then the building shall have sanitary facilities.

text: 1.1.2 WC pans and basins are required in any building where people: a) live or are accommodated.
paraphrase: If the building activity is living or accomodation, then the building shall have wc pans and basins.

text: Structure Design 7.0 Glazing 7.1 NZS 4223.1 7.2 NZS 4223.2 7.3 NZS 4223.3.
paraphrase: If glazing is part of the structure, then the glazing's design shall comply with NZS 4223.1 7.2, NZS 4223.2 7.3, and NZS 4223.3.

text: Structure Design 8.0 Small Chimneys; See Acceptable Solution B1/AS3.
paraphrase: If the structure is a small chimney, then the chimney design is as per B1/AS3.

text: R-values for walls, roofs and ceilings shall be no less than: For light timber frame wall or other framed wall constructions with cavities, 1.5.
paraphrase: If wall type is light timber framing or framing with cavities, then the wall's R-values for walls shall be no less than 1.5.

text: R-values for walls, roofs and ceilings shall be no less than: For single skin normal weight masonry based wall construction without a cavity, 0.6.
paraphrase: If walls are made from masonry that is single skin and normal weight and the wall is without a cavity, then the wall's R-values for walls shall be no less than 0.6.

text: R-values for walls, roofs and ceilings shall be no less than: For solid timber wall systems no less than 60 mm thick, 0.6.
paraphrase: For solid timber wall systems no less than 60 mm thick, then the wall's R-values for walls shall be no less than 0.6.

text: R-values for walls, roofs and ceilings shall be no less than: For roof or ceilings of any construction, 1.5.
paraphrase: If roofs or ceilings exist, the R-values of the roofs and ceilings shall be no less than 1.5.

text: 1.1.1 This document describes the requirements to be satisfied by specific design for systems used for the collection, storage, treatment and disposal of industrial liquid waste.
paraphrase: If a system is used for the collection, storage, treatment or disposal of industrial liquid waste, then the system's spefic design shall comply with G14/VM1.

text: 1.9.1 Where unauthorised access to treatment facilities may be hazardous, security shall be provided by: a) Locating the facilities in a lockable enclosed space within a building.
paraphrase: If unauthorised access to treatment facilities may be hazardous, then the treatment facility shall be located in a lockable space within a building.

text: 1.8.1 Vehicle access areas for the collection of industrial liquid waste shall: Drain any spilled waste to a kerbed area sloped so that the waste does not collect under the vehicle, or drain in an uncontrolled manner to other areas of the plant.
paraphrase: If a vehicle access area is for industrial liquid waste collection, then the vehicle access area shall drain any spilled waste to a kerbed area.

text: 1.8.1 Vehicle access areas for the collection of industrial liquid waste shall: Any spilled waste shall not enter the sewage system unless the spilled waste is acceptable as a discharge to the sewer by the network utility operator.
paraphrase: If a vehicle access area is for industrial liquid waste collection and the network utility operator does not accept the discharge of the waste to the sewer, then spilled waste shall not enter the sewer.

text: 1.8.1 Vehicle access areas for the collection of industrial liquid waste shall: Any spilled waste shall: i) be contained on-site for subsequent removal, ii) not enter the surface water system.
paraphrase: If a vehicle access area is for industrial liquid waste collection and waste is spilled, then the spilled waste shall be contained and not enter the sewer.

text: 1.9.1 Where unauthorised access to storage facilities may be hazardous, security shall be provided by: a) Locating the facilities in a lockable enclosed space within a building.
paraphrase: If unauthorised access to storage facilities may be hazardous, then the storage facility shall be located in a lockable space within a building.

text: 1.9.1 Where unauthorised access to storage facilities may be hazardous, security shall be provided by: b) An external security fence with lockable gates if located in the open.
paraphrase: If unauthorised access to storage facilities may be hazardous and the storage facility is located outside, then the storage facility shall have an external security fence with lockable gates.

text: 2.0.1 Where the network utility operator accepts the discharge of industrial liquid waste to a sewer, the waste shall be conveyed in a plumbing and drainage disposal system complying with NZBC G13 Foul Water.
paraphrase: Where the network utility operator accepts the discharge of industrial liquid waste to a sewer, then the waste shall be conveyed in a disposal system for plumbing and drainage, which complies with NZBC G13.

text: 2.1.1 Screens, grit chambers, grease traps or similar appropriate equipment should be installed at the head of piping systems if suspended solids or material within the liquid waste might cause blockage of the piping system.
paraphrase: If liquid waste might cause blockage of the piping system, then the head of the piping system shall have screens, grit chambers, grease traps, or equipment similar to screens, grit chambers, grease traps.

text: 2.1.2 Wherever possible, piping systems shall convey industrial liquid waste using gravity flow.
paraphrase: If a piping system conveys industrial liquid waste and gravity flow is possible, then the piping system shall use gravity flow.

text: 2.0 Conveyance of industrial liquid waste 2.1.3 Gravity flow pipelines should have sufficient gradient to provide flow velocities that prevent the settlement of entrained solids and grit.
paraphrase: If a piping system method is gravity flow, then the piping system should have a gradient that provides flow velocities that prevent the settlement of entrained solids and grit.

text: 2.0 Conveyance of industrial liquid waste 2.3.2 Joints, fittings and valves – The number of joints, fittings and valves in the piping system shall be kept to a practical minimum.
paraphrase: If a piping system exists, then the piping system shall have the practical minimum number of joints, fittings and valves.

text: 2.3.3 Bends shall have a centreline radius of no less than 1.5 times the nominal pipe diameter.
paraphrase: If a pipe has a bend, then the bend's centreline radius shall be no less than 1.5 times the nominal diameter of the pipe.

text: 3.2.1 Free-standing tanks shall be secured against earthquake forces. The methods given in NZS 4219 are acceptable.
paraphrase: If a tank is free-standing, then the tank shall have seismic resistance. The tank's seismic resistance can be as described in NZS 4219.

text: 6.1 Water heaters 6.5.2 Energy cut-off devices shall be designed to: b) Disconnect the energy supply before the water temperature exceeds 95°C.
paraphrase: If a water heater has an energy cut-off device, then the energy cut-off device shall be designed to: b) Disconnect the energy supply before the waterHeater's water temperature exceeds 95 degC.

text: Boundary fences and other site development must not significantly hamper the flow of surface water from the site.
paraphrase: If site development exists, then the site development must not cause obstruction to the flow of surface water.

text: 2.2.1 Solid fuel burning domestic appliances weighing no more than 130 kg shall be supported on a 65 mm thick hearth slab that is: a) Reinforced with 665 mesh, or D10 rods at 300 mm centres each way, placed centrally in the slab thickness, b) Supported on a timber or concrete floor, or integral with a concrete floor. (The floor supporting the hearth slab shall comply with NZS 3604 or NZS 4229 as appropriate), and c) Comprised of ordinary grade concrete complying with the relevant clauses of NZS 3109.
paraphrase: If solid fuel burning domestic appliances are weighing no more than 130 kg, then the appliance shall be supported on a 65 mm thick hearth slab, and either the slab is reinforced with 665 sized mesh or D10 sized rods at 300 mm centres each way the of the slab, and the reinforcing is placed centrally in the slab thickness, and either the slab is supported on a timber or concrete floor complying with NZS 3604 or NZS 4229, or the slab is integral with a concrete floor, and the slab shall be comprised of ordinary grade concrete complying with the relevant clauses of NZS 3109.

text: 2.2.2 Hearth slabs on a timber floor shall be held in position by supporting members on all four sides of the hearth. These members shall each be held by four screws with a minimum shank diameter of 4.88 mm that penetrate the floor framing by 50 mm.
paraphrase: If hearth slabs are on a timber floor, then for each side of the slabs the slab side shall have support and the support has four screws. The screws shall have a minimum shank diameter of 4.88 mm that penetrate the floor framing by 50 mm.

text: 2.2.3 Hearth slabs on concrete floors shall be secured in position by four D10 starter rods. The rods shall be located in each corner of the hearth slab and they shall terminate each end with standard hooks complying with NZS 3109.
paraphrase: If hearth slabs are on concrete floors, then the slabs shall be fixed with four D10 starter rods. For each corner of the slab, the corner shall have a rod and the rods end shall have hooks complying with NZS 3109.

text: 2.2.4 Hearth slabs for solid fuel burning appliances shall comply with AS/NZS 2918.
paraphrase: If hearth slabs are for solid fuel burning appliances, then the slab shall comply with NZS 2918.

text: 1.1.2 Where waste is hazardous, the storage facilities shall also comply with NZBC F3 Hazardous Substances and Processes.
paraphrase: If a storage facility is for hazardous waste, then the storage facility shall comply with NZBC F3.

text: 1.4.1 Collection facilities shall be located: a) In areas that will not create health or safety hazards.
paraphrase: If collection facilities exists, then collection facilities shall have a location that will not cause health or safety hazards.

text: 1.4.1 Storage facilities shall be located: a) In areas that will not create health or safety hazards.
paraphrase: If storage facilities exists, then storage facilities shall have a location that will not create health or safety hazards.

text: 1.4.1 Treatment facilities shall be located: a) In areas that will not create health or safety hazards.
paraphrase: If treatment facilities exists, then treatment facilities shall have a location that will not create health or safety hazards.

text: 1.4.1 Disposal systems shall be located: a) In areas that will not create health or safety hazards.
paraphrase: If disposal systems exists, then disposal systems shall have a location that will not create health or safety hazards.

text: 1.4.1 Collection facilities shall be located: To ensure that spillage from storage tanks or ponds can be safely contained.
paraphrase: If collection facilities exists, then collection facilities shall have a location that ensures spillage containment.

text: 1.4.1 Storage facilities shall be located: To ensure that spillage from storage tanks or ponds can be safely contained.
paraphrase: If storage facilities exists, then storage facilities shall have a location that ensures spillage containment.

text: 1.4.1 Treatment facilities shall be located: To ensure that spillage from storage tanks or ponds can be safely contained.
paraphrase: If treatment facilities exists, then treatment facilities shall have a location that ensures spillage containment.

text: 6.6.3 The edge of the panel elevated above the roof plane is to be supported by hot dip galvanized steel or stainless steel angle struts which are: 40 x 40 x 3 mm angle for struts up to 2.4 m long.
paraphrase: If the panel is elevated and above the roof and angle struts are over 2.4 m long, then the edge of the paned is to be supported by hot dip galvanized steel angle struts or stainless steel angle struts which are: a) 40 mm width, 40 mm length, and 3 mm thickness.

text: The scope of this Acceptable Solution is limited to the materials, products and processes contained herein, for buildings within the scope of NZS 3604, and: a) Up to 3 storeys with a height measured from lowest ground level adjacent to the building to the highest point of the roof (except for chimneys, aerials and the like) of 10 m or less, and b) With floor plan area limited only by seismic and structural control joints, and c) External walls that are vertical, and roofs that are 60° or less above the horizontal.
paraphrase: If NZS 3604 applies to a building and the building has up to three storeys, and the building height in between the lowest ground level elevation adjacent to the building and the highest elevation of the roof excluding chimneys and aerials of 10 m or less, and the building's floor plan area limited by seismic control joints and structural control joints, and and the building's external walls are oriented vertical, and building roofs that are 60° or less slope, then E2/AS1 applies to the buildings materials, products and processes.

text: Where buildings are based on NZS 3604, but require specific engineering design input, the framing shall be of at least equivalent stiffness to the framing provisions of NZS 3604.
paraphrase: If buildings are based on NZS 3604a and the building engineering require specific design, then the building framing stiffness shall comply with NZS 3604.

text: Buildings with drained cavities and spread-of-flame requirements, as specified in NZBC C Clauses, are outside the scope of this Acceptable Solution. Cavities in such circumstances must be specifically designed for both weathertightness and spread of flame.
paraphrase: If a buildings has drained cavities and spread-of-flame requirements, as specified in NZBC C Clauses, then E2AS1 does not apply to that buidling. The drained cavities must have specific design for weathertightness and spread of flame.

text: Table 2 sets out the risk matrix that shall be used to define the risk score for a building within the scope of this Acceptable Solution. A risk score is calculated for each external face of the building. Claddings are then selected from Table 3 according to the risk scores.
paraphrase: If E2/AS1 applies to a building, then the risk matrix shall be as in E2/AS1 Table 2, and the for each exterior face the risk score shall be calculated according to risk matrix and the exterior face's claddings shall be according to the risk score and E2/AS1 Table 3.

text: Flashing materials shall take into account the following factors: a) The requirements of NZBC Clause B2 Durability, b) The environment where the building is located, c) The specific conditions of use, and d) Consideration of the surrounding materials.
paraphrase: If a flashing exists, then the flashing materials shall comply with NZBC Clause B2, and be according to the building environment, the conditions of use, surrounding materials.

text: Flashing materials shall be selected according to the relevant exposure conditions as defined in Table 20 to minimise corrosion.
paraphrase: If a flashing exists, then the flashing materials shall be according to the exposure in E2/AS1 Table 20.

text: 4.2.2 Surrounding materials; Uncoated metals shall not be used where carbon deposits or chemical contaminants may accumulate.
paraphrase: If the material has accumulation of carbon deposits or chemical contaminants, then the material shall not be metals that are uncoated.

text: uPVC flashings shall be a minimum of 0.75 mm thick. uPVC flashings shall comply with the requirements of the following Clauses of AS/NZS 4256: Part 2: a) Clause 9.2 Impact resistance, b) Clause 9.3 Tensile strength, and c)  Clause 9.4 Colourfastness and impact resistance following ultraviolet light exposure.
paraphrase: If flashings are made of uPVC, then the flashing shall be a minimum of 0.75 mm thick and comply with NZS 4256 Part 2 Clause 9.2, 9.3, and 9.4.

text: Aluminium flashings shall be a minimum thickness of 0.7 mm, and formed from 5000 series in accordance with AS/NZS 1734.
paraphrase: If flashings are aluminium, then the flashings shall be a minimum thickness of 0.7 mm, and aluminium grade shall be 5000 series and in accordance with NZS 1734.

text: Galvanized steel flashings shall: a) have a BMT of 0.55 mm minimum b) be grade G550, or G300 for rolled or crimped flashings c) be selected for corrosion protection according to the intended exposure zone as shown in Table 20.
paraphrase: If flashings are made of galvanized steel, then the flashing shall have a base metal thickness of 0.55 mm minimum. Either flashing shall be grade G550, or G300 for rolled or crimped flashings. The flashing's corrosion protection shall be according to the intended exposure zone as shown in E2/AS1 Table 20.

text: Aluminium-zinc-magnesium coated steel shall: a) have a BMT of 0.55 mm minimum b) be grade G550, or G300 for curved or crimped flashings c) be selected for corrosion protection according to the intended exposure zone as shown in Table 20.
paraphrase: If flashings are made of steel with aluminium-zinc-magnesium coating, then the flashing shall have a base metal thickness of 0.55 mm minimum. Either flashing shall be grade G550, or G300 for rolled or crimped flashings. The flashing's corrosion protection shall be according to the intended exposure zone as shown in E2/AS1 Table 20.

text: Zinc sheet flashings shall only be used in accordance with Tables 20, 21 and 22. Zinc sheet flashings shall be: a) A minimum thickness of 0.7 mm, and b) In compliance with BS EN 988.
paraphrase: If flashings are zinc sheet, then the flashings shall be in accordance with E2/AS1 Tables 20, 21 and 22. The flashings shall be a minimum thickness of 0.7 mm, and in compliance with BS EN 988.

text: Buildings with drained cavities and acoustic requirements, as specified in NZBC Clause G6, are outside the scope of this Acceptable Solution.
paraphrase: If a building has drained cavities and acoustic requirements, as specified in NZBC Clause G6, then E2/AS1 does not apply to the building.

text: Specific design for preventing the ingress of snow melt water is required when the open ground snow load Sg, as defined in NZS 3604, exceeds 1.0 kPa, and the roof is constructed in a way that is likely to cause a build-up of snow.
paraphrase: If the open ground snow load defined in NZS 3604 exceeds 1 kPa, and the roof construction can cause build-up of snow, then the roof shall have specific design for ingress prevention of snow melt water.

text: Buildings, components or junction details not included or shown in this Acceptable Solution require specific design.
paraphrase: If E2/AS1 does not include buildings, components or junction details, then the  buildings, components and junction details shall have specific design.

text: Cladding systems shall meet the requirements of NZBC E2.2 to E2.3.7, and the provisions of this Acceptable Solution are acceptable means of achieving this.
paraphrase: If caldding systems comply with E2/AS1, then the cladding systems complies with NZBC E2 2 to NZBC E2 3.7.

text: Materials used to construct the building envelope shall be: a) In accordance with the durability requirements of NZBC B2, b) Suitable for their end-use, location and environment as shown in Table 20, and c) Compatible with adjoining materials as shown in Table 21 and Table 22.
paraphrase: If a material is included in the building envelope, then the material durability shall be in accordance with NZBC B2, the material suitability shall include end-use, location and environment as shown in E2/AS1 Table 20, and the material compatibility with adjoining materials as shown in E2/AS1 Table 21 and Table 22.

text: All building products shall be considered as part of a system, even if the components of that system are provided from different sources.
paraphrase: If the building has products, then the products are considered as part of a system.

text: Materials used to construct the building envelope shall be designed as a complete cladding system rather than as separate items.
paraphrase: If the building envelope includes a material, the material shall be designed as a cladding system and the material shall be not designed as item.

text: Finish colours for flush-finished fibre cement sheet and EIFS shall have a reflectivity of 40% or more when measured in accordance with ASTM C1549.
paraphrase: If flush-finished fibre cement sheet or EIFS have finish colours, then the finish colour shall have a reflectivity of 40 percent or more when the reflectivity measurement is in accordance with ASTM C1549.

text: Maintenance shall be carried out as necessary (Rule 2.5.0.2) to achieve the required durability of materials, components and junctions.
paraphrase: If the buildings materials, components or junctions require durability, then the building shall have maintenance complying with E2AS1 Rule 2.5.0.2.

text: The extent and nature of necessary maintenance is dependent on the: a) Type of cladding or components used, b) Position of cladding or components on the building, c) Geographical location of the building, and d) Specific site conditions.
paraphrase: If the building has maintainance, then the extent and nature of the maintenance is dependent on the: a) Type of cladding or components, b) Position of cladding or components, c) location of the building, and d) site conditions.

text: Regular maintenance of a building will include: a) Washing exterior surfaces, b) Inspecting surfaces and junctions, and repairing or replacing items when necessary, in order to preserve the weathertightness of the building. c) Maintaining clearances between cladding and external ground or paving as per Paragraph 9.1.3. d) Maintaining minimum 35 mm clearances between roofing and membrane decking, and wall cladding above e) Maintaining finish coatings especially for stucco, EIFS and fibre cement claddings.
paraphrase: If maintenance of a building is type regular, then the maintenance tasks will include Washing exterior surfaces, and the maintenance tasks will include inspecting surfaces and junctions, and the maintenance tasks will include repairing or replacing items if they are not weathertight, and the maintenance tasks will include maintaining clearances between either cladding and external ground or cladding and paving as per E2/AS1 Paragraph 9.1.3, and maintaining minimum 35 mm clearances between roof and membrane decking, and roof and wall cladding, and maintaining finish coatings of claddings.

text: A risk assessment of the proposed design shall be carried out using a building envelope risk matrix. This allows the risks related to various features to be aggregated, resulting in a risk score for the design.
paraphrase: If design is proposed, then the design shall have a risk assessment using a building envelope risk matrix. The building envelope risk matrix allows risk aggregation for various features with the result being a risk score of the design.

text: Table 1 sets out the definitions of risk levels relating to the location and design features of the building.
paraphrase: If the building has a location or design feature, then the definitions of the risk level for the location and design feature are described in E2/AS1 Table 1.

text: 1.9.1 Where unauthorised access to treatment facilities may be hazardous, security shall be provided by: b) An external security fence with lockable gates if located in the open.
paraphrase: If unauthorised access to treatment facilities may be hazardous and the treatment facility is located outside, then the treatment facility shall have an external security fence with lockable gates.

text: Where the solar water heater stores potable water and is used as a pre-heater for an instantaneous water heater, either: a) the hot water storage tank connected to the solar collector must be fitted with supplementary heating and a controller operating to meet the conditions outlined in Paragraph 3.5.1, b) the instantaneous water heater must heat all water passing through it to not less than 70°C.
paraphrase: If the solar water heater has potable water storage and is used as a pre-heater for an instantaneous water heater, then either the hot water storage tank connected to the solar collector must be fitted with supplementary heating and a controller operating to meet the conditions outlined in G12/AS2 Paragraph 3.5.1, or the water passing through instantaneous water heater must be heated to not less than 70 degC.

text: 3.0 Solar Water Heater Requirements; For protection from freezing, collectors installed in climate zones 1 and 2 (as shown in Figure 1) must: pass the level 1 test described in AS/NZS 2712 Appendix E, or have an automatic drain-down system.
paraphrase: If the solar collectors are installed in climate zones 1 and 2, then the solar collector must either pass the level 1 test described in NZS 2712 Appendix E, or the solar collector must have an automatic drain-down system.

text: 3.0 Solar Water Heater Requirements; Collectors installed in climate zone 3 (as shown in Figure 1) must: a) pass the level 2 test described in AS/NZS 2712 Appendix E, or have an automatic drain-down system.
paraphrase: If solar collectors are installed in climate zone 3, then the solar collector must either pass the level 2 test described in NZS 2712 Appendix E, or solar collector must have an automatic drain-down system.

text: 5.1.2 A wetback water heater must have an open-vent connected to the: water tank, or wetback water heater flow pipe (see G12/AS1 Figure 5).
paraphrase: If a wetback water heater exists, the wetback water heater must have an open-vent connected either to the water tank, or to the flow pipe.

text: Joins of metal flashings shall have the following features: f) When using uncoated or coated lead flashings, maximum continuous lengths shall be 1300 mm for 17 kg or 1500 mm for 20 kg lead. Where the pitch of the flashing is greater than 15° at the join, the lap at the join shall be 100 mm minimum. Where the pitch of the flashing is 15° or less at the join, the lap at the join shall be 200 mm minimum and the flashing underneath the lap shall have a hook at the edge,.
