The sealant shall comply with: a) Type F, Class 20LM or 25LM of ISO 11600, or b) low modulus Type II Class A of Federal Specification TT-S-00230C.
paraphrase: If flashings are material metal and the flashing join has laps and E2/AS1 4.5.2.0.2.e.1 and 4.5.2.0.2.f.1 do not apply to the flashing, then the lap shall be sealed using a neutral cure silicone sealant and mechanical fasteners. The sealant shall comply with ISO 11600 Type F Class 20LM or ISO 11600 Type F 25LM or TT-S-00230C low modulus Type II Class A.

text: 4.6 Flashing overlaps and upstands; Overlaps and upstands to flashings shall be as specified in this paragraph and Table 7.
paraphrase: If flashings have laps or upstands, then the laps and upstands shall be as specified in E2/AS1 4.6 and E2/AS1 Table 7.

text: Flashing edges, with hooks, hems, kick-outs and bird's beaks shall be as required in Table 7 and Paragraph 4.5.1.
paraphrase: If flashing edges have hooks, hems, kick-outs or bird's beaks, then the flashing edge shall be as required in E2/AS1 Table 7 and Paragraph 4.5.1.

text: Where a turn-down to the cover flashing for profiled metal claddings is required, use: a) A soft edge flashing for corrugated profiles.
paraphrase: If cladding material is profiled metal, then the cladding has cover flashings, the flashing required a turn-down, and the profiled metal is corrugated, them the flashing shall have soft edges.

text: Where a turn-down to the cover flashing for profiled metal claddings is required, use: b) A notched turn-down or soft edge flashing for trapezoidal profiles with rib height not exceeding 30 mm and/or rib centres not exceeding 200 mm.
paraphrase: If cladding material is profiled metal, the cladding has cover flashings, the flashing required a turn-down, and the profiled metal is trapezoidal and either the profiled metal rib height is not exceeding 30 mm or profiled metal rib centres not exceeding 200 mm, then the turn-down shall be notched or flashing edges be soft.

text: Where a turn-down to the cover flashing for profiled metal claddings is required, use: c) A notched turn-down for trapezoidal profiles with rib height exceeding 30 mm and/or rib centres exceeding 200 mm.
paraphrase: If cladding material is profiled metal, the cladding has cover flashings, the flashing required a turn-down, and the profiled metal is trapezoidal and either the profiled metal rib height is exceeding 30 mm or profiled metal rib centres exceeding 200 mm, then the turn-down shall be notched.

text: Where a turn-down to the cover flashing for profiled metal claddings is required, use: d) A notched turn-down for trough profiles.
paraphrase: If cladding material is profiled metal, the cladding has cover flashings, the flashing required a turn-down, and the profiled metal is trough, then the turn-down shall be notched.

text: Apron flashing cover over metal roofing: Transverse flashing: The apron shall have: i) for notched turn-downs, a gap between the flashing and the pan of the roof cladding. The gap shall be a maximum of 5 mm.
paraphrase: If apron flashings are over metal roofing, and the flashings are transverse, and the flashing have notched turn-downs, then there shall be a gap between the flashing and the pan of the metal roofing cladding. The gap shall be a maximum of 5 mm.

text: Apron flashing; The apron shall have: ii) a minimum effective cover to roof cladding, excluding any soft edge or turn-down to the flashing, as shown in Table 7.
paraphrase: If flashings are type apron, then the flashing shall have a minimum effective cover to roof cladding, excluding any soft edge or turn-down to the flashing, as shown in E2/AS1 Table 7.

text: 4.0 Flashings 4.6.1.6 Window and door heads; a) Slopes and covers of flashings at window and door heads shall comply with Table 7.
paraphrase: If flashings are for window heads or door heads, then the slopes and covers of flashings shall comply with E2/AS1 Table 7.

text: 4.0 Flashings 4.6.1.6 Window and door heads; Overlap cover of cladding to the flashing upstand and clearance from the bottom of the cladding to top of head flashing slope shall be in accordance with Table 7.
paraphrase: If flashings are for window heads or door heads, then overlap cover between cladding and the flashing upstand and clearance betweem the bottom of the cladding and top of head flashing slope shall be in accordance with E2/AS1 Table 7.

text: 4.0 Flashings 4.6.1.7 Inter-storey junctions; a) Minimum slopes and covers of flashings shall be in accordance with Table 7.
paraphrase: If flashings are for inter-storey junctions, then the slopes and covers of flashings shall be in accordance with E2/AS1 Table 7.

text: 4.0 Flashings 4.6.1.7 Inter-storey junctions; Overlap cover of the cladding to the flashing upstand, and clearance from the bottom of the cladding to the top of the slope of the head flashing, shall be in accordance with Table 7.
paraphrase: If flashings are for inter-storey junctions, then overlap cover between cladding and the flashing upstand and clearance betweem the bottom of the cladding and top of head flashing slope shall be in accordance with E2/AS1 Table 7.

text: All roof-to-wall junctions shall be made weathertight by using an apron flashing as outlined in Paragraph 4.6.1.1, and shown in Figure 7, that: a) Provides a minimum lap under the wall cladding of 75 mm in accordance with Table 7.
paraphrase: If a junction is type roof-to-wall, then the junction shall be weathertight and have an apron flashing as outlined in E2/AS1 Paragraph 4.6.1.1, and shown in E2/AS1 Figure 7. The flashing provides a lap under the wall cladding of minimum size of 75 mm in accordance with E2/AS1 Table 7.

text: Where the roof finishes within the length of an adjacent wall, a kick-out or stopend as detailed in Figure 8B shall be provided to direct water out from the wall cladding onto the roof cladding and gutter.
paraphrase: If the roof is adjacent to a wall and the roof finishes within the length of the wall, then the roof shall have a kick-out or stopend as detailed in E2/AS1 Figure 8.b to direct water out from the wall cladding onto the roof cladding and gutter.

text: Gutters, barges and fascias: Where eaves gutters/spoutings, barges or fascias terminate against claddings, these shall be installed after the wall cladding, and after any protective finishes have been applied.
paraphrase: If the eaves has gutters, barges or fascias and the gutters, barges or fascias terminate against claddings, then the gutters, barges and fascias shall be installed after the wall cladding, and after any protective finishes have been applied.

text: Eaves gutters/spouting, barges and fascias shall terminate so as to leave a gap of 10 mm from the finished wall cladding as shown in Figure 8B.
paraphrase: If eaves have gutters, barges and fascias, then the gutters, barges and fascias termination shall include a gap of 10 mm to the wall cladding as shown in E2/AS1 Figure 8.b.

text: Eaves shall be enclosed by installing soffit linings direct fixed to framing and comprising minimum 4.5 mm fibre cement sheet, or 7 mm H3 plywood, with joints, fixings and finishes as shown in Paragraphs 9.7 and 9.8.
paraphrase: If eaves exist, then the eave shall have enclosing with soffit linings fixed to framing and the soffit linings shall be minimum 4.5 mm thick fibre cement sheet, or 7 mm thick H3 plywood, the soffit linings shall have joints, fixings and finishes as shown in E2/AS1 Paragraphs 9.7 and 9.8.

text: Soffit linings shall be finished to fascias, barges and wall claddings as outlined in Figure 8A generally, or Figure 114 for flush finished fibre cement. Wall underlays shall not be required behind soffit linings.
paraphrase: If soffit linings exist, then soffit linings shall be finished to fascias, barges and wall claddings, and either the Soffit linings finish shall be as outlined in E2/AS1 Figure 8.a and the soffit linings material is not flush finished fibre cement, or the Soffit linings finish shall be as outlined in E2/AS1 Figure 114 and the soffit linings material is flush finished fibre cement. There may be no wall underlays behind soffit linings.

text: Parapets require a drained cavity for claddings except for vertical corrugated steel as outlined in Table 3.
paraphrase: If parapets have claddings and the cladding material is not vertical corrugated steel, then the parapet shall have a drained cavity for the claddings.

text: Apron flashing cover over metal roofing: Parallel flashing: The apron shall: i) be dimensioned to suit the roof cladding profile,.
paraphrase: If apron flashings are over metal roofing, and the flashings are parallel, then the flashing shall be dimensioned to suit the metal roofing cladding profile.

text: Apron flashing cover over metal roofing: Parallel flashing: The apron shall: ii) for profiled metal roof cladding, cover at least two crests, (turned-up edge to full crest height constitutes a crest).
paraphrase: If apron flashings are over metal roofing, the flashings are parallel, and the metal roofing has profiled metal roof cladding, then the flashing shall cover at least two crests of the cladding.

text: Overlap with roof claddings: Apron flashing cover over metal roofing: Parallel flashing: The apron shall: iii) for profiled metal roof cladding, overhang flashing a minimum 10 mm clear of crest and maximum 5 mm clear of trough as shown in Figure 47.
paraphrase: If apron flashings are over metal roofing, the flashings are parallel, and the metal roofing has profiled metal roof cladding, then the flashing shall have a minimum 10 mm clearance to the cladding crest and maximum 5 mm clearance to the cladding trough as shown in E2/AS1 Figure 47.

text: 4.0 Flashings 4.6.1.2 Ridges and hips; a) For notched turn-downs of the flashing leave a gap between the flashing and the roof cladding. The gap shall be a maximum of 5 mm.
paraphrase: If flashings is for ridges or hips and the flashing has notched turn-downs, then the the flashing shall leave a gap between the flashing and the cladding. The gap size shall be a maximum of 5 mm.

text: 4.0 Flashings 4.6.1.2 Ridges and hips; b) There shall be a minimum effective cover to roof cladding, excluding any soft edge or turn-down to the flashing, in accordance with Table 7.
paraphrase: If flashings is for ridges or hips and the flashing, then there shall be a minimum effective cover to the cladding, excluding any soft edge or turn-down to the flashing, in accordance with E2/AS1 Table 7.

text: 4.0 Flashings 4.6.1.3 Change in metal roof pitches; a) There shall be a minimum effective lap under roof cladding in accordance with Table 7, with a hem at upper edge.
paraphrase: If flashings are for changed metal roofing pitches, then there shall be a minimum effective lap under the cladding, and the lap shall be in accordance with E2/AS1 Table 7, have a hem at the upper edge.

text: The apron cover over the roof cladding shall be in accordance with Table 7.
paraphrase: If the apron cover is over the roof cladding, then the cover shall be in accordance with E2/AS1 Table 7.

text: 4.0 Flashings 4.6.1.4 Roof- or deck-to-wall junctions; a) There shall be a total minimum upstand height of 110 mm, in accordance with Table 7, comprising a minimum: i) overlap cover of cladding to the flashing upstand of 75 mm, and ii) 35 mm clearance from bottom of the wall cladding to roof cladding or finished deck material.
paraphrase: If flashings are for Roof- or deck-to-wall junctions, then the flashing shall have a minimum upstand height of 110 mm, in accordance with E2/AS1 Table 7. The upstand height included a overlap cover of cladding to the flashing upstand of minimum 75 mm, and the upstand height includes clearance from bottom of the wall cladding to either roof cladding or finished deck material, and the clearnace shall be of minimum 35 mm.

text: 4.0 Flashings 4.6.1.5 Barges; a) There shall be a minimum effective overlap to the barge board, excluding the drip edge to the flashing, in accordance with Table 7.
paraphrase: If the flashing type is barge, then there shall be a minimum effective overlap to the barge board, excluding the drip edge to the flashing, in accordance with E2/AS1 Table 7.

text: 4.0 Flashings 4.6.1.5 Barges; The apron cover over the roof cladding shall be as for Paragraph 4.6.1.1.
paraphrase: If the flashing type is barge, then the apron cover over the roof cladding shall be as for E2/AS1 Paragraph 4.6.1.1.

text: Flexible flashing tape shall comply with Parts 3.2 and 4 of ICBO Acceptance Criteria AC148, shall be compatible with adjacent building wall underlay or roof underlay, and be used only in fully concealed applications.
paraphrase: If flashing tape is flexible, then the flashing tape shall comply with ICBO AC148 Parts 3.2 and 4, the flashing tape shall be compatible with adjacent building wall underlay or roof underlay, and the flashing tape shall be used only in fully concealed applications.

text: Exposed flashings such as barge and ridge flashings are to be fixed along both edges.
paraphrase: If flashings type is exposed barge and ridge, then the flashing shall have a fixture for each edge with location at the edge.

text: All flashings shall have expansion joints where required in Paragraph 4.5.2 to provide for thermal expansion.
paraphrase: If flashings require expansion joints in E2/AS1 Paragraph 4.5.2, then the flashing shall have expansion joints for thermal expansion.

text: Flashings are required to shed or divert water at sensitive areas of the building cladding. These include at: a) The building periphery, except where gutters are present, b) Changes of direction in cladding materials, c) Intersections between cladding materials or with other buildings, and d) Roof or wall penetrations, including windows, doors and other penetrations.
paraphrase: If the building cladding has either a sensitive areas or the cladding area is the building periphery, and no gutters are in the cladding area, or the cladding area's material has changes of direction, or the cladding area has intersections between cladding materials or to other buildings, or the cladding area has penetrations, windows or doors, then the cladding area shall have flashings to shed water or divert water.

text: Exposed bottom edges of flashings shall be folded to a kick-out or a bird's beak as shown in Figure 5.
paraphrase: If the bottom edges of flashings is eposed, then the bottom edge shall be a kick-out or a bird's beak and the bottome edge shall be as shown in E2/AS1 Figure 5.

text: For Low, Medium, High and Very High wind zones, flashing upstands shall have either: 1) A hem or hook to Figure 5, with upstand dimensions as shown throughout the document, or 2) No hooks or hems, and flashing upstand dimensions increased by 25 mm beyond those shown.
paraphrase: If wind zones types are low, Medium, High or Very High and the flashing has upstands, then either the upstand shall have a hem or hook to E2/AS1 Figure 5 with upstand dimensions as shown in E2/AS1, or the upstands shall have no hooks or hems, and flashing upstand dimensions shall be 25 mm greater than the values shown in E2/AS1.

text: For Extra High wind zones, hooks and hems shall be used, and flashing upstand dimensions increased by 25 mm beyond those shown in Table 7 or elsewhere in the document.
paraphrase: If the wind zone type is extra high and the flashing has an upstand, then the upstand shall have hooks and hems, and the upstand dimensions shall be 25 mm greater than the values shown in E2/AS1 Table 7 and E2/AS1.

text: Joins of metal flashings shall have the following features: a) Rivets used for joining and sealing laps shall be spaced at a maximum of 50 mm centres, and be: i) compatible with the flashing material as per Table 21 and Table 22, and ii) sealed against moisture, or iii) of a sealing type or blind rivet,.
paraphrase: If flashings are material metal and have joins with rivets to join laps and seal laps, then the rivets shall be spaced at a maximum of 50 mm centres, and there shall be compatibility between rivet and flashing material as per E2/AS1 Table 21 and Table 22, and the rivet shall either have sealing against moisture or be of type sealing or blind.

text: Joins of metal flashings shall have the following features: b) Expansion joints shall be provided for joined flashings with a combined length exceeding: i) 12 metres for light coloured steel and stainless steel. 8 metres for dark coloured steel, ii) 8 metres for copper, iii) 8 metres for aluminium.
paraphrase: If metal multiple flashings are joined, then either the flashings shall have expansion joints and the sum of the flashing lengths exceed 12 metres and the flashings shall be light coloured steel or stainless steel, or the sum of the flashing lengths shall not exceed 12 metres and the flashings shall be light coloured steel or stainless steel, or the flashings shall have expansion joints and the sum of the flashing lengths exceed 8 metres and the flashings shall be dark coloured steel, copper or aluminium, or the sum of the flashing lengths shall not exceed 8 metres and the flashings is dark coloured steel, copper or aluminium.

text: Floor waste pipes may be combined to form a floor waste stack and shall have a diameter not less than that given in Table 3 (see Figure 3).
paraphrase: If the floor waste has pipes, then the pipes may be combined to form a floor waste stack and shall have a diameter not less than the values given in G13/AS1 Table 3.

text: 1.4 Calculating occupant loads 1.4.3 Duplication shall be avoided by: Not including an occupant load for exitways, or for the occupant load determined for areas such as lift lobbies or sanitary facilities that are used intermittently by people already counted elsewhere in the building.
paraphrase: If a space has people but is either an exitway or used intermittently, then the space shall have no occupant load.

text: 8.0 Roof; Hips, ridges, valleys and barges shall be made weathertight by using flashings and seals as shown in Figure 23 to Figure 28.
paraphrase: If the roof component is a hip, ridge, valley or barge, then the component shall be made weathertight by using flashings and seals, the flashings and seals shall be as shown in E2/AS1 Figure 23 to Figure 28.

text: Steel for the manufacture of pressed metal tile and flashing systems shall: a) have a base metal thickness (BMT) of 0.39 mm minimum, b) be grade G300 or G250, c) be selected for corrosion protection according to the intended exposure zone as shown in Table 20.
paraphrase: If the material of pressed metal tile and flashing is steel, then the steel shall have a minimum base metal thickness of 0.39 mm, the stell shall be grade G300 or G250, and the steel shall be chosen for corrosion protection based on the exposure zone as shown in E2/AS1 Table 20.

text: 8.3 Pressed Metal Tiles; The minimum roof pitches for metal tiles where rafter length does not exceed 12 m shall be limited to: a) 12° (1:4.75) for profiles resembling standard profiles, and b) 15° (1:3.75) for profiles resembling shingle or shake profiles.
paraphrase: If the roof has pressed metal tiles and a rafter, and the rafter length does not exceed 12 m, then the roof pitches shall be either minimum 12 deg and the pressed metal tile's profiles similar to standard profiles or the roof pitches shall be minimum 15 deg and the pressed metal tile's profiles similar to shingle or shake profiles.

text: Pressed metal tiles shall be fixed as shown in Figure 33, with: a) 50 x 2.8 mm hot-dipped galvanized painted flat-head annular-grooved nails.
paraphrase: If pressed metal tiles exist, then the pressed metal tiles shall be fixed as shown in E2/AS1 Figure 33, with nails type flat-head annular-grooved, and the nails are hot-dipped galvanized and painted, and the nails are dimension 50 x 2.8 mm.

text: 8.3 Pressed Metal Tiles; Metal flashings are generally supplied by the metal tile manufacturer, and shall comply with Paragraph 8.3.4.2 and Table 7, unless specifically shown otherwise in the details.
paraphrase: If the roof type is pressed metal tile and the roof has flashings with material metal, then the manufacturer of the pressed metal tiles supplies the flashings. The flashings shall comply with E2/AS1 Paragraph 8.3.4.2 and Table 7.

text: This Acceptable Solution is limited to the following types of profiled metal roof cladding: a) Profiled as outlined in Paragraph 8.4.4, b) Valley gutters that do not change direction in plan, c) Not curved, and d) With sheets no more than 18 metres long.
paraphrase: If roof cladding is profiled metal and either the profiled metal is as outlined in E2/AS1 Paragraph 8.4.4, or the profiled metal has valley gutters that do not change direction in plan, or the profiled metal is not curved, or the profiled metal is no more than 18 metres long, then E2/AS1 applies to the roof cladding.

text: Metal roof cladding and flashings shall be selected according to the exposure conditions in Table 20 as defined in: a) NZS 3604, or b) AS/NZS 2728.
paraphrase: If roof cladding or flashings are metal, then the metal shall be according to the exposure conditions in E2/AS1 Table 20 and the exposure condition is defined in NZS 3604, or NZS 2728.

text: 8.4 Profiled Metal Roof Cladding; Materials for the manufacture of profiled steel roof cladding shall: a) have a BMT of 0.4 mm minimum b) be grade G550, or G300 for rolled, crimped, or trough profile roofing c) be selected for corrosion protection according to the intended exposure zone as shown in Table 20.
paraphrase: If the material of profiled metal roof claddings is steel, then the steel shall have a base metal thickness of 0.4 mm minimum. The steel shall be grade G550 and not for rolled, crimped, or trough profile roof cladding, or the steel shall be grade G300 and rolled, crimped, or trough profile roof cladding. The steel shall be selected for corrosion protection according to the intended exposure zone as shown in E2/AS1 Table 20.

text: 8.4 Profiled Metal Roof Cladding; Fixings shall: a) Be fixed through crests, b) Penetrate purlins by a minimum of 40 mm for nail fixings and 30 mm for screw fixings, c) Include sealing washers of: i) neoprene (having a carbon black content of 15% or less by weight).
paraphrase: If the profile of Profiled Metal Roof Cladding has a fixing, then the fixings shall be through the crests of the roof cladding, the fixings shall penetrate purlins and either the fixings is a nail and the penetration is 40 mm or the fixing is a screw and the penetration is 30 mm, and the fixing shall include sealing washers of  neoprene and the sealing washer shall have a carbon black content of 15 percent or less.

text: 8.4 Profiled Metal Roof Cladding; Clip fixings for trough profiles and spans as shown in Table 13 shall be as shown in Figure 40, and shall: a) Have a minimum BMT of 0.9 mm b) Be a minimum width of 30 mm c) Be made from a material compatible with the cladding, refer to Tables 20 and 21 d) Have clips fastened with a minimum of two 10-gauge by 30 mm waferhead hot-dipped galvanised screws which comply with Class 3 of AS 3566: Part 2.
paraphrase: If the Profiled Metal Roof Cladding has clip fixings and the roof cladding profile is trough and the roof cladding span is as shown in E2/AS1 Table 13, then the fixing shall be as shown in E2/AS1 Figure 40, and the fixing shall have a minimum base metal thickness of 0.9 mm, and the fixing shall be a minimum width of 30 mm, and the fixing shall be a material compatible with the roof cladding, for the fixing material refer to E2/AS1 Tables 20 and 21, and the fixing shall have clips fastened with a minimum of two screws, the screws are 10-gauge size and 30 mm length waferhead hot-dipped galvanised and the screws comply with Class 3 of AS 3566: Part 2.

text: 8.4.10 Allowance for expansion of corrugated and trapezoidal roof cladding; Where Table 16 requires profiled washers, allowance shall be made for expansion by: a) Fixing the top 50% (closest to the ridge) with conventional fixings, and b) Fixing the lower 50% with sealing washers fixed over profiled washers as shown in Figure 39, and: i) using oversized holes, and ii) positioning fixing in centre of hole.
paraphrase: If roof claddings are corrugated or trapezoidal and the roof claddings have profiled washers  required in E2/AS1 Table 16, then the roof cladding shall have expansion allowed by having fixings and the roof cladding's top 50 percent shall have conventional fixings, and the roof cladding's bottom 50 percent shall have sealing washer fixings over profiled washers and the sealing wahsers as shown in E2/AS1 Figure 39, and the roof cladding penetrations shall be oversized and the fixing located in the center of the penetration.

text: The roofing shall be flashed at all boundaries to comply with the following: a) At edges discharging to gutters with eaves flashings where required in Figure 45(a) b) Soft edge to cover flashings complying with Paragraph 4.6. Refer to Figure 41 for example of use and Tables 21 and 22.c) Notched turn-downs to cover flashings shall comply with Paragraph 4.6. Refer to Figure 42 for example of use. d) Materials for flashings shall be compatible with the roof cladding material as per Table 21 and Table 22, and shall be in accordance with Paragraph 4.3. e) Provide expansion joints in accordance with Paragraph 4.5.2.
paraphrase: If a roof exists, then the roof boundaries shall have flashings and a) At edges discharging to gutters with eaves flashings where required in E2/AS1 Figure 45.a. The flashing shall have soft edge as cover, and the soft edge shall comply with E2/AS1 Paragraph 4.6. The flashing shall have notched turn-downs as cover, and the notched turn-downs shall comply with E2/AS1 Paragraph 4.6. Materials for flashings shall be compatible with the roof cladding material as per E2/AS1 Table 21 and Table 22 and Paragraph 4.3. The flashing shall have expansion joints in accordance with E2/AS1 Paragraph 4.5.2.

text: Where end-laps are required in flashings, form these as shown in Figure 6 and, before joining the two parts, apply an 8 mm diameter bead of neutral cure sealant complying with: i) Type F, Class 20LM or 25LM of ISO 11600, or ii) low modulus Type II Class A of Federal Specification TT-S-00230C.
paraphrase: If end-laps are required in flashings, then the end-lap shall be as shown in E2/AS1 Figure 6 and, before joining the end-lap and flashing, apply an 8 mm diameter bead of neutral cure sealant and the sealant complying with ISO 11600 Class 20LM Type F or ISO 11600 Class 25LM Type F, or TT-S-00230C Class A low modulus Type II.

text: Preformed compressible seals shall not be used at the eaves.
paraphrase: If eaves exist, then the eave shall not have preformed compressible seals.

text: Valley gutters shall be in accordance with catchment areas shown in Table 8, and as shown in Figure 51 and Paragraph 8.1.6.2.
paraphrase: If gutters are valley gutters, then the gutter shall be in accordance with catchment areas shown in E2/AS1 Table 8, and the gutter shall be as shown in E2/AS1 Figure 51 and Paragraph 8.1.6.2.

text: 8.4 Profiled Metal Roof Cladding; The edge of roofing penetrations over 200 mm wide shall be supported in either direction with additional framing as shown in Figure 21.
paraphrase: If profiled metal roof cladings have penetrations and the penetration is over 200 mm wide, then the edge of the penetration shall have for each direction framing as support, the framing shall be as shown in E2/AS1 Figure 21.

text: This Acceptable Solution is limited to membranes composed of butyl or EPDM installed over plywood substrates for: a) Roofs with a minimum fall of 2° (1:30), b) Decks with: i) a minimum fall of 1.5° (1:40), ii) a maximum area of 40 m2, iii) no steps in level within deck area except into gutters, iv) no integral roof gardens, and v) no downpipe direct discharge to deck, c) Internal gutters with a minimum fall of 1 in 100, with no cross seams in the gutters, and d) Decks with removable raised surfaces to give level access as shown in Figure 17A.
paraphrase: If membranes are material butyl or EPDM installed over plywood substrates and either the membrane is for a roof with a minimum fall of 2 deg, or the membrane is for decks with a minimum fall of 1.5 deg and the deck has a maximum area of 40 m2 and the deck area has no steps in level except into gutters and the deck has no integral roof gardens and no downpipe direct discharge to the deck, or the membranes are for internal gutters with a minimum fall of 1 in 100 and there are no cross seams in the gutters, or the membrane is for decks with removable raised surfaces to give level access as shown in E2/AS1 Figure 17.a, then E2/AS1 does apply to the membrane.

text: 8.5 Membrane Roofs and Decks; The application of directly applied wearing or decorative surfaces to membranes is not covered in this Acceptable Solution.
paraphrase: If membranes are for roofs or decks and the application of wearing or decorative surfaces is to the membrane, then E2/AS1 does not apply to the application.

text: Closed-in construction spaces under membrane roofs and decks require adequate ventilation to prevent the accumulation of moisture under the membrane.
paraphrase: If closed-in construction spaces are under membrane roofs and decks, then the space shall have ventilation to prevent the accumulation of moisture.

text: Membranes installed over plywood substrates; Plywood shall be: a) A minimum of 17 mm complying with AS/NZS 2269, b) At least CD Grade Structural plywood with the sanded C face upwards, and c) H3 with treatment type compatible with membrane and adhesives used.
paraphrase: If membranes are over plywood substrates, then the plywood shall be a minimum of 17 mm thick complying with NZS 2269, the plywood shall be at least CD grade with the sanded C face upwards, and the plywood shall have H3 treatment compatible with membrane and adhesives used.

text: Plywood substrates shall be fixed according to the following requirements: a) Panels shall be laid with staggered joints (brick bond), b) Panels shall be laid with the face grain at right angles to the main supports, c) Supports in b) shall be at 400 mm maximum centres, d) The edge of sheets shall be supported with dwangs or framing.
paraphrase: If substrates are from plywood, then the substrate shall substrate panels shall be arranged with staggered joints or brick bond, Panels shall be laid with the face grain at right angles to the main supports, and the supports shall be maximum located at 400 mm centres, and the edge of sheets shall have dwangs or framing.

text: Membrane roof; All control joints in the substrate shall be accommodated in the membrane roof design.
paraphrase: If the roof is a membrane roof and the membrane is above the substrate and the control joints is in the substrate, then the roof design shall include the control joint.

text: The design of control joints for membrane roofing is subject to specific design and is outside the scope of this Acceptable Solution.
paraphrase: If the control joint is for a membrane roof, then the control joint shall have specific design and E2/AS1 does not apply to the control joint.

text: 9.0 Wall Claddings; 9.1.3 Bottom of cladding; Clearances shall be measured to: a) The finished plane of any adjacent horizontal surface.
paraphrase: If the bottom of the wall cladding has a clearance, then the clearances shall be measured to the finished plane of any adjacent horizontal surface.

text: 9.0 Wall Claddings 9.1.3.1 Concrete slabs; Slab levels shall be set to allow reinstatement of final landscaped ground levels as outlined in Figure 65 and Table 18.
paraphrase: If the concrete slab is adjacent to the wall cladding, then the slab's elevation shall be above finished ground levels as outlined in E2/AS1 Figure 65 and Table 18.

text: The height of the floor slab above finished ground level shall be in accordance with Figure 73D and as shown in Table 18.
paraphrase: If a floor slab exists, then the height of the floor slab above finished ground level shall be in accordance with E2/AS1 Figure 73.d and Table 18.

text: 9.1.3.3 Bottom of wall claddings for concrete ground slabs (except masonry veneer); At concrete slab level, the base of the cladding system shall be as shown in Table 18, and: a) Finish a minimum of: i) 100 mm above a paved surface, or ii) 175 mm above finished unpaved surface, b) Overlap the concrete slab by 50 mm, and c) Be offset horizontally by a minimum of 6 mm for direct fixed claddings to prevent capillary action.
paraphrase: If wall claddings are not masonry veneer and the concrete ground slab adjoins the wall cladding, then the bottom of the wall cladding shall be as shown in E2/AS1 Table 18, and either the wall cladding bottom is at a minimum of 100 mm above a paved surface, or the wall cladding bottom is at a minimum of 175 mm above finished unpaved surface, and the wall cladding bottom overlaps the concrete slab by 50 mm size, and the wall cladding bottom shall be either offset horizontally by a minimum of 6 mm size for direct fixed claddings to prevent capillary action, or the wallcladding shall be not direct fixed.

text: 9.1.3.5 Bottom of wall claddings for timber floor framing; At ground floor level, the base of the cladding system shall: a) Overlap the timber floor structure by 50 mm minimum, and b) For walls with direct fixed claddings, be offset horizontally from a concrete foundation wall by a minimum of 6 mm c) Have no direct connection between sub-floor spaces and drained cavities.
paraphrase: If timber floor framing adjoins the wall cladding and the floor is at ground level, then the wall cladding bottom overlaps the floor by 50 mm size, and the wall cladding bottom shall be either offset horizontally from a concrete foundation wall by a minimum of 6 mm size for direct fixed wall claddings, or the wallcladding shall be not direct fixed, and the wall cladding's drained cavities shall have no direct connection to sub-floor spaces.

text: This Acceptable Solution requires external walls to have barriers to airflow.
paraphrase: If a wall is external, then the wall shall have barriers to airflow.

text: Barrier to airflow for external walls shall be in form of: a) Interior linings with all joints stopped for wind zones up to Very High, or b) Rigid underlays (and drained cavities) for buildings in Extra High wind zones - refer to Paragraph 9.1.7.2 c) Where walls are not lined, such as attic spaces at gable ends, an air barrier complying with Table 23, fixed to framing prior to fixing cladding or cavity battens d) For attached garages, underlays to Paragraph 9.1.3.4.
paraphrase: If an external wall has a barrier against airflow, then either the barrier shall be in form of interior linings with all joints stopped for buildings in wind zones up to Very High, or the barrier shall be by rigid underlays and drained cavities for buildings in Extra High wind zones - refer to E2/AS1 Paragraph 9.1.7.2, or the walls are not lined and the barrier shall be an air barrier complying with E2/AS1 Table 23, fixed to framing prior to claddings or cavity battens, or if the wall is part of an attached garages, the barrier shall be by underlays to Paragraph 9.1.3.4.

text: 9.1.5 Wall underlays to wall openings; Prior to window or door installation: a) Flexible wall underlay shall be cut and dressed into all sides of openings as per Figure 72A and B,.
paraphrase: If the wall has an opening and the opening type is window or door, then all sides of openings shall have underlays and the underlays shall be for walls and shall be flexible and as per E2/AS1 Figure 72.a and Figure 72.b, and the undlay installation shall be before the installation of the opening.

text: 9.0 Wall claddings; Where a drained cavity is required, it shall: a) Be installed over a wall underlay, either flexible or rigid, that: i) complies with Table 23, and ii) is fixed to wall framing, b) Be formed using vertical cavity battens, c) Restrict air movement between the drained cavity and: i) floor, wall and roof framing, ii) attic roof space, and iii) subfloor space, d) Be drained and open to the exterior at the bottom of cavities, e) Use vermin-proofing at the cavity base as per Paragraph 9.1.8.3 and Figure 66, f) Use cavity spacers as shown in Figure 67, where fixing is required between cavity battens. Alternative cavity spacers to those described in Paragraph 9.1.8.2 are permitted. Refer to Paragraph 9.1.8.4 f).
paraphrase: If the wall cladding requires a drained cavity, then the drained cavity shall be installed over a wall underlay, the underlay shall beeither flexible or rigid, and the underly complies with E2/AS1 Table 23, and the underlay is fixed to wall framing, the drained cavity shall be formed using vertical cavity battens. There shall be air movement restriction between the drained cavity and floor framing, drained cavity and wall framing, drained cavity and roof framing, drained cavity and attic roof space, and drained cavity and subfloor space. The bottom of drained cavities shall have drainage and openings. Use vermin-proofing at the cavity base as per E2/AS1 Paragraph 9.1.8.3 and Figure 66. Either there is fixing in between cavity battens and the cavity battens shall have cavity spacers as shown in E2/AS1 Figure 67 and either E2/AS1 Paragraph 9.1.8.2 or Pargraph 9.1.8.4, or no fixing is in between cavity battens and the cavity

text: 9.0 Wall claddings; This Acceptable Solution is limited to masonry veneer cladding attached to timber wall framing outlined in NZS 3604. Masonry veneer is either: a) Clay brick, or b) Concrete brick or block.
paraphrase: If the wall cladding is masonry veneer attached to timber wall framing outlined in NZS 3604 and the masonry veneer tyep is either Clay brick, or Concrete brick or concrete block, then E2/AS1 applies to the wall cladding.

text: 9.0 Wall claddings; Masonry veneer shall be attached to wall framing by wall ties. Wall ties and their spacings and embedment shall be in accordance with the requirements of NZS 4210 and Tables 18A, 18B and 18C. Screw fixings shall be minimum 12 gauge, 35 mm long hex washer face, galvanised or stainless steel to suit the ties required under Table 18C.
paraphrase: If wall claddings are masonry veneer, then the wall cladding shall be connected to wall framing by wall ties. Wall ties and their spacings and embedment shall be in accordance with NZS 4210 and E2/AS1 Tables 18.a, 18.b and 18.c. Screw fixings for the wall ties shall be minimum size 12 gauge, 35 mm long hex washer face, galvanised or stainless steel.

text: 9.0 Wall Claddings; 9.7 Fibre Cement Sheet; Install sheets with: Paint seals to all sheet edges and cut edges, including 100 mm across back face from each edge.
paraphrase: If the wall cladding is type fibre cement sheets, then the sheets edges shall have paint seals and the back face adjacent to the edge shall have paint for 100 mm width.

text: Where the tops to enclosed balustrades are formed using EIFS, they shall have a minimum fall of 10° (1:6), and be wrapped as shown in Figure 129 and 130, with a liquid waterproofing membrane approved by the supplier. The EIFS system shall be fully protected by the coating, and shall comply with the requirements of AS/NZS 4858 Table 8, Parts (a) to (e), except that bleach and detergent immersion set out in Appendix A1 shall not be required.
paraphrase: If the tops to enclosed balustrades are material EIFS, then the top of the balustrade shall have a minimum fall of 10 deg, and be wrapped as shown in E2/AS1 Figure 129 and E2/AS1 Figure 130, with a liquid waterproofing membrane approved by the supplier. The EIFS system shall be fully protected by the membrane, and shall comply with the requirements of NZS 4858 Table 8.a to NZS 4858 Table 8.e. The EIFS system may exclude bleach and detergent immersion described in NZS 4858 Appendix A1.

text: Parapets shall be constructed as shown in Figure 10, and shall comply with the following requirements: a) Timber for framing and cavity battens shall comply with B2/AS1, b) Sloped packers under cappings shall be polystyrene or timber treated to B2/AS1, or minimum 9 mm H3 plywood on packers, and c) Framing shall be fully enclosed with wall underlay or roof underlay, in accordance with Table 23 for the specific cladding. d) claddings shall be installed over a cavity in accordance with Paragraph 9.1.8.
paraphrase: If a parapet exists, then the parapets shall be constructed as shown in E2/AS1 Figure 10. a) The timber used in the parapet's framing and cavity battens shall comply with B2/AS1 b) Sloped packers under parapet cappings shall be polystyrene, timber or H3 plywood. Polystyrene and timber shall be treated to B2/AS1, and H3 plywood shall be minimum 9 mm thick. c) Framing shall be fully enclosed with wall underlay or roof underlay, in accordance with E2/AS1 Table 23. d) Claddings shall be installed over a cavity in accordance with E2/AS1 Paragraph 9.1.8.

text: Parapets shall be capped with metal, butyl or EPDM membrane. Cappings shall comply with the requirements of Paragraph 4.0.
paraphrase: If parapets have cappings, then the capping material shall be metal, butyl or EPDM membrane. Cappings shall comply with E2/AS1 Paragraph 4.0.

text: Metal cappings installed over parapets and enclosed balustrades, shall be as outlined in Paragraphs 6.0 and 7.4, and comply with the following requirements: a) Tops of cappings shall be free of any penetrations, b) Slope of top shall be 5° (1:12) minimum, c) The cover at the sides of the capping shall be in accordance with Table 7, d) All cappings shall have drip edges. e) Cappings shall be separated from underlying timber by roof underlay as shown in Figure 10.
paraphrase: If metal cappings are installed over parapets or enclosed balustrades, then the capping shall be as outlined in E2/AS1 Paragraphs 6.0 and 7.4, and the top of cappings shall be free of penetrations, and the slope of the top of the capping shall be 5 deg minimum, and the cover at the sides of the capping shall be in accordance with E2/AS1 Table 7, and the cappings shall have drip edges. The details shown in E2/AS1 Figure 5 are acceptable minimum drip edges for parapets, and roof underlay shall be between cappings and underlying timber as shown in E2/AS1 Figure 10.

text: Below ground 2.1 Fill materials 2.1.1 Fill materials, as shown in Figure 7, shall be: a) Bedding material of clean granular non-cohesive material with a maximum particle size of 20 mm, b) Selected fill of fine-grained soil or granular material that is free from topsoil and rubbish and has a maximum particle size of 20 mm, or c) Ordinary fill of excavated material.
paraphrase: If fill materials exists, then fill materials shall be either: a) Bedding material that is clean, granular and non-cohesive and has a maximum particle size of 20 mm, b) Selected fill of fine-grained soil or granular material that does not include topsoil and rubbish and has a maximum particle size of 20 mm, or c) Ordinary fill of excavated material.

text: Drainage 3.3.1 All gully traps shall have (see Figures 2 and 3): The overflow level of the gully dish no less than: 100 mm above unpaved surfaces.
paraphrase: If gully traps exists, then gully traps shall have an overflow level of no less than 100 mm above unpaved surfaces.

text: Drainage 3.3.1 All gully traps shall have (see Figures 2 and 3): At least one discharge pipe discharging to the gully trap to avoid waterseal evaporation,.
paraphrase: If gully traps exists, then there shall be a discharge pipe towards the gully trap.

text: 3.3.1 All gully traps shall have (see Figures 2 and 3): Wastepipes that discharge to the gullytrap arranged to permit easy cleaning of the gullytrap.
paraphrase: If waste pipes are towards the gullytrap, then the waste pipe shall be arranged to permit the gullytrap to be easily cleaned.

text: Drainage 3.3.1 All gully traps shall have (see Figures 2 and 3): The top of the water seal no more than 600 mm below the top of the gully dish.
paraphrase: If gully traps exists, then the top of the gully trap's water seal shall be no more than 600 mm below the top of the gully trap's gully dish.

text: Other types of grease trap such as those that separate or digest grease must be approved by the network utility operator as required by G14/VM1 1.2.
paraphrase: If the grease trap is type other, then the grease trap must be approved by the network utility operator as required by G14/VM1 1.2.

text: Metal cappings installed over parapets and enclosed balustrades. h) Expansion joints shall be provided for joined cappings with a combined length exceeding: i) 12 metres for light coloured steel and stainless steel, 8 metres for dark coloured steel ii) 8 metres for copper iii) 8 metres for aluminium.
paraphrase: If metal cappings are installed over parapets or enclosed balustrades and multiple cappings are joined and either the capping's combined length exceeds 12 metres and capping material is light coloured steel or stainless steel, or the capping's combined length exceeds 8 metres and the capping material is dark coloured steel, copper, or aluminium, then expansion joints shall be provided for the cappings.

text: Metal cappings installed over parapets and enclosed balustrades. i) Where both ends of a capping are constrained, allowance shall be made for expansion.
paraphrase: If metal cappings are installed over parapets and enclosed balustrade and each ends of a capping is constrained, then the capping shall have expansion allowance.

text: Butyl rubber and EPDM cappings shall comply with the following requirements: b) Sides of membrane cappings shall overlap the wall claddings as outlined in Table 7.
paraphrase: If cappings are material butyl rubber and EPDM, then the sides of cappings shall overlap the wall claddings as outlined in E2/AS1 Table 7.

text: Cappings formed by using stucco, EIFS and flush-finished fibre cement materials shall not be used for parapets, (but may be used for enclosed balustrades as described in Paragraph 7.4).
paraphrase: If the capping material is stucco, EIFS and flush-finished fibre cement, then the capping shall not be used for parapets, but the capping may be used for enclosed balustrades as described in E2/AS1 Paragraph 7.4.

text: Timber used to construct decks, enclosed balustrades and other attachments such as pergolas shall comply with B2/AS1.
paraphrase: If the construction is a deck, enclosed balustrade or attachment similar to pergola, and the construction material is timber, then the timber shall comply with B2/AS1.

text: The level of the upper surface of the slatted deck: a) Shall be a minimum of 50 mm below the threshold level for cantilevered decks as shown in Figures 14(b) and 16.
paraphrase: If the deck is slatted and cantilevered, then the deck's upper surface level shall be a minimum of 50 mm below the threshold level as shown in E2/AS1 Figures 14.b and 16.

text: Where drains are laid at gradients of 1:80 or less, verifiable levelling devices shall be used to ensure uniform and accurate gradients.
paraphrase: If drains are laid at gradients of 1:80 or less, then a verifiable levelling devices shall is required for the drain installation.

text: The width of the trench at the top of the pipe shall be no more than 600 mm unless the pipes in the trench are covered with concrete, as shown in Figure 7 (c).
paraphrase: If the pipes located in the trench are not covered with concrete, then the width of the trench where the trench elevation is the same as the elevation of the top of the pipe shall be no more than 600 mm.

text: Where a disused drain is being reinstated, the disused drain shall be tested to verify that the drain is sound.
paraphrase: If a disused drain is being reinstated, then the disused drain shall be tested for soundness.

text: A floor waste shall: Be trapped, discharge 50 mm above the grating of a gully trap.
paraphrase: If a floor waste exists, then the floor waste shall have a gully trap and the floor waste shall have discharge 50 mm above the grating of a gully trap.

text: 2.2.1 Fire safety system types, as defined in Table 2.2, shall be provided throughout firecells and be as specified in: Table 2.2a for risk groups SM and SI.
paraphrase: If firecells are risk groups SM and SI, then the firecell's fire safety system shall be as specified in C/AS2 Table 2.2.a.

text: 2.2.1 Fire safety system types, as defined in Table 2.2, shall be provided throughout firecells and be as specified in: Table 2.2b for risk group CA.
paraphrase: If firecells are risk group CA, then the firecell's fire safety system shall be as specified in Table 2.2.b.

text: 2.2.1 Fire safety system types, as defined in Table 2.2, shall be provided throughout firecells and be as specified in: Table 2.2c for risk groups WB and WS.
paraphrase: If firecells are risk groups WB and WS, then the firecell's fire safety system shall be as specified in Table 2.2.c.

text: 2.2.1 Fire safety system types, as defined in Table 2.2, shall be provided throughout firecells and be as specified in: Table 2.2d for risk group VP.
paraphrase: If firecells are risk groups VP, then the firecell's fire safety system shall be as specified in Table 2.2.d.

text: For slatted decks, a minimum gap of 12 mm shall be provided between the exterior wall and the adjacent decking slat.
paraphrase: If the deck is slatted, then a gap shall be provided between the exterior wall and the adjacent decking slat, the gap size shall be minimum 12 mm.

text: Maintenance of claddings shall be carried out as necessary to achieve the expected durability of the materials - refer to Paragraph 2.5.
paraphrase: If cladding materials have a durability as shown in E2/AS1 Paragraph 2.5, then the cladding requires maintenance.

text: Prevent sagging of roof underlay by either: For R1 underlays, fully support with a corrosion resistant material • For R2 self supporting underlays, laid to maximum 1.2 metre span between adjacent supports.
paraphrase: If the roof has an underlay, then the underlay type shall be either R1 and the underlay shall be fully support with a corrosion resistant material, or the underly shall be type R2 and self supporting and laid to maximum 1.2 metre span between adjacent supports.

text: b) If a gutter depth is reduced to allow entry of a valley gutter, the reduced depth must be used to calculate the capacity of the gutter.
paraphrase: If a gutter depth has a reduction for a valley gutter, then the calculation of the capacity of the gutter must exclude the reduction.

text: Roof; c) For internal, valley, and hidden gutters, have no fixings in gutter bottoms or sides, and be continuously supported on H1.2 minimum treated timber gutter boards or H3 ply which is separated from metal by roof underlay strip.
paraphrase: If gutters are internal, valley, and hidden, then the gutter shall have no fixings in gutter bottoms or sides, and be continuously supported and the support is either on H1.2 minimum treated timber boards or the support is on H3 treated plywood and roof underlay strips are between the plywood and metal.

text: Firecells shall be fire separated from each other by the higher of the two FRRs if the adjoining firecell has a higher FRR (refer to Paragraph 2.3).
paraphrase: If the adjoining firecells have different fire resistance ratings, then the firecells shall have fire separation between them, with the greater of the higher of the two fire resistance ratings.

text: Valley gutters be minimum 250 mm wide where receiving run off from spreaders.
paraphrase: If the gutter type is valley and spreaders discharge into the gutter, then the gutter shall be minimum 250 mm wide.

text: Moisture contained in the building structure at completion of construction shall not be permitted to damage the building elements.
paraphrase: If at completion of construction the building structure contains moisture, then the building element shall not have damage caused by the moisture.

text: Construction moisture includes the moisture contained in: a) Timber products as a result of a treatment or manufacturing process, b) Green timber, and timber or other materials that have been exposed to the weather, and c) Concrete, mortar or plaster that is not completely cured.
paraphrase: If timber products include moisture as a result of a treatment or manufacturing process, materials include moisture and either materials are green timber or timber, or materials are exposed to the weather, and materials include moisture and are concrete, mortar or plaster and is not completely cured, then the building construction has moisture.

text: d) Eaves gutters/spoutings shall: Be to any of the materials outlined for flashings in Paragraph 4.1 except 4.3.9, 4.3.10 and 4.3.11 e) Have a minimum cross sectional area of 2500 mm2 f) Be designed to overflow water to the outside.
paraphrase: If the eaves have gutters, then the gutters material shall be as in E2/AS1 4.1 and not as in E2/AS1 4.3.9, 4.3.10 and 4.3.11, the gutters shall have a minimum cross sectional area of 2500 mm2, and the gutters shall overflow to the outside.

text: Downpipes shall: g) Be formed from any of the materials outlined for flashings in Paragraph 4.1 except 4.3.9, 4.3.10 and 4.3.11 h) Upper roofs shall drain via downpipes directly to ground level where possible, or i) Where discharging to a lower roof, be fitted with a spreader as detailed in Figure 20 j) Have a maximum catchment area of 25 m2 if discharging on to a lower roof area.
paraphrase: If downpipes exist, then the dowpipe shall be any of the materials outlined in E2/AS1 4.1 and not outlined in E2/AS1 4.3.9, 4.3.10 and 4.3.11. Either upper roofs shall have drainage through downpipes to the ground level, or upper roofs shall have drainage towards a lower roof, the downpipe shall be fitted with a spreader as detailed in E2/AS1 Figure 20 and the downpipe shall have a maximum catchment area of 25 m2.

text: Drainage of roof water; Spreaders shall: k) Be to any of the materials outlined for flashings in Paragraph 4.1 except 4.3.9, 4.3.10 and 4.3.11 l) Be to Figure 20 and not be used on masonry tile roofs unless a roof underlay is installed m) Discharge directed away from roofing laps and clear of roof penetrations.
paraphrase: If the roof drainage includes spreaders, then the spreaders shall be any of the materials outlined in E2/AS1 Paragraph 4.1 but not outlined in E2/AS1 4.3.9, 4.3.10 and 4.3.11. The spreaders shall be to Figure 20 and either roof type is not masonry tile, or the roof type is masonry tile and the roof has a underlay. The spreader discharge shall be directed away from roofing laps and clear of roof penetrations.

text: 8.1.6.1 Internal gutters; Internal gutters shall: d) Be constructed to at least the minimum dimensions shown in Figure 52, or the capacity calculated to E1/AS1 plus an additional freeboard depth of 20 mm minimum.
paraphrase: If gutters are internal, then the gutter be at least the minimum dimensions shown in E2/AS1 Figure 52, or the gutter capacity calculated to E1/AS1 plus an additional freeboard depth of 20 mm minimum.

text: The maximum moisture contents shall be: a) For timber framing at the time of installing interior linings, the maximum acceptable moisture content shall be the lesser of: i) 20% for insulated buildings, 24% for non-insulated buildings, or ii) as specified in NZS 3602,.
paraphrase: If the framing is timber and interior linings are installed to the framing, then the framing moisture content medasured at the time of installing interior linings shall be maximum 20 percent for insulated buildings or 24 percent for non-insulated buildings, and maximum the value specified in NZS 360.

text: The maximum moisture contents shall be: For timber weatherboards, 20% at the time of painting,.
paraphrase: If weatherboards are timber, then the weatherboards' maximum moisture contents shall be 20 percent with the weatherboards painting time being equal the moisture contents measurement time.

text: The maximum moisture contents shall be: For timber exterior joinery, 20% at the time of painting,.
paraphrase: If exterior joinery is timber, then the exterior joinery maximum moisture contents shall be 20 percent with the exterior joinery painting time being equal the moisture contents measurement time.

text: The maximum moisture contents shall be: For reconstituted wood products, 18% at all times.
paraphrase: If products are wood that is reconstituted, then the product's maximum moisture contents shall be 18 percent.

text: Valley gutters and hidden gutters shall be constructed as shown in Figures 50 and 51 for the applicable roof cladding (except for membrane roofing) and: a) Not change direction in plan b) Have a minimum underlap to roof cladding as specified in Figures 27, 37, 50, and 51 for the relevant roof cladding c) Be formed from any of the materials outlined for flashings in Paragraph 4.3 except 4.3.10 and 4.3.11 d) Be fixed at upper ends only, and be secured with a purpose-made clip system for the remaining length to enable expansion/ contraction along the length of the gutter e) Discharge into an internal gutter or eaves gutter/spouting.
paraphrase: If gutter type is valley or hidden and the roof type is not membrane, then the gutter shall be constructed as shown in E2/AS1 Figures 50 and 51, and the gutter shall not change direction in plan, the gutter shall have a minimum underlap to roof cladding as specified in E2/AS1 Figures 27, 37, 50, and 51, and the gutter material shall be as outlined in E2/AS1 Paragraph 4.3 and not in 4.3.10 and 4.3.11, and the gutter shall be fixed at upper ends, and be secured with a purpose-made clip system to allow expansion and contraction, and the gutter shall discharge into an internal gutter or eave gutter.

text: In addition f) Have minimum slopes to Table 8 for valley gutters h) Spreaders not discharge directly into a valley gutter.
paraphrase: If the gutter type is valley, then the gutter shall have minimum slopes to E2/AS1 Table 8 and spreaders shall not discharge directly into the gutter.

text: The edge of roofing penetrations over 200 mm wide shall be supported in either direction with additional framing as shown in Figure 21.
paraphrase: If the roof has penetrations over 200 mm wide, then the edge of the penetration shall be supported in either direction with additional framing as shown in E2/AS1 Figure 21.

text: Materials for flashings, gutters and fixings shall be in accordance with Paragraph 4.0, and: a) Be selected from Table 20 to minimise corrosion, and b) Be compatible with mortar and bedding in accordance with Table 21 and Table 22.
paraphrase: If materials are for flashings, gutters or fixings, then the material shall be in accordance with E2/AS1 Paragraph 4.0, and the material shall be selected from E2/AS1 Table 20, and the material shall be compatible with mortar and bedding in accordance with E2/AS1 Table 21 and Table 22.

text: 10.3 Measuring moisture content 10.3.1 Timber; Measurement shall be by the recommended procedure in the Scion (New Zealand Forest Research Institute) publication 'Measurement of moisture content of Wood' using electrical resistance type moisture meters with insulated probes. Representative samplings of measurements shall be taken: a) With meters calibrated to AS/NZS 1080.1 Appendix E b) By inserting probes to at least 1/3 the depth of timber being measured, at a distance exceeding 200 mm from board ends c) Using correction factors for timber species, temperature, and treatment type (outlined in Scion publication above).
paraphrase: If the moisture content of timber is measured, then the measurement shall be by the recommended procedure 'Measurement of moisture content of Wood' in the Scion publication, the measurement shall use electrical resistance type moisture meters with insulated probes. the moisture meters shall be calibrated to AS/NZS 1080.1 Appendix E, and doing the measurement sampling by inserting probes to at least 1/3 the depth of timber being measured, and the probe located at a distance exceeding 200 mm from board ends c) Using measurement correction factors for timber species, temperature, and treatment type, and the measurement correction factors outlined in Scion publication.

text: 10.3 Measuring moisture content 10.3.2 Concrete floors; Measurement shall be made in accordance with BRANZ Bulletin 330 Thin Flooring Materials using hygrometers calibrated to ASTM E 104 - 2002 Standard practice for maintaining constant relative humidity by means of aqueous solutions.
paraphrase: If floors are concrete, then the measurement of the floor's moisture content shall be made in accordance with BRANZ Bulletin 330 using hygrometers with calibration to ASTM E 104 - 2002.
